The and Jesus said to them: Indeed I say to you, that you the having followed me, in the new birth day when may sit the son of the man upon a throne of glory of him, shall sit also you upon twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of the Israel.

And all who left houses, or brothers, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or fields, on account of the name of me, a hundred fold shall receive, and life agelasting shall inherit.
Many but shall be first, last and last first.
Like for is the kingdom of the heavens to a man a householder, who went out with morning to hire laborers into the vineyard of him.
Having agreed and with the laborers for a denarius the day, he sent him into the vineyard of him.
And going out about third hour, he saw others standing in the marketplace idle;
and to them he said: Go and you into the vineyard; and whatever may be just, I will give you. They and went away.
Again going out about sixth and ninth hour, he did in like manner.
About and the eleventh hour going out, he found others standing, and he says to them: Why here stood you all the day idle?
They say to him: Because no one us hired. He says to them: Go also you into the vineyard; and whatever maybe just, you shall receive.
Evening and having come on, says the lord of the vineyard to the steward of him: Call the laborers, and give to them the hire, beginning from the last, till the first.
And having come those about the eleventh hour, received each a denarius.
Having then those first, supposed, that more they shall receive; and received also they each a denarius.
Having received but they murmured against the householder,
saying: That these the last one hour worked, and equal to us them thou hast made, to the having endured the burden of the day, and the burning heat.
He but answering said to one of them: Friend, not I wrong thee; not of a denarius didst thou agree to me?
Take thee thine and go, I wish and to this the last to give as also of thee.
Or not is it lawful to me to do what I will with the my own? or the eye of thee evil is, because I good am?
Thus shall be the last, first; and the first, last. Many for are called, few but chosen.
And going up the Jesus to Jerusalem, he took the twelve disciples privately in the way, and said to them:
Lo, we go up to Jerusalem, and the son of the man will be delivered up to the highpriests and scribes; and they will condemn him to death,
and they will deliver up him to the Gentiles for the to mock, and to scourge, and to crucify; and in the third day he will stand up.
Then came to him the mother of the sons of Zebedee, with the sons of her, prostrating, and asking something from him.
He and said to her: What wilt thou? She says to him: Say that may sit these the two sons of me, one at right of thee, and one at left of thee, in the kingdom of thee.
Answering but the Jesus said: Not you know, what you ask. Are you able to drink the cup, which I am about to drink? They say to him: We are able.
And he says to them: The indeed cup of me you shall drink; the but to sit at right of me and at left of me, not is mine to give, but to whom it has been prepared by the Father of me.
And having heard the ten, were angry on account of the two brothers.
The but Jesus, having called them, said: You know, that the rulers of the nations domineer over them. Not thus great exercise authority over them.
Not thus it shall be among you; but whoever may wish among you great to become, let him be of you servant;
and whoever may wish among you to be first, let him be of you a slave;
even as the son of the man not came to be served but to serve, and to give the life of him a ransom for many.
And departing of them from Jericho, followed him a crowd great.
And lo, two blind men, sitting by the way, hearing that Jesus passes by, cried out, saying: Pity us, O lord, son of David.
The and crowd reproved them, that they might be silent. They but more did cry out, saying: Pity us, O lord, son of David.
And having stopped the Jesus he called them, and said: What do you wish I should do to you?
They say to him: O lord, that may be opened of us the eyes.
Being moved with pity and the Jesus, he touched the eyes of them; and immediately saw again of them the eyes; and they followed him.
And when they were nigh to Jerusalem, and had come to Bethphage by the mountain of the olivetrees, then the Jesus sent away two disciples, saying to them:
You may go to the village the over against you, and immediately you will find an ass having been bound, and a foal with her; having loosed bring to me.
And if any (one) to you should say any (thing), you shall say: That the lord of them need has; immediately and he will need them.
This and all has been done, that might be fulfilled the word spoken through the prophets, saying:
Say to the daughter of Zion: Lo, the king of thee comes to thee meek, and having been set on an ass, even a foal a son of a beast of burden.
Having gone and the disciples, and having done as commanded to them the Jesus,
they led the ass and the foal, and they placed upon them the mantles of them; and they caused to sit on (one) of them.
The and greater crowd spread of themselves the mantles in the way; others and cut off branches from the trees, and scattered in the way.
The and crowds those going before and those following did cry, saying: Hosanna to the son of David; worthy of blessing he coming in name of Lord; hosanna in the highest.
And having entered of them into Jerusalem, was moved all the city, saying: Who is this?
The and crowds said: This is Jesus the prophet, that from Nazareth of the Galilee.
And entered the Jesus into the temple of the God, and cast out all the selling and buying in the temple, and the tables of the money changers overturned, and the seats of the selling the doves;
and he says to them: It is written The house of me, a house of prayer shall be called; you but it have made a den of robbers.
And came to him blind and lame in the temple, and he healed them.
Having seen but the highpriests and the scribes the wonders, which he did, and the boys crying in the temple, and saying: Hosanna to the son of David; they were angry,
and said to him: Hearest thou what these are saying? The and Jesus says them: Yes; Never have you read: That out of mouth of babes and of suckling (ones) thou has perfected praise?
And having left them, he went out of the city into Bethany, and he lodged there
Early but, returning into the city, he was hungry.

And seeing a figtree one by the way, he came to her, and nothing found in her except leaves alone; and he says to her: No more by thee fruit may be produced to the age. And withered immediately the figtree.
And seeing the disciples wondered, saying: How soon withered the figtree?

Answering and the Jesus said to them: Indeed I say to you, if you may have faith, and not should doubt, not only the (miracle) of the figtree you shall do, but also if to the mountain this you should say: Be thou lifted up, and be cast into the sea; it shall be done.
And all, whatever you shall ask in the prayer, believing you shall receive.

And having come to him into the temple, came to him teaching the highpriests and the elders of the people, saying: By what authority these (things) doest thou? and who to thee gave the authority this?
Answering and the Jesus said to them: I will ask you also I word one; which if you may say to me, also I to you will tell, by what authority these (things) I do;
the dipping of John whence was? from heaven, or from men? They and reasoned among themselves, saying: If we should say, from heaven; he will say to us: Why then not did you believe to him?
if but we should say from men; we fear the crowd; all for hold the John as a prophet.
And they answering to the Jesus said: Not we know. Said to them and he: Neither I say to you by what authority these (things) I do.
What but to you seems right? A man had children two; and coming to the first, he said: Son, go, today work in the vineyard of me.
He and answering said: Not I will; afterward but having changed his mind, he went.
And coming to the other, he said just the same. He and answering said: I lord, and not went.
Who of the two did the will of the father? They say to him: The first. Says to them the Jesus: Indeed I say to you, that the taxgatherers and the harlots go before you in the kingdom of the God.
Came for to you John in a way of righteousness, and not you believed him; the but taxgatherers and the harlots believed him; you and seeing not repented afterwards, of the to believe him.

Another parable hear you; a man was a householder, who planted a vineyard, and a hedge to it placed around, and digged in it a winepress, and built a tower; and let out it to husbandmen, and went abroad.
When and drew near the time of the fruits, he sent the slaves of him, to the husbandmen, to receive the fruits of it.
And having taken the husbandmen the slaves of him, him indeed they flayed, him and they killed, him and they pelted with stones.
Again he sent other slaves, greater the first; and they did to them in like manner.
Afterwards and he sent to them the son of him, saying: They will regard the son of me.
The but husbandmen, seeing the son, said among themselves: This is the heir; come, we may kill him, and may retain the inheritance of him.
And having taken him, they cast out of the vineyard, and killed.
When therefore may come the lord of the vineyard, what will he do to the husbandmen to those?
They say to him: Wretches wretchedly destroy them; and the vineyard will let out to other husbandmen, who will render to him the fruits in the seasons of them.
He says to them the Jesus: Never have you read in the writings: A stone which rejected they building, the same was made into a head of a corner; from Lord was this, and it is wonderful in eyes of us?
On account of this I say to you, that shall be taken from you the kingdom of the God, and shall be given to a nation making the fruits of her.
And he falling on the stone this, shall be broken; on whom but it shall fall, it will crush to pieces him.
And having heard the highpriests and the Pharisees the parables of him, knew, that about them he says.
And seeking him to seize, they feared the crowds; since as a prophet him they held.
And answering the Jesus again said to them in parables, saying:
Has been likened the kingdom of the heavens to a man a king, who made marriagefeasts to the son of him,
and he sent the slaves of him, to call the having been invited to the marriagefeasts; and not they would to come.

Again he sent other slaves, saying: Say to the having been called; Lo, the dinner of me I prepared; the bullocks of me and the fatlings having been killed, and all (things) ready, come to the marriagefeasts.
They but neglecting went away; he indeed to the own field, he and to the traffic of him.
The and remainder having seized the slaves of him, insulted and killed.
Having heard and the king, was wroth; and having sent the armies of him, destroyed the murderers those, and the city of them burned.
Then he says to the slaves of him; the indeed marriagefeast ready is, they but having been called not were worthy.
Go you therefore to the outlets of the ways, and whoever you may find, call you to the marriagefeasts.
And having gone forth the slaves those into the ways, they brought together all, as many as they found, bad ones both and good ones; and was filled the marriagefeast of reclining ones.
Having entered and the king to see the reclining ones, saw there a man not having been clothed a garment of marriage;
and he says to him: Friend, how didst thou enter here, not having a garment of marriage? He but was struck speechless.
Then said the king to the servants: Having bound of him feet and hands, take him, and cast into the darkness the outer; there shall be the weeping and the gnashing of the teeth.
Many for are called, few but picked out.
Then having gone the Pharisees counsel took, how him they might insnare in word.

And they sent away to him the disciples of them with the Herodians, saying: O teacher, we know, that true thou art, and the way of the God in truth thou teachest, and not there is care to thee about no one; not for thou lookest into face of men.
Say therefore to us, what to thee seems right? is it lawful to give tribute to Caesar, or not?
Knowing but the Jesus the wickedness of them, said: Why me tempt you hypocrites?
Show you to me the coin of the tribute. They and brought to him a denarius.
And he says to them: Of whom the likeness this and the inscription?
They say to him: Of Caesar. Then he says to them: Give you back then the (things) of Caesar to Caesar; and the (things) of the God to the God.
And having heard they wondered: and leaving him they departed.
In that the day came to him Sadducees, they saying, not to be a resurrection; and they asked him,
saying: O teacher, Moses said: If any one should die not having children, shall marry the brother of him the wife of him, and shall raise seed to the brother of him.
There were now with us seven brothers; and the first having married, died; and not having seed, left the wife of him to the brother of him.
Likewise also the second, and the third till the seven.
After and of all died also the woman.
In the therefore resurrection, of whom of the seven shall be a wife? all for had her.
Answering and the Jesus said to them: You go astray, not knowing the writings, neither the power of the God.
In for the resurrection neither they marry, nor are given in marriage, but as messengers of the God in heaven are.
About but the resurrection of the dead (ones) not have you read that having been spoken to you by the God, saying:
I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob? Not is the God, a God of dead (ones), but of living (ones).
And having heard the crowds, were astonished at the teaching of him.
The and Pharisees, hearing that he silenced the Sadducees, were assembled on the same;
and asked one out of them, a lawyer, tempting him and saying:
O teacher, which commandment great in the law?
The and Jesus said to him: Thou shalt love Lord the God of thee, in whole the heart of thee, and in whole the soul of thee, and in whole the mind of thee.
This first and great commandment.
Second and like to it; Thou shalt love the neighbor of thee, as thyself.
In these the two commandments whole the law and the prophets are hung.
Having been assembled and of the Pharisees, asked them the Jesus,
saying: What to you thinks about the Anointed? of whom a son is he? They say to him: Of the David.
He says to them: How then David in spirit Lord of him calls? saying:
Said the Lord to the lord of me; Sit thou at right of me, till I may place the enemies of thee a footstool of the feet of thee.
If then David calls him lord, how a son of him is he?
And no one was able to him to answer a word; nor dared any one from that the day to ask him any more.
Then the Jesus spoke to the crowds and to the disciples of him,
saying: Upon the Moses seat sit the scribes and the Pharisees.
All therefore, whatever they say to you to observe observe you and do you; according to but the works of them not do you; They say for, and not they do.
They bind for burdens heavy and oppressive, and place upon the shoulders of the men; of the and finger of them not they will to move them.
All but the works of them they do to the to be seen to the men. They widen and the phylacteries of them, and they enlarge the tufts of the mantles of them;
they love and the upper couch in the feasts, and the first seats in the synagogues,
and the salutations in the markets, and to be called by the men rabbi, rabbi;
You but not may be called rabbi; one for is of you the leader; all but you brethren are.
And father not you may call of you on the earth; one for is the Father of you, he in the heavens.
Neither be ye called leaders; one for of you is the leader, the Anointed.
The but greater of you, shall be of you a servant.
Who and shall exalt himself, shall be humbled; and who shall humble himself, shall be exalted.
Woe but to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites; because you devour the houses of the widows, and for a show long are praying; through this you shall receive heavier judgment.
Woe to you, scribes, and Pharisees, hypocrites; because you shut the kingdom of the heavens in presence of the men; you for not enter, nor the entering you permit to enter.
Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees hypocrites; because you go about the sea and the dry, to make one proselyte; and when he becomes, you make him a son of Gehenna double of you.
Woe to you guides blind, the saying: Whoever may swear by the temple, nothing it is; who but ever may swear by the gold of the temple, he is bound.
O fools and blind; which for greater is? the gold, or the temple, that sanctifying the gold?
Also; Whoever may swear by altar, nothing it is; who but ever may swear by the gift that upon it, he is bound.
O fools and blind; which for greater? the gift, or the altar, that sanctifying the gift?
He then answering by the altar swears by it and by all the (things) upon it;
and the swearing by the temple, swears by it and by the (one) having inhabited it;
and he swearing by the heaven, swears by the throne of the God and by the (one) sitting upon it.

Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites; because you tithe the mint, and the dill, and the cummin; and pass by the weightier (things) of the law, the justice, and mercy, and the faith. These but it is binding to do, and those not to omit.
Guides blind; the straining out the gnat the but camel swallowing down.
Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites; because you cleanse the outside of the cup and of the dish, within but they are full of rapine and injustice.
O Pharisee blind, cleanse first the inside of the cup and of the dish, that may become also the outside of them clean.
Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites; because you are like to tombs having been whitened, which without indeed appear beautiful, within but are full of bones of dead and of all uncleanness.
So and you without indeed appear to the men just, within but full are of hypocrisy and of lawlessness.
Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites; because you build the tombs of the prophets, and adorn the monuments of the just,
and say: If we had been in the days of the fathers of us, not we had been partakers of them in the blood of the prophets.
So that you testify to yourselves, that sons you are of the having killed the prophets.
And you fill you the measure of the fathers of you.
O serpents, O broods of vipers; how can you flee from the judgment of the Gehenna?

Because of this, lo, I send to you prophets, and wise men, and scribes; and out of them you will kill and will crucify, and out of them you will scourge in the synagogues of you and pursue from city to city;

so that may come upon you all blood righteous, being shed upon the earth from the blood of Abel the just to the blood of Zecharias a son of Barachias, whom you killed between the temple and the altar.
Indeed I say to you, that shall come these (things) all upon the generation this.

Jerusalem, Jerusalem, the killing the prophets, and stoning the having been sent to her; how often I desired to gather the children of thee, what manner gathers a bird the brood of herself under the wings? and not you were willing.
Lo, is left to you the house of you a desert.
I say for to you: Not not me you may see from now, till you may say: Having been blessed he coming in name of Lord.
And being come out the Jesus was going from the temple; and came the disciples of him to point out to him the buildings of the temple.
The and Jesus said to them: Not you see all these? Indeed I say to you, not not should be left here a stone upon stone, which not shall be thrown down.

Sitting and of him upon the mountain of the olive tree, came to him the disciples privately saying: Tell to us, when these (things) shall be? and what the sign of the thy presence and of the end of the age?
And answering the Jesus said to them: Take heed, not any one you may deceive.
Many for shall come in the name of me, saying: I am the Anointed; and many they shall deceive.
You shall be about and to hear wars, and reports of wars; see, not you be disturbed; it behooves for all to take place; but not yet is the end.
Shall be raised up for nation against nation, and kingdom against kingdom; and there shall be famines, and plagues, and earthquakes in places.
All but these a beginning of sorrows.
Then they shall deliver up you to affliction, and shall kill you; and you shall be being hated by all of the nations on account of the name of me.
And then shall be caused to stumble many; and each other shall deliver up, and shall hate each other.
And many falseprophets shall be raised up, and shall deceive many;
and because of the to be increased the lawlessness, shall be cooled the love of the many.
He but holding out the end, the same shall be saved.
And shall be published this the glad tidings of the kingdom in whole the habitable, for a testimony to all the nations; and then shall come the end.
When therefore you may see the abomination of the desolation, the word having been spoken through Daniel the prophet, having stood in place holy; (he reading let him think;)
then they in the Judea, let them flee to the mountains;
he upon the roof, not let him go down, to take the out of the house of him;
and he in the field, not let him turn back, to take the mantle of him.
Woe and to the in womb having and to the giving suck in those the days.
Pray you and, that not may be the flight of you of winter, nor in sabbath.
Shall be for then affliction great, such as not has been from a beginning of world till the now, nor not not may be.
And except were shortened the days those, not should be saved all flesh; on account of but the chosen shall be shortened the days those.
Then if any to you should say: Lo, here the Anointed, or here; not you believe.
Shall be raised for false anointed ones and false prophets, and shall give signs great and wonders, so as to deceive, if possible even the chosen.
Lo, I have foretold to you.
If then they should say to you: Lo, in the desert he is; not you should go out; Lo, in the retired places; not you should believe;
As for the lightning comes out from east, and shines to west, so shall be also the presence of the son of the man.
Where for ever may be the carcass, there will be gathered the eagles.

Immediately but after the affliction of the days those, the sun shall be darkened, and the moon not shall give the light of her, and the stars shall fall from the heaven, and the powers of the heavens shall be shaken.

And then shall appear the sign of the son of the man in the heaven; and then shall lament all the tribes of the earth, and they shall see the son of the man coming upon the clouds of the heaven, with power and glory much;
and he will send the messengers of him with of trumpet a voice great; and they shall gather the chosen (ones) of him from the four winds, from extremities of heavens to extremities of them.
From but the figtree learn you the parable; when already the branch of her may be tender, and the leaves may put forth, you know, that near the summer;
So also you, when you may see all these, know you, that near it is at doors.
Indeed I say to you, not not may pass away the generation this, till all these may be done.
The heaven and the earth shall pass away; the but words of me not not may pass away.
About and the day that and hour no one knows, nor the messengers of the heavens, except the Father alone.
As and the days of the Noah, even so will be also the presence of the son of the man.
As for they were in the days the before the flood eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, till of which day entered Noah into the ark,
and not they knew, till came the flood and took away all; even so will be also the presence of the son of the man.
Then two shall be in the field; the one is taken away and the one is left.
Two grinding in the mill; one is taken away, and one is left.
Watch you therefore, because not you know, in what hour the lord of you comes.
This but know you, that if had known the householder in what watch the thief comes, he would have watched, and not would have allowed to be dugthrough the house of him.
On account of this also you be ready; because in which hour not you think, the son of the man comes.
Who then is the faithful slave and prudent, whom placed the lord of him over the domestics of him, of the to give to them the food in season?
Blessed the slave that, whom coming the lord of him shall find doing so.
Indeed I say to you, that over all the possessions of him he will place him.
If but should say the bad slave that in the heart of him: Delays the lord of me to come;
and should begin to strike the fellowslaves, may eat and also may drink with those getting drunk;
shall come the lord of the slave that in a day, in which not he expects, and in an hour, in which not he knows;
and shall cut asunder him, and the part of him with the hypocrites will place; there will be the weeping and the gnashing of the teeth.
Then will be compared the kingdom of the heavens ten virgins, who having taken the lamps of them, went out to a meeting of the bridegroom.
Five and were of them prudent, and five foolish.
Who foolish, having taken the lamps of them, not took with themselves oil.
The but prudent took oil in the vessels of them with the lamps of them.
Delaying and the bridegroom, nodded all, and did sleep.
Of middle and night a cry was raised; Lo, the bridegroom comes; go out to a meeting of him.
Then arose all the virgins those, and put in order the lamps of them.
The but foolish to the prudent said: Give to us out of the oil of you, because the lamps of us are extinguished.
Answered but the prudent, saying: Lest not it might suffice to us and to you; go you rather to the selling, and buy to yourselves.
Going away and of them to buy, came the bridegroom; and the prepared ones entered with him into the nuptialfeasts; and was closed the door.
Afterwards and came also the remaining virgins, saying: O lord, O lord, open to us.
The but answering said: Indeed I say to you, not know you.
Watch you therefore, because not you know the day, nor the hour.
Like for a man going abroad called the own slaves, and delivered to them the goods of him.
and to him indeed he gave five talents, to him and two, to him and one; to each according to the own power; and went abroad immediately.
Going and he the five talents having received, traded with them, and made other five talents.
Likewise also he the two, gained also he other two.
He but the one having received having retired digged in the earth, and hid the silver of the lord of him.
After but time much comes the lord of the slaves those, and adjusts with them an account.
And coming he the five talents having received, brought other five talents, saying: O lord, five talents to me thou delivered; see, other five talents I gained upon them.
Said to him the lord of him: Well, O slave good and faithful; over a few (things) thou wast faithful, over many thee I will place; enter into the joy of the lord of thee.
Coming and also he the two talents having received, said: O lord, two talents to me thou deliveredst; lo, other two talents I gained upon them;
Said to him the lord of him: Well, O slave good and faithful; over a few (things) thou wast faithful, over many thee I will place; enter into the joy of the lord of thee.
Coming and also he the one talent having taken, said: O lord, I knew thee, that hard thou art a man, reaping where not thou sowed, and gathering whence not thou scatteredst;
and being afraid, going away I hid the talent of thee in the earth; lo, thou hast the thine.
Answering and the lord of him said to him: O wicked slave and slothful, didst thou know, that I reap where not I sowed, and gather whence not I scattered?
It behooved then thee cast the silver of me to the bankers; and coming I might have received the mine with interest.
Take you therefore from him the talent, and give to him having the ten talents.
To the for having all shall be given, and he shall abound; from but the not having, even what he has, shall be taken away from him.
And the useless slave cast you into the darkness the outer; there shall be the weeping and the gnashing of the teeth.
When and may come the son of the man in the glory of him, and all the messengers with him, then shall be sit on a throne of glory of him,
and will be gathered in presence of him all the nations; and he will separate them from each other, as the shepherd separates the sheep from the goats;
and and he will place the indeed sheep by right of him, the and goats by left.
Then will say the king to the by right of him: Come the having been blessed of the Father of me, inherit the having been prepared to you kingdom from a foundation of world.
I hungered for, and you gave to me to eat; I thirsted, and you gave drink to me; a stranger I was, and you entertained me;
naked, and you clothed me; I was sick, and you visited me; in prison I was, and you came to me.
Then shall answer to him the just one, saying: O lord, when thee we saw hungering, and nourished? or thirsting, and we gave drink?
When and thee we saw a stranger, and we entertained? or naked, and we clothed?
When and thee we saw sick, or in prison, and we came to thee?
And answering the king will say to them: Indeed I say to you, in whatever you did, to one of these of the brothers of me of the least, to me you did.
Then he will say also to the of left: Go from me the having been cursed into the fire the everlasting, that having been prepared to the accuser and to the messengers of him.
I hungered for, and not you gave to me to eat; I thirsted, and not you gave drink to me;
a stranger I was, and not you entertained me; naked, and not you clothed me; sick, and in prison, and not you visited me.
Then will answer and they, saying: O lord, when thee we saw hungering, or thirsting, or a stranger, or naked, or sick, or in prison, and not we served thee?
Then he will answer them, saying: Indeed I say to you, in as much not you did to one of these of the least, neither to me you did.
And shall go away these into a cuttingoff agelasting; the and just ones into life agelasting.
And it happened, when had finished the Jesus all the words these, he said to the disciples of him:
You know, that after two days the passover comes on; and the son of the man is delivered into the to be crucified.
Then were assembled the highpriests, and the scribes, and the elders of the people, into the court of the highpriest, that being called Caiaphas;
and they consulted, that the Jesus with deceit they might seize and might kill.
They said but: Not in the feast, that not a tumult there should be among the people.
The and Jesus having arrived in Bethany, in a house of Simon the leper,
came to him a woman, an alabaster box of balsam having great value, and she poured upon the head of him being reclined.
Seeing and the disciples of him, were displeased, saying: On account of what the loss this?
She was able for this to have sold of much, and to have given to poor.
Knowing and the Jesus said to them: Why troubles present you the woman? a work for good she was wrought for me.
Always for the poor you have with yourselves; me but not always you have.
Having cast for she the balsam this upon the body of me, to the to prepare for burial me she did.
Indeed I say to you, wherever may be published the glad tidings this, in whole the world, shall be spoken also what did she, for a memorial of her.
Then going one of the twelve he being named Judas Iscariot, to the highpriests,
said: What are you willing to me to give, and I to you will deliver up him? They and paid to him thirty pieces of silver.
And from then he did seek opportunity, that him he might deliver up.
The and first of the feasts of unleavened bread came the disciples of the Jesus, saying to him: Where wilt thou we make ready to thee to eat the passover?
He and said: Go you into the city to the certain one, and say to him: The teacher says: The season of me nigh is; to thee I will make the passover with the disciples of me.
And did the disciples as commanded to them the Jesus; and they prepared the passover.
Of evening and being come he reclined with the twelve.
And of eating of them, he said: Indeed I say to you, that one of you will deliver up me.
And being grieved exceedingly, they began to say to him each one of them: Not I am, O lord?
He but answering said: He dipping with me in the bowl the hand, this me, will deliver up.
The indeed son of the man goes as it has been written about him; Woe but to the man that, through whom the son of the man is delivered up; good it was to him, if not was born the man that.
Answering and Judas, he delivering up him, said: Not I am, rabbi? He says to him: Thou hast said.
Eating and of them, having taken the Jesus the loaf and having blessed, broke, and did give to the disciples, and said: Take you, eat you; This is the body of me.
And having taken the cup, and having given thanks, he gave to them, saying: Drink you out of it all;
this for is the blood of me, that of the new covenant, that about many being shed for forgiveness of sins.
I say but to you, that not not I will drink from now of this the product of the vine, till the day that, when it I drink with you new in the kingdom of the Father of me.
And having sung a hymn, they departed to the mountain of the olivetrees.
Then he says to them the Jesus: All you will be stumbled at me in the night this; it is written for: I will smite the shepherd, and will be scattered the sheep of the fold.
After but the to be raised me, I will go before you to the Galilee.
Answering and the Peter said to him: If all shall be stumbled at thee, I never will be stumbled.
Said to him the Jesus: Indeed I say to thee, that in this the night, before a cock to have crowed, thrice thou wilt deny me.
Says to him the Peter: And if it may behoove me with thee to die, not not thee I will deny. In like manner also all the disciples said.
Then comes with them the Jesus into a place being called Gethsemane, and says to the disciples: Sit you here, while going away I shall pray there.
And having taken the Peter and the two sons of Zebedee, he began to be sorrowful and to be in anguish.
Then he says to them: Extremely sorrowful is the soul of me to death; remain you here and watch you with me.
And going forward a little, he fell on face of him, praying, and saying: O Father of me, if possible it is, let pass from me the cup this; but not as I will, but as thou.
And he comes to the disciples, and finds them sleeping, and he says to the Peter: So not could you one hour to watch with me?
Watch you and pray you, that not you enter into temptations; and indeed spirit ready, the but flesh weak.
Again, a second time going away, he prayed, saying: O Father of me, if not it is possible this, the cup to pass from me, except it I drink, be done the will of thee.
And coming he finds them again sleeping; (were for of them the eyes weighed down;)
and leaving them, going away again, he prayed a third time, the same word speaking.
Then he comes to the disciples of him, and says to them: Sleep you the remainder and rest you? lo, has come nigh the hour, and the son of man is delivered up into hands of sinners.
Arise, let us go; lo, has come nigh he delivering up me.
And while of him speaking, lo, Judas, one of the twelve, came, and with him a crowd great with swords and clubs, from the highpriests and elders of the people.
He and delivering up him, gave to them a sign, saying: Who ever I may kiss, he it is; seize him.
And immediately approaching to the Jesus, he said to him: Hail rabbi; and kissed him.
The but Jesus said to him: Companion, for what art thou present? Then coming they laid the hands on the Jesus, and they seized him.
And lo, one of the with Jesus, stretching the hand, drew out the sword of him; and striking the slave of the highpriest, cut off of him the ear.
Then says to him the Jesus: Return thee the sword into the place of her; all for the taking a sword, by a sword shall perish.
Or thinkest thou, that not I am able now to entreat the Father of me, and will furnish to me more then twelve legions of messengers?
How then should be fulfilled the writings, that thus it must be done.
In that the hour said the Jesus to the crowds: As upon a robber came you out with swords and clubs, to take me; every day with you I did sit teaching in the temple, and not you seized me.
This but all has been done, that might be fulfilled the writings of the prophets. Then the disciples all, leaving him, they fled.
They and seizing the Jesus, they led to Caiaphas the highpriest, where the scribes and the elders were assembled.
The but Peter followed him at a distance, to the palace of the highpriest; and having gone in, sat with the attendants, to see the end.
The and highpriests and the elders and the highcouncil whole sought false testimony against the Jesus, so that him they might deliver to death.
And not they found, many falsewitnesses having come. Afterwards but coming two falsewitnesses
said: This affirmed; I am able to destroy the temple of the God, and in three days to build it.
And rising up the highpriest said to him: Nothing answerest thou? what these of thee testify against?
The but Jesus was silent. And answering the highpriest said to him: I adjure thee by the God of the living, that to us thou tell, if thou art the Anointed, the son of the God.
Says to him the Jesus: Thou has said. Besides I say to you, from now you shall see the son of the man sitting at right of the power, and coming upon the clouds of the heaven.
Then the highpriest rent the clothes of him, saying: That he blasphemes; what further need have we of witnesses? see, now you heard the blasphemy of him.
What to you thinks? they and answering said: Liable to death he is.
Then they spat into the face of him, and beat with the fist him: they and struck with palms of their hands,
saying: Prophesy to us, O Anointed, who is he striking thee?
The and Peter without sat in the courtyard. And came to him one maidservant, saying: Also thou wast with Jesus of the Galilee.
He but denied in presence of them all, saying: Not I know what thou sayest.
Going out and he into the portico, saw him another, and says to those there; also this was with Jesus of the Nazareth.
And again he denied with an oath; That not I know the man.
After a little and approaching those having stood by, said to the Peter: Certainly also thou of them art; even for the speech of thee manifest thee makes.
Then he began to curse, and to swear. That not I know the man. And instantly a cock crew.
And remembered the Peter of the word of the Jesus, declaring to him; That before a cock crows, thrice thou wilt deny me. And going out, he wept bitterly.
Morning and having come, a council held all the highpriests and the elders of the people against the Jesus, so us to deliver to death him.
And binding him, they led, and delivered up him to Pontius Pilate the governor.
Then seeing Judas, that betraying him, that he was condemned, repenting he returned the thirty pieces of silver to the highpriests and the elders,
saying: I sinned, having delivered up blood innocent. They but said: What to us? Thou wilt see.
And hurling the pieces of silver in the temple, he withdrew; and having gone forth strangled himself.
The and highpriests, taking the pieces of silver, said: Not it is lawful to put them into the treasury, since price of blood it is.
Counsel and taking, they bought with them the field of the potter, to bury the strangers.
Therefore is called the field that, a field of blood, to the day.
Then was fulfilled the word spoken through Jeremiah the prophet, saying: And I took the thirty pieces of silver, the price of the having been valued, whom they valued from sons of Israel,
and gave them for the field of the potter; even as directed me a Lord.
The and Jesus stood in presence of the governor; and asked him the governor, saying: Thou art the king of the Jews? The and Jesus said to him: Thou sayest.
And in the to be accused him by the highpriests and the elders, nothing he answered.
Then says to him the Pilate: Not thou hearest, how many things of thee they bear witness against?
And not he answered him to not even one word; so as to astonish the governor greatly.
At and a feast was accustomed the governor to release one to the crowd prisoner, whom they wished.
They had and then a prisoner noted, being called Barabbas.
Having being assembled then of them, said to them the Pilate: Which wish you I release to you? Barabbas or Jesus, the being called Anointed?
He knew for, that through envy they had delivered up him.
Being seated and of him upon the tribunal, sent to him the wife of him, saying: Nothing to thee and to the just one that; many things for I suffered this day in a dream because of him.
The but highpriests and the elders persuaded the crowds, that they should ask the Barabbas, the and Jesus they might destroy.
Answering and the governor said to them: Which wish you of the two I shall release to you? They and said: Barabbas.
He says to them the Pilate: What then shall I do Jesus, the being called Anointed? They say to him all: Let him be crucified.
The and governor said: What for evil has he done? They but vehemently cried, saying: Let him be crucified.
Seeing and the Pilate that nothing profits, but rather a tumult is made, taking water, he washed the hands before the crowd, saying: Innocent I am from the blood of the just of this; you shall see.
And answering all the people said: The blood of him upon us, and upon the children of us.
Then he released to them the Barabbas, the and Jesus having scourged he delivered up, that he might be crucified.
Then the soldiers of the governor taking the Jesus into the judgment hall, they gathered together to him whole the company.
And having stripped him, they put on to him a soldiers cloak scarlet.
And braiding a crown of thorns, placed upon the head of him, and a reed of the right of him; and bending the knee in presence of him, mocked him, saying: Hail, the king of the Jews.
And spitting on him, they took the reed, and struck on the head of him.
And when they had mocked him, they took off him the soldiers cloak, and put on him the garments of him; and led away him into the to be crucified.
Going out and, they met a man a Cyrenian, by name Simon; him they compelled, that he might carry the cross of him.
And coming into a place being called Golgotha, which is being called of a skull a place,
they gave to him to drink vinegar with gall having been mixed; and having tasted, not he would drink.
Crucifying and him, they divided the garments of him, casting a lot.
And being seated they watched him there.
And they placed above the head of him the accusation of him having been written: This is Jesus the king of the Jews.
Then were crucified with him two robbers; one by right, and one by left.
Those and passing along reviled him, shaking the heads of them,
and saying: He overthrowing the temple, and in three days building, save thyself; if a son thou art of the God, come down from the cross.
Likewise and also the highpriests, mocking with the scribes and elders, said:
Others he saved, himself not is able to save; if a king of Israel he is, let him come down now from the cross, and we will give credit to him.
He trusted in the God; let him rescue now him, if he wishes him; he said for: That of God I am a son.
That through it also the robbers, those being crucified with him, reproached him.
From now sixth hour darkness was on all the land, till hour ninth.
About and the ninth hour cried out the Jesus with a voice great, saying: Eli, Eli; lama sabachthani? that is: O God of me, O God of me; why me hast thou forsaken?
Some and of those there standing, having heard, said: For Elias he cries this.
And immediately running one of them, and taking a sponge, filling and of vinegar, and attaching to a reed, gave to drink him.
The but others said: Leave alone; we may see, if comes Elias, will be saving him.
The then Jesus, again crying with a voice great, resigned the breath.
And lo, the curtain of the temple was rent into two, from above to below; and the earth was shaken, and the rocks were rent,
and the tombs were opened; and many bodies of the having been asleep holy ones were raised,
and coming forth from the tombs, after the resurrection of him went into the holy city, and appeared to many.
The and centurion and those with him watching the Jesus, seeing the earthquake and the things being done, they were afraid much, saying: Truly of God a son was this.
Were and there women many from a distance beholding; who followed the Jesus from the Galilee, ministering to him;
among whom was Mary the Magdalene, and Mary the of the James and Joses mother, and the mother of the sons of Zebedee.
Evening and being come, came a man rich from Arimathea, by name Joseph, who also himself was discipled to the Jesus.
He coming to the Pilate requested the body of the Jesus. Then the Pilate ordered to be given the body.
And taking the body the Joseph, wrapped it fine linen cloth clean;
and laid it in the new of himself tomb, which he had hewn in the rock; and having rolled a stone great of the door of the tomb he went away.
Was and there Mary the Magdalene, and the other Mary, sitting over against the sepulchre.
The now next day, which is after the preparation, were assembled the highpriests and the Pharisees to the Pilate,
saying: O sir, we remember, that that the deceiver said while living: After three days I will arise.

Do thou command therefore to be made fast the tomb till the third day lest coming the disciples of him, might steal him, and might say to the people: He has been raised from the dead; and will be the last fraud worse of the first.
Said to them the Pilate: You have a guard; go you, make fast as you know.
They and going made fast the tomb, having sealed the stone, with the guard.
After now sabbath, to the dawning into first of week, came Mary the Magdalene, and the other Mary, to see the tomb.
And lo, a shaking occurred great; a messenger for of a Lord, descending from heaven, approaching rolled away the stone from the door, and sat upon it.
Was and the aspect of him like lightning, and the garments of him white as snow.
From and the fear of him shook the keepers, and became as dead (men).
Answering and the messenger said to the women: Not be afraid you; I know for, that Jesus that having been crucified you seek.
Not he is here; he has been raised for, even as he said. Come see the place, where lay the Lord.
And quickly going tell the disciples of him, that he has been raised from the dead; and lo, he goes before you into the Galilee; there him you will see; lo, I told you.
And coming out quickly from the tomb with fear and joy great, they ran to inform the disciples of him.
As and they went to inform the disciples of him, and lo, the Jesus met them, saying: Hail you. They and having approached laid hold of him the feet, and prostrated to him.
Then says to them the Jesus: Not be afraid; go you, inform to the brethren of me, so that they may go into the Galilee, and there me they shall see.
Going away and of them, lo, some of the keepers, coming into the city, told to the highpriests all the (things) having been done.
And being assembled with the elders, counsel and taking, pieces of silver sufficient they gave to the soldiers, saying:
Say you, That the disciples of him, by night coming, stole him, of us being asleep.
And if should be reported this to the Governor, we will persuade him, and you free from care we will make.
They and having received the pieces of silver, did as they were taught. And is spread abroad the word this among Jews till the day.
The and eleven disciples went to the Galilee, to the mountain, where had appointed them the Jesus.
And seeing him, they prostrated to him; they but doubted.
And approaching the Jesus, spoke to them, saying: Has been given to me all authority in heaven and on earth.
Going forth disciple you all the nations, immersing them into the name of the Father and of the Son and of the holy spirit;
teaching them to observe all, whatever I have charged you. And lo, I with you am all the days, till the end of the age.
A beginning of the glad tidings of Jesus Anointed, a son of the God.
As it is written in Esaias the prophet: Lo, I send the messenger of me before face of thee, who will prepare the way of thee.
A voice crying out in the desert; Make you ready the way of a lord, straight make you the beaten ways of him.
Was John dipping in the desert, and publishing a dipping of reformation into forgiveness of sins.
And went out to him all the Judea country, and the Jerusalem all; and were dipped in the Jordan river by him, confessing the sins of them.
Was now John having been clothed hairs of a camel, and a belt made of skin around the loins of him, and eating locusts and honey wild.
And he cried out saying: Comes the mightier of me after me, of whom not I am worthy bowed down to loose the string of the sandals of him.
I indeed dipped you in water; he but will dip you in spirit holy.
And it came to pass in those the days, came Jesus from Nazareth of the Galilee, and was dipped by John into the Jordan.
And immediately ascending from the water, he saw rending the heavens, and the spirit, as a dove, descending upon him.
And a voice came out of the heavens: Thou art the son of me the beloved in whom I delight.
And immediately the spirit him casts into the desert.
And he was in the desert days forty, being tempted by the adversary, and was with the wild beasts; and the messengers ministered to him.
After now the to be delivered up the John, came the Jesus into the Galilee, preaching the glad tidings of the kingdom of the God,
and saying: That has been fulfilled the season, and has come nigh the majesty of the God; reform you, and believe you in the good message.
Walking and by the sea of the Galilee, he saw Simon and Andrew the brother of him, casting a fishing net in the sea; they were for fishers.
And said to them the Jesus: Come after me, and I will make you to be fishers of men.
And immediately leaving the nets of them, they followed him.
And going thence a little, he saw James the of the Zebedee, and John the brother of him, and themselves in the ship were mending the nets;
and immediately he called them. And leaving the father of them Zebedee in the ship with the hirelings, they went after him.
And they went into Capernaum; and immediately to the sabbath going into the synagogue, he taught.
And they were amazed at the teaching of him; he was for teaching them as authority having, and not as the scribes.
And was in the synagogue of them a man in spirit unclean, and he cried out,
saying: Let alone, what to us and to thee, Jesus O Nazarene, comet thou to destroy us? I know thee who thou art, the holy of the God.
And rebuked him the Jesus, saying: Be silent, and come out of him.
And convulsing him the spirit the unclean, and crying a voice great, came out of him.

And they were astonished all, so as to reason among themselves, saying: What is this? what the teaching the new this? that with authority even to the spirits to the unclean he enjoins and they harken to him.
Went out and the report of him forthwith into whole the country of the Galilee.
And instantly, out of the synagogue being come, he went into the house of Simon and Andrew, with James and John.
The and motherinlaw of Simon was laid down having a fever; and immediately they spoke to him about her.
And coming he raised her, having laid hold of the hand of her; and left her the fever immediately; and ministered to them.
Evening and being come, when set the sun, they brought to him all those sickness having, and those being demonized;
and the city whole having been assembled was at the door.
And he healed many sick having various diseases; and demons many cast out, and not allowed to speak the demons, because they knew him.
And early, night much, having arisen he went out, and depart into a desert place, and there prayed.
And eagerly followed him the Simon and those with him.
And having found him, they say to him: That all seek thee.
And he says to them: We must go into the neighboring towns, that also there I may preach; for this because I have come out.
And he was proclaiming in the synagogues of the, in whole the Galilee, and the demons casting out.
And comes to a leper, beseeching him and kneeling him, and saying to him: That if thou wilt, thou art able me to cleanse.
The and Jesus being moved with pity, stretching out the hand, touched of him, and says to him; I will, be thou cleansed.
And having said of him, immediately departed from him the leprosy, and he was cleansed.
And having strictly charged him, immediately he sent forth him,
and says to him: See, to no one anything thou tell; but go, thyself show to the priest, and offer for the purification of thee what enjoined Moses, for a witness to them.

He but going out began to publish many (things) and spread abroad the word, so as no longer him to be able publicly into a city to enter; but without in desert place he was, and they went to him from all parts.
And again he went into Capernaum after days; and it was reported, that into a house he is.
And immediately were gathered together many, so as no longer to contain not even the places near the door; and he spake to them the word.
And they come to him a paralytic bringing, being carried by four.
And not being able to come nigh to him through the crowd, they uncovered the roof, where he was; and having dug through they let down the bed upon which the paralytic was laid.
Seeing and the Jesus the faith of them, says to the paralytic: Son, are forgiven of thee the sins.
Were but some of the scribes there sitting and reasoning in the hearts of them:
Why this thus speaks blasphemy? Who is able to forgive sins, if not one the God?
And immediately knowing the Jesus to the spirit of himself, that thus they reasoned among themselves, said to them: Why these (things) reason you in the hearts of you?
Which is easier? to say to the paralytic: Are forgiven of thee the sins? or to say: Arise, take up of thee the bed, and walk?
That but you may know, that authority has the son of the man on the earth to forgive sins; (he says to the paralytic:)
To thee I say: Arise, take up the bed of thee, and go into the house of thee.
And he was raised immediately, and taking up the bed, went out in presence of all; so as to astonish all, and to glorify the God, saying: That never thus we saw.
And he went out again by the sea; and all the crowds came to him, and he taught them.
And passing on he saw Levi the of the Alpheus, sitting at the custom house, and says to him: Follow me. And arising up he followed him.
And it happened in the to recline at table him in the house of him, and many publicans and sinners reclined with the Jesus and the disciples of him; they were for many, and they followed him.
And the scribes and the Pharisees seeing him eating with the publicans and sinners, said to the disciples of him: Why that with of the publicans and sinners he eats and drinks?
And hearing the Jesus says to them: No need have those being well of a physician, but those sick being. Not I came to call just (ones) but sinners.
And were the disciples of John and the Pharisees fasting; and they come, and they say to him: Why the disciples of John and those of the Pharisees fast; those but to thee disciples not fast?
And said to them the Jesus: Not are able the sons of the bridechamber, in which the bridegroom with them is, to fast? so long a time with themselves they have the bridegroom, not are able to fast.
Will come but days, when may be taken away from them the bridegroom, and then they will fast in that the day.
No one a patch of cloth unfulled sews on to a mantle old; if but not, takes away the patch of itself the new of the old, and worse a rent becomes.
And no one puts wine new into bottles old; if but not, bursts the wine the new the bottles, and the wine is spilled, and the bottles are lost; but wine new into bottles new must be put.
And it came to pass to go him in the sabbath through the cornfields, and began the disciples of him a way to make plucking the ears of corn.
And the Pharisees said to him: See, why do they in the sabbath, what not is lawful?
And he said to them: Never have you known, what did David, when need he had, and was hungry, he and those with him?
How he went into the house of the God, to Abiathar of the highpriest, and the loaves of the presence did eat, which not is lawful to eat if not the priests, and he gave also to those with him being?
And he said to them: The sabbath because of the man was made, not the man because of the sabbath.
So that a lord is the son of the man even of the sabbath.
And he entered again into the synagogue; and was there man having been withered having the hand,
and they closely watched him, if to the sabbath he will heal him, that they might accuse him.
And he says to the man to that having been withered having the hand: Arise in the midst.
And he says to them: Is it lawful to the sabbath to do good or to do evil? a life to save, or to destroy? They but were silent.
And looking round them with anger, being grieved at the hardness of the hearts of them, he says to the man: Stretch out the hand of thee. And he stretched it out; and was restored the hand of him.
And coming out the Pharisees, immediately with the Herodians a council held against him, how him they might destroy.
And the Jesus with the disciples of him withdrew to the sea; and a great multitude from the Galilee followed him; and from the Judea, and from Jerusalem,
and from the Idumea, and beyond the Jordan, and those about Tyre and Sidon, a multitude great, having heard what things he did, came to him.
And he spake to the disciples of him, that a small vessel should attend him, because of the crowd, that not they might throng him.
Many for he cured, so as to rush to him, that him they might touch, as many as had scourges.
And the spirits the unclean, when him gazing on, fell before him, and cried, saying: That thou art the son of the God.
And many times he charged them, that not known him they should make.
And he goes up into the mountain, and calls whom would he; and they came to him.
And he appointed twelve, that they should be with him, and that he might send them to preach,
and to have authority to cure the diseases, and to cast out the demons.
And he put on to the Simon a name Peter;
and James that of the Zebedee, and John the brother of the James; and he put on them names Boanerges, that is, sons of thunder;
and Andrew, and Philip, and Bartholomew, and Matthew, and Thomas, and James that of the Alpheus, and Thaddeus, and the Simon the Canaanite,
and Judas Iscariot, who even delivered up him.
And they come into a house. And came together again a crowd, so as not to be able them not even bread to eat.
And having heard those with him, went out to restrain him; they said for: That he is out of place.
And the scribes, those from Jerusalem having come down, said: That Beelzebul he has; also; That by the chief of the demons he casts out the demons.
And having called them, in parables he said to them: How is able an adversary and adversary to cast out?
And if a kingdom against herself should be divided, not able to stand the kingdom that;
and if a house against herself should be divided, not able to stand the house that;
and if the adversary has risen up against himself and has been divided, not able to stand, but an end he has.
No one is able the household goods of the strong man, entering into the house of him, to plunder, if not first the strong man he should bind; and then the house of him he will plunder.
Indeed I say to you, that all will be forgiven to the sons of the men the sins, and the evil speakings, whatever they may revile;
who but ever may speak evil to the spirit the holy, not has forgiveness to the age, but liable is of agelasting judgment.
Because they said: A spirit unclean he has.
Comes then the mother of him and the brothers of him; and without standing they sent to him, calling him.
And sat a crowd about him; said and to him: Lo, the mother of thee and the brothers of thee without are seeking thee.
And he answered to them, saying: Who is the mother of me, or the brothers of me?
And looking about round those about him sitting, he says: Lo the mother of me, and the brothers of me.
Who for ever may do the will of the God, this a brother of me, and a sister of me and a mother is.
And again he began to teach by the sea; and was assembled to him a crowd great, so as him entering into the ship, to sit in the sea; and all the crowd by the sea on the land was.
And he taught them in parables many, and said to them in the teaching of him:
Hear you: Lo, went out the sower of the (seed) to sow.
And it happened in the sowing, this indeed fell on the path; and came the birds, and ate it.
Another and fell on the rocky ground, where not it had earth much; and immediately it sprung up, through the not to have a depth of earth.
Sun and having arisen, it was scorched, and through the not to have a root, was dried up.
And another fell into thorns; and sprung up the thorns, and chocked it, and fruit not it gave.
And another fell into the ground the good; and it bore fruit springing up and increasing; and bore one thirty, and one sixty, and one a hundred.
And he said: He having ear to hear, let him hear.
When and he was alone, asked him those about him, with the twelve, the parables.
And he said to them: To you it is given to know the secret of the kingdom of the God; to them but to those without in parables the all (things) are done;
that seeing they may see, and not they may see; and hearing they may hear, and not they may hear; lest they should turn, and should be forgiven to them the sins.
And he says to them: Nat know you the parable this? and how all the parables will you know?
He sowing, the word sows.
These and are they by the path, where is sown the word, and when they may hear, immediately comes the adversary, and takes the word that having been sown in the hearts of them.
And these are like those on the rocky ground being sown, who, when they may hear the word, immediately with joy they receive it;
and not they have a root in themselves, but for a reason they are; then occurring trial or persecution through the word, immediately they are offended.
And others are those into the thorns, being sown; these are those the word hearing,
and the cares of the age, and the delusion of the wealth, and the about the other (things) strong desires entering in choke the word; and unfruitful it becomes.
And these are those upon the ground the good being sown, who hear the word, and accept; and bear fruit, one thirty, and one sixty, and one a hundred.
And he said to them: Neither the lamp comes, that under the measure it may be placed, or under the couch? not that on the lampstand it may be placed?
Not for is any thing hidden, which if not it may be disclosed; nor was stored away, but that into light it may come.
If any one has ears to hear, let him hear.
And he said to them: Consider you, what you hear. In what measure you measure, it shall be measured to you.
Who for ever may have, it shall be given to him; and who not has, even what he has will be taken from him.
And he said: Thus is the kingdom of the God, as if a man should cast the seed on the earth,
and should sleep and wake night and day, and the seed should germinate and grow up, as not knows he.
Of its own accord for the earth bears fruit, first, a plant, then an ear, then full grain in the ear.
When but may be ripe the fruit, immediately he sends the sickle, for is ready the harvest.
And he said: To what may be compare the kingdom of the God? or by what parable may we compare her?
As a grain of mustard, which, when it may be sown on the earth, less of all of the seeds it is of those on the earth;
and when it may be shown, it springs up and becomes of all herbs greater, and produces branches great, so as to be under the shadow of it the birds of the heaven to build nests.
And such like parables many he spoke to them the word, even they were able to hear.
Without but a parable not he spoke to them; privately but to the disciples of himself he explained all.
And he says to them in that the day, evening being come: We may pass over to the other side.
And having left the crowd they took him, as he was in the ship; also other and ships was with him.
And arose a squall of wind great; the and waves dashed into the ship, so as it was now to fill.
And was he in the stern, on the pillow sleeping; and they awoke him, and they said to him: O teacher, not it concerns thee, that we perish?
And having arisen he rebuked the wind, and said to the sea: Be silent, be still. And ceased the wind, and was a calm great.
And he said to them: Why timid are you so? how not you have faith?
And they feared a fear great, and said to one another: Who then this is, for even the wind and the sea hearken to him.
And they came to the other side of the sea, into the country of the Gadarenes.
And having come to him out of the ship, immediately met him out of the tombs a man in spirit unclean,
who the dwelling had in the tomb; and not even with chains no one was able him to bind,
for the him many times with fetters and chains to have been bound, and to have been hurt by him the chains, and the fetters to have been broken; and no one him was able to tame;
and always, night and day, in the tombs and in mountains he was crying out, and cutting himself with stones.
Seeing and the Jesus from a distance, he ran, and prostrated to him;
and crying out with voice great, said: what to me and to thee, Jesus, O son of the God of the highest? I will adjure thee the God, not me thou mayest torment.
(He had said for to him: Come out the spirit the unclean out of the man.)
And he asked him: What thy name? and he says to him: Legion name to me; for many we are.
And he besought him many times, that not them he would send out of the country.
Was and there near to the mountain a herd of swine great feeding.
And besought him the demons, saying: Dismiss us into the swine, that into them we may go.

And gave leave to them immediately the Jesus. And having come out the spirits the unclean entered into the swine; and rushed the herd down the precipice into the sea; they were and about two thousand; and were choked in the sea.
Those and feeding them fled, and reported to the city, and to the villages. And they came out to see, what is that having been done.
And they come to the Jesus, and they behold the being demonized sitting and having been clothed, and being of sane mind, and having been possessed by the legion; and they were afraid.
And related to them those having seen, how it happened to the one being demonized, and about the swine.
And they began to entreat him to depart from the coasts of them.
And entering of him into the ship, besought him he having been demonized, that he might be with him.
And not he suffered him, but he says to him: Go into the house of thee to the friends, and relate to them, how much to thee the Lord has done, and has pitied thee.
And he went, and began to publish in the Decapolis, how much had done to him the Jesus; and all were astonished.
And having passed over the Jesus in the ship again to the other side, were gathered a crowd great to him; and he was by the sea.
And lo, comes one of the synagoguerulers, by name Jairus; and seeing him, he fell to the feet of him,
and besought him much, saying: That the littledaughter of me last end is; that coming thou mayest put to her the hands, so that she may be saved; and she shall live.
And he went with him; and followed him a crowd great, and pressed on him.
And a woman certain being in a flow of blood years twelve,
and many things having suffered under many physicians, and having spent the things of her all, and nothing having seen benefited, but rather into the worse state having come,
having heard about Jesus, having come in the crowd behind, touched the mantle of him.
(She said for: That even if the cloths of him I may touch, I shall be saved.)
And immediately was dried up the source of the blood of her; and knew to the body, that was saved from the scourge.
And immediately the Jesus knowing in himself the out of himself power having gone out, having turned round in the crowd, said: Who of me touched the clothes?
And said to him the disciples of him: Thou seest the crowd pressing on thee; and sayest thou: Who me touched?
And he was looking round to see the (woman) this having done.
The but woman, fearing and trembling, having known what was done on her, came and fell down to him, and told to him all the truth.
He but said to her: Daughter, the faith of thee has saved thee; go in peace, and be thou well from the scourge of thee.
While of him speaking, they came from the synagoguerulers, saying: That the daughter of thee is dead; why yet troubled thou the teacher?
The but Jesus immediately, having heard the word being spoken, says to the synagogueruler: Not fear, only believe thou.
And not he suffered no one him to follow, except Peter, and James, and John the brother of James.
And he comes into the house of the synagogueruler, and he sees a tumult, and weeping and wailing much.
And having entered he says to them: Why are you troubled and do you weep? the child not is dead, but sleeps.
And they derided him. He but, having sent out all he takes the father of the child, and the mother and those with him, and goes in, where was the child.
And having grasped the hand of the child, he says to her: Talitha, cumi; which is being translated: The girl, to thee I say, arise.
And immediately arose the girl, and walked about; she was for years twelve. And they were astonished with an astonishment great.
And he charged them much, that no one might know this; and spake to have given to her to eat.
And he went out thence, and came into the country of himself; and follow him the disciples of him.

And being come sabbath, be began in the synagogue to teach. And many hearing were astonished, saying: Whence to this these things? and what the wisdom that being given to him? and miracles so great through the hands of him are done.
Not this is the carpenter, the son of Mary, brother and of James, and Joses, Juda, and Simon? and not are the sisters of him here with us? And they were stumbled in him.
Said but to them the Jesus: That not is a prophet without honor, except in the country of himself, and among the relatives, and in the house of himself.
And not was able there no one miracle to do, except a few sick having put on the hands, were cured.
And he wondered because of the unbelief of them. And he went out round the villages round about, teaching.
And he calls the twelve, and he began them to send two two; and he gave to them authority of the spirits of the unclean,
and he charged them, that nothing they should take for a way, except a staff only; no bag, no bread, not into the belt copper money;
but having been shod sandals; and not you may put on two coats.
And he said to them: Whence if you may enter into a house, there remain till you may go away from thence.
And whoever not may receive you, nor hear you, going away from thence, shake out the dust that under the feet of you, for a witness to them.
And having gone out they published, that they should reform;
and demons many they cast out, and anointed with oil many sick ones, and they were cured.

And heard the king Herod, (wellknown for was the name of him,) and wellknown for was the name of him,) and he said: That John he dipping out of dead has been raised, and through the work the mighty powers in him.
Others said: That Elias he is. Others and said: That a prophet he is, like one of the prophets.
Having heard for the Herod, said: That whom I beheaded John, he is raised from dead.
Himself for the Herod, sending seized the John, and bound him in prison, through Herodias, the wife of Philip of the brother of himself, for her he had married.
Said for the John to the Herod: That not it is lawful to thee to have the wife of the brother of thee.
The and Herodias had a grudge against him and wished him to destroy; and not was able.
The for Herod feared the John, knowing him a man just and holy; and protected him; and hearing him, many things he did, and gladly him he heard.
And having come a day convenient, when Herod to the birthday of himself a feast he made to the nobles of himself, and to the commanders, and to the chiefs of the Galilee;

and having entered of the daughter of her of the Herodias, and dancing, and having pleased the Herod and those reclining at table, said the king to the little girl: Ask me, whatever thou wilt, and I will give to thee.
And he swore to her: That whatever me thou mayst ask, I will give to thee, till half of the kingdom of me.
The and going out, said to the mother of herself: What shall I ask? She and said: The head of John the dipper.
And coming in immediately with haste to the king, she asked, saying: I will that to me thou wouldst give instantly on a plate the head of John the dipper.
And very sorry having become the king, because of the oaths and those reclining at table not he would her reject.
And immediately sending the king a guardsman, he ordered to be brought the head of him. He and going forth cut off the head of him in the prison;
and brought the head of him on a plate, and gave her to the little girl; and the little girl gave her to the mother of herself.
And having heard the disciples of him, came, and took the dead body of him, and placed it in a tomb.
And were assembled the apostles to the Jesus, and reported to him all, and what they did, and what they taught.
And he said to them: Come you yourselves privately into a desert place, and rest you a little. Were for those coming and those going many; and not even to eat they had leisure.
And they went into a desert place to the ship privately.
And they saw them going away; and knew many; and on foot from all of the cities they ran together there.
And coming out he saw great a crowd, and was moved with pity towards them, for they were as sheep, not having a shepherd; and he began to teach them many things.
And already time much having gone, coming to him the disciples of him, they say: That a desert is the place, and already time much;
dismiss them, that going into the surrounding country and villages, they may buy themselves loaves; any for they might eat not they have.
He but answering said to them: Give to them you to eat. And they say to him: Going may we buy denarii two hundred loaves, and give to them to eat?
He but says to them: How many loaves have you? go you and see you. And having ascertained, they say: Five and two fishes.
And he ordered them to make recline all, company company, on the green grass.
And they reclined squares squares, by a hundred, and by fifty.

And taking the five loaves and the two fishes, looking up to the heaven, he gave praise, and broke the loaves, and gave to the disciples of him, that they might set before them; and the two fishes he divided to all.
And they ate all, and were filled.
And they took up of fragments twelve baskets full, and of the fishes.
And were those having eaten the loaves, five thousand men.
And immediately he urged the disciples of himself to step into the ship, and to go before to the other side to Bethsaida, while he should dismiss the crowd.
And having sent away them, he went into the mountain to pray.
And evening having come, was the ship in middle of the sea; and he alone upon the land.
And he saw them tormented in the rowing; was for the wind opposite to them. And about fourth watch of the night comes towards them, walking on the sea; and wished to pass them.
They but, seeing him walking on the sea, they thought a phantom to be, and they cried out.
All for him saw, and were terrified. And immediately he spoke with them, and says to them: Take courage; I am, not be afraid.
And he went up to them into the boat; and ceased the wind. And greatly out of measure in themselves they were amazed and wondered.
Not for they understood about the loaves; was for the heart of them having been stupified.
And having passed over they came to the land Gennesaret; and drew to the shore.
And coming out of them out of the ship, immediately knowing him,
running about whole the adjacent country that, they began on the couches those sickness having to carry out, where they heard, that there he is.

And wherever he entered into towns, or cities, or villages, in the markets they placed those being sick, and they besought him, that if even the tuft of the mantle of him they might touch; and whoever touched him, were saved.
And were gathered to him the Pharisees, and some of the scribes, having come from Jerusalem;
and seeing some of the disciples of him with common hands, that is unwashed, eating loaves;
(the for Pharisees and all the Jews, if not with fist they may wash the hands, not they eat, holding the tradition of the elders;
and from a market, if not they might dip, not they eat; and other many things is, which they received to hold, dippings of cup, and of pots, and of copper vessels, and of couches);
then asked him the Pharisees and the scribes: Why the disciples of thee not walk according to the tradition of the elders, but with common hands they eat the loaf?
He but answering said to them: That well prophesied Esaias about you the hypocrites, as it is written: This the people with the lips me honor, the but heart of them far off is removed from me.
In vain but they worship me, teaching teachings, commandments of men.
Leaving for the commandment of the God, you hold the tradition of the men, dippings of pots and of cups; and other similar such like many things you do.
And he said to them: Well you set aside the commandment of the God, that the tradition of you you may keep.
Moses for said: Honor the father of thee and the mother of thee; and: He cursing father or mother, a death let him die.
You but say: If should say man to the father or the mother, Corban (which is, a gift), whatever out of me thou mightest be profited;
and no more you suffer him any thing to do for the father of himself, or for the mother of himself
making void the word of the God for the tradition of you, which you delivered; and similar such like many things you do.
And having called all the crowd, he said to them: Hear me all, and be instructed.
Nothing is outside of the man, entering into him, which is able him to make common; but the things proceeding from him, those is the things making common the man.
If any one has ears to hear, let him hear.
And when he entered into a house from the crowd, asked him the disciples of him concerning the parable.
And he says to them: Thus also you without understanding are? Not know you, that all that without, entering into the man, not is able him to make common?
that not goes of it into the heart, but into the belly; and into the privy goes out, cleansing all the foods.
He said and: That the out of the man, proceeding forth, that makes common the man.
Within for out of the heart of the men the purposes the evil proceeds; adulteries, fornications, murders,
thefts, covetousnesses, villianies, deceit, intemperance, eye evil, evil speaking, pride, folly;
all these the things evil within comes forth, and makes common the man.
