And thence arising, he went into the borders of Tyre and Sidon; and entering into the house, no one he wished to know; and not he was able to be concealed.
Having heard for a woman about him, of whom had the little daughter of herself a spirit unclean, having come fell down to the feet of him;
(was now the woman a Greek, a Syrophenician to the birth;) and she besought him, that the demon he would cast out of the daughter of herself.
The but Jesus said to her: Let alone first to be filled the children; not for good it is, to take the bread of the children, and to cast to the dogs.
She but answered, and says to him: Yes, sir; even for the dogs under the table eatest from of the crumbs of the children.
And he said to her: Through this the word go; has come out the demon from the daughter of thee.
And having gone into the house of her, she found the demon having gone out, and the daughter having been laid upon the bed.
And again coming out from the borders of Tyre and Sidon, he came to the sea of the Galilee, through midst of the borders of Decapolis.
And they bring to him a deaf man a stammerer, and they entreat him that he might place to him the hand.
And having taken him from the crowd privately, he put the fingers of himself into the ears of him, and spitting he touched the tongue of him;
and looking up to the heaven, he groaned, and says to him: Ephphatha, that is, be opened.
And immediately were opened of him the ears; and was loosed the bond of the tongue of him, and he spoke plainly.
And he charged them, that no one they should tell; what but he to them charged, more abundantly they published.
And beyond measure they were astonished, saying: Well all (things) he has done; and the deaf ones he makes to hear, and the dumb ones to speak.
In those the days, very great crowd being, and not having any thing they could eat, having called the disciples of himself he says to them:
I have pity on the crowd; because now days three, they continue with me and not they have any thing they can eat.
And if I dismiss them fasting into house of themselves, they will faint on the way; come for of them a great distance have come.
And answered to him the disciples of him: Whence these will be able any one here to satisfy of loaves in a desert place?
And he asked them: How many have you loaves? They and say: Seven.

And he gave orders to the crowd to recline upon the ground; and taking the seven loaves, giving thanks he broke, and gave to the disciples of himself, that they might set before; and they set before the crowd.
And they had small fishes a few; and giving praise, he said: Place before also them.
They ate and, and were filled; and they took up over and above of fragments, seven large baskets.
Were and those having eaten, about four thousand; and he dismissed them.
And immediately entering into the ship with the disciples of himself, he came into the parts of Dalmanutha.
And came forth the Pharisees, and began to argue with him, seeking of him a sign from the heaven, tempting him.
And groaning deeply to the spirit; of himself, he says: Why the generation this a sign seeks? Indeed I say to you, if shall be given to the generation this a sign.
And leaving them, entering again into the ship, he departed to the other side.
And they forgot to take loaves, and except one loaf not they had with themselves in the ship.
And he charged them saying: Look you, beware you of the leaven of the Pharisees, and of the leaven of Herod.
And they reasoned with one another saying: Because loaves not we have.
And knowing the Jesus he says to them: Why reason you, because loaves not you have? Not yet perceive you, neither understand you? Yet having been stupified have you the heart of you?
Eyes having not see you? and ears having not hear you? and not remember you?
When the five loaves I broke to the five thousand, how many baskets full of fragments took you up? They say to him: Twelve.
When and the seven to the four thousand, how many large baskets full of fragments took you up? They and said: Seven.
And he said to them: How is it not you understand?
And he comes to Bethsaida. And they bring to him a blind man and beseech him, that him he would touch.
And having taken the hand of the blind man, he led him outside of the village; and having spit into the eyes of him, having placed the hands to him, he asked him, if any thing he sees.
And looking up he says: I see the men, like trees, walking.
Then again he placed the hands upon the eyes of him, and he made him look up and was restored, and he saw plainly every one.
And he sent him to house of him saying: Neither into the village mayest thou enter, nor mayest thou tell any one in the village.
And departed the Jesus and the disciples of him into the villages of Caesarea of the Philip. And on the way he asked the disciples of himself, saying to them: Who me they say the men to be?
They and answered: John the dipper; and others, Elias; others and, one of the prophets.
And he says to them: You but who me you say to be? Answering and the Peter says to him: Thou art the Anointed.
And he strictly charged them, that no one they should tell about him.

And he began to teach them, that must the son of the man many things to suffer, and to be rejected of the elders and of the highpriests and of the scribes, and to be killed, and after three days to stand up;
and plainly the word he spoke. And taking aside him the Peter, he began to rebuke him.
He but turning round, and seeing the disciples of himself, he rebuked the Peter, saying: Go thou behind me, adversary; because not thou thinkest the things of the God, but the things of the men.
And having called the crowd with the disciples of himself, he said to them: Whoever wishes after me to follow, let him deny himself, and let him bear the cross of himself, and let him follow me.
Who for ever may wish the life of himself to save, shall loose her. Who but ever may lose the of himself life on account of me and of the glad tidings shall save her.
(What for will it profit a man, if he should win the world whole, and he should forfeit the life of himself?
or what shall give a man in exchange for the life of himself?)

Who for ever may be ashamed me and the my words in the generation this the adulterous and sinful, also the son of the man will be ashamed him, when he may come in the glory of the Father of himself with the messengers of the holy ones.
And he said to them: Indeed I say to you, that are some of those here having stood, who not not shall taste of death, till they may see the royal majesty of the God having come in power.
And after days six takes the Jesus the Peter, and the James and John, and leads up them into a mountain high privately alone; and he was transfigured in the presence of them
And the garments of him became glittering, white extremely as snow, such as a fuller upon the earth not is able to make white.
And appeared to them Elias with Moses; and were talking with the Jesus.
And answering the Peter says to the Jesus: Rabbi, good it is us here to be; and we may make tents three, to thee one, and Moses one, and Elias one.
Not for he knew any thing he might say; there were for terrified.
And there came a cloud overshadowing them; and came a voice out of the cloud: This is the son of me the beloved; him hear you.
And suddenly looking round, no longer no one they saw, but the Jesus alone with themselves.
Coming down and of them from the mountain, he charged them, that to no one they should relate what they saw, except when the son of the man out of dead ones should be raised.
And the word they kept to themselves, arguing, what is that out of dead ones to be raised.
And they asked him, saying: That say the scribes, that Elias must to come first?
He and answering said to them: Elias indeed coming first; restores all things, and how it is written about the son of the man, that many things he should suffer, and should be despised.
But I say to you, that both Elias has come, and they have done to him whatever they wished, even as it is written about him.
And coming to the disciples, he saw a crowd great about them, and scribes disputing with them.
And immediately all the crowd, seeing him, were awestruck, and running to saluted him.
And he asked them: What dispute you wish with them?
And answering one out of the crowd said: O teacher, I brought the son of me to thee, having a spirit dumb.
And wherever him it may seize, it convulses him; and he foams, and grinds the teeth of him, and pines away. And I spoke to the disciples of thee, that it they might cast out, and not they had power.
He and answering to them says: O generation without faith, till when you shall I be? till when shall I bear you? Bring you him to me.
And they brought him to him. And seeing him, immediately the spirit convulsed him; and falling upon the ground, he rolled, foaming.
And he asked the father of him: How long a time is it, since this happened to him? He and said: From a child;
and often him both into fire has cast and into waters, that it might destroy him; but if any thing thou canst do, give aid to us, having pity on us.
The and Jesus said to him: That, if thou art able to believe; all things are possible to the believing.
And immediately crying out the father of the child, with tears he said: I believe help thou of me the unbelief.
Seeing and the Jesus, that runs together a crowd, he rebuked the spirit the unclean, saying to it: The spirit the dumb and deaf, I to thee command; Come out of him, and no more enter into him.
And crying out, and many times convulsing, it came out. And he became as dead, so that many to say, that he is dead.
The but Jesus taking him of the hand, raised up him; and he stood up.
And having come him into a house, the disciples of him asked him privately: That we not were able to cast out it?
And he said to them: This the kind by nothing is able to go out, if not in prayer and fasting.
And thence departing, he passed through the Galilee; and not was willing, that any one should know.
He taught for the disciples of himself, and said to them: That the son of the man is delivered up into hands of men, and they will kill him; and having been killed, the third day he will rise.
They but did not understand the word, and were afraid him to ask.
And he came to Capernaum; and in the house being, he asked them: What in the way among yourselves were you disputing?
but were silent; with one another for they had disputed on the way, who greater.
And sitting down, he called the twelve, and says to them: If any one desires first to be, he will be of all last, and of all a servant.
And taking a little child, he placed it in midst of them, and embracing in his arms it, he said to them:
Whoever one of the such little children may receive in the name of me, me receives; and whoever me may receive, not me receives, but the having sent me.
Answered and to him John, saying: O teacher, I saw one to the name of thee casting out demons; and we forbade him, because not he follows us.
He but Jesus said: Not do you forbid him. No one for is, who will do a mighty work in the name of me, and will be able readily to speak evil of me.
Who for not is against you, for you is.
Who for ever may give drink to you a cup of water, in name, because of Anointed you are, indeed I say to you, not not he may lose the reward of himself.
And whoever may insnare one of the little ones, of the believing into me, good it is to him rather, if hangs a stone of a mill around the neck of him, and has been cast into the sea.
And if may insnare thee the hand of thee, cut thou off her; good to thee it is crippled into the life to enter, than the two hands having to go into the Gehenna, into the fire the inextinguishable,
where the worm of them not dies, and the fire not is quenched.
And if the foot of thee may insnare thee, cut thou off him; good it is to thee to enter into the life lame, than the two feet having to be cast into the Gehenna, into the fire the inextinguishable,
where the worm of them not dies, and the fire not is quenched.
And if the eye of thee may insnare thee, cast thou out him; good to thee it is oneeyed to enter into the kingdom of the God, than two eyes having to be cast into the Gehenna of the fire,
where the worm of them not dies, and the fire not is quenched.
Every one for with fire shall be salted; and every sacrifice with salt shall be salted.
Good the salt; if but the salt without taste may become, with what it will you season? Have you in yourselves salt, and be you at peace with one another.
And from thence arising he comes into the borders of the Judea, by the other side if the Jordan; and come together again crowds he taught them.
And approaching Pharisees asked him: If it is lawful for a man a wife to release? trying him.
He and answering said to them: What to you did enjoin Moses?
They and said: Moses allowed a scroll of separation to be written, and to release.
And answering the Jesus said to them: For the hardness of heart of you he wrote to you the commandment this.
From but a beginning of creation a male and a female he made them the God
On account of this shall leave a man the father of himself and the mother, and shall be closely united to the wife of himself.
And shall be the two into flesh one. So that no longer they are two, but one flesh.
What then the God has joined together, a man not disunites.
And in the house again the disciples of him concerning of the him asked him.
And he says to them: Whoever may release the wife of himself, and may marry another, commits adultery with her.
And if a woman may release the husband of herself, and may be married to another, commits adultery.
And they brought to him little children, that he might touch them; the but disciples rebuked those bringing.
Seeing but the Jesus was displeased, and said to them: Allow the little children to come to me, not hinder them; of the for such like is the kingdom of the God.
Indeed I say to you, whoever not may receive the kingdom of the God like a little child, not not may enter into her.
And embracing in his arms them, having placed the hands upon them, he blessed them.
And going out of him into a way, running up one, and kneeling before him, he asked him: O teacher good, what must I do, that life agelasting I may inherit?
The and Jesus said to him: Why me callest thou good? no one good, if not one, the God.
The commandments thou knowest: Not thou must commit adultery; Not thou must kill; Not thou must steal; Not thou must testify falsely; Not thou must defraud; Honor the father of thee, and the mother.
He but answering said to him: O teacher, these all I kept from childhood of me.

He but Jesus looking on him, loved him, and said to him: One to thee lacks; go, whatever thou hast sell, and give to the poor; and thou shalt have treasure in heaven; and hither, follow me, take up the cross.
He but looking sad at the word, went away sorrowing; he was for having possessions many.
And looking round the Jesus, says to the disciples of himself: How hardly those the riches having into the kingdom of the God shall enter.

They and disciples were astonished at the words of him. The but Jesus again answering says to them: Children, how difficult it is those having confidence in the riches, into the kingdom of the God to enter.
Easier it is a camel through the hole of the needle to pass, than a rich man into the kingdom of the God to enter.
They and greatly were amazed, saying among themselves: And who is able to be saved?
Looking on and to them the Jesus says: With men impossible but not with the God; all for possible is with the God.
Began the Peter to say to him: Lo, we left all, and followed thee.

Answering the Jesus said: Indeed I say to you, no one is, who has left houses, or brothers, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or fields, on account of me and on account of the glad tidings,
if not he may receive a hundred fold, now in the season this, houses, and brothers, and sisters, and mothers, and children, and fields, with persecutions, and in the age to come life agelasting.
Many but shall be first, last; and last, first.

They were and in the way going up to Jerusalem; and was going before them the Jesus; and they were amazed, and following they were afraid. And taking aside again the twelve, he began to them to tell the things being about to him to happen:
For lo, we go up to Jerusalem, and the son of the man will be delivered up to the highpriests and to the scribes; and they will condemn him to death, and they will deliver up him to the Gentiles,
and they will mock him, and they will scourge him, and they will spit upon him, and they will kill him; and the third day he will stand up.
And come to him James and John, the sons of Zebedee, saying: O teacher, we wish, that whatever we may ask, thou mayst do for us.
He but said to them: What do you wish to do me for you?
They and said to him: Give to us, that one at right of thee, and one at left of thee we may sit in the glory of thee.
The and Jesus said to them: Not you know what you ask. Are you able to drink the cup, which I drink, and the dipping, which I am dipped, to be dipped?
They and said to him: We are able. The and Jesus said to them: The indeed cup, which I drink, you will drink; and the dipping, which I am dipped, you will be dipped;
the but to sit at right of me and at left, not is mine to give, but to whom it has been prepared.
And having heard the ten, they began to be angry about James and John.
The but Jesus having called them, he says to them: You know, that those presuming to rule the nations, lord it over them, and the great of them exercise authority over them.
Not so but it shall be among you; but whoever may wish to become great among you, shall be of you a servant;
and whoever may wish of you to become first, shall be of all a slave.
And for the son of the man not came to be served, but to serve, and to give the life of himself a ransom for many.
And they come into Jericho; and going out of him from Jericho, and the disciples of him, and a crowd great, a son of Timeus, Bartimeus the blind, sat by the way begging.
And hearing, that Jesus the Nazarene it is, he began to cry out and to say: The son of David, Jesus, have pity me.
And rebuked him many, so that he might be silent; he but much more cried out: O son of David, have pity on me.
And stopping the Jesus, said him to be called; and they called the blind, saying; to him: Take courage, rise up; he calls thee.
He and throwing off the mantle of himself, arising came to the Jesus.
And answering says to him the Jesus: What dost thou wish I may do to thee? The and blind said to him: Rabboni, that i may see again.
The and Jesus said to him: Go; the faith of thee has saved thee. And immediately he saw again, and followed him in the way.
And when they drew near to Jerusalem, to Bethphage and Bethany, to the mountain of the olive trees, he sends two of the disciples of himself, and says to them:
Go you into the town that opposite you; and immediately entering into her, you will find a colt having been tied, upon which no one of men has sat; having loosed him lead you.
And if any one to you should say: Why do you this? say you: That the master of him need has; and immediately him he will send here.
They went and, and found a colt having been tied near the door without in the street; and they loosen him.
And some of those there standing said to them: What do you loosing the colt?
They and said to them even as commanded the Jesus; and they suffered them.
And they led the colt to the Jesus, and they threw upon him the mantles of themselves; and he sat upon him.
Many and the mantles of themselves spread in the way; others and branches cut off from the trees, and scattered in the way.
And those going before and those following did cry, saying: Hosanna; worthy of blessing be coming in name of Lord;
worthy of blessing the coming kingdom of the father of us David; Hosanna in the highest.
And entered into Jerusalem the Jesus, and into the temple; and having looked round on all, evening now being the hour, he went out to Bethany with the twelve.
And the next day coming out of them from Bethany, he was hungry;
and seeing a fig tree at a distance, having leavens, he went, if perhaps he will find any thing on her; and coming to her, nothing he found except leaves; not for it was season of figs.
And answering he said to her: No more of thee to the age no one fruit may eat. And heard the disciples of him.

And they come to Jerusalem; and going into temple he began to cast out those selling and buying in the temple; and the tables the moneychangers, and the seats of those selling the doves he overturned;
and not suffered, that any one should carry an article through the temple.
And he taught, saying to them: Not is it written: That the house of me, a house of prayer shall be called for all the nations? you but have made it a den of robbers.
And heard the scribes and the highpriests, and they sought how him they might destroy; they feared for him, because all the crowd was amazed at the teaching of him.
And when evening it became, he went out of the city.
And in the morning passing along, they saw the figtree having been withered from roots;
And remembering the Peter, says to him: Rabbi, lo, the figtree, which thou didst curse, has been withered.
And answering the Jesus says to them: Have you faith of God.

Indeed for I say to you, that whoever may say to the mountain this: Be lifted up, and cast into the sea; and not should doubt in the heart of himself, but should believe that what he says comes to pass; it shall be to him whatever he may say.
Through this I say to you, all things whatever praying you desire, believe you that you receive, and it shall be to you.
And when you stand praying, forgive, if any thing you have against any one; that also the Father of you, that in the heavens, may forgive you the faults of you.
If but you not forgive, neither the Father of you, that in the heavens, will forgive the faults of you.
And they come again to Jerusalem. And in the temple walking of him, come to him the highpriests and the scribes and the elders,
and they say to him: By what authority these things doest thou? and who to thee the authority this gave, that these things thou mayest do?
The but Jesus answering said to them: I will ask you also I one word; and answer you to me, and I will tell to you, by what authority these things I do.
The dipping of John from heaven was or from men? answer you to me.
And they reasoned among themselves, saying: If we should say: From heaven, he will say: Why then not did you believe him?
But if we should say: From men; they feared the people; all for held the John, that really a prophet was.
And answering they say to the Jesus. Not we know. And the Jesus answering says to them: Neither I say to you, by what authority these things I do.
And he began to them in parables to talk: A vineyard planted a man, and placed around a hedge, and dug a winevat, and built a tower; and let out it to husbandmen, and went abroad.
And he sent to the husbandmen in the season a slave, that from the husbandmen, he might receive of the fruit of the vineyard.
They but taking him, they flayed, and sent away empty.
And again he sent to them another slave; and this pelting with stones they wounded of the head, and sent away having dishonored.
And another he sent; and this they killed; and many others, some indeed flaying, some but killing.
Yet therefore one son having, beloved of himself he sent and him to them last, saying: That they will regard the son of me.
Those but the husbandmen said to themselves: That this is the heir; come, we may kill him, and of us shall be the inheritance.
And having taken him, they killed, and cast out of the vineyard.
What therefore will do the lord of the vineyard? He will come and destroy the husbandmen, and will give the vineyard to others.
Not even the writing this have you read: A stone which rejected those building, this was made into a head of a corner;
by a Lord was done this, and it is wonderful in eyes of us?
And they sought him to seize, but they feared the crowd; they knew for, that to them the parable he spoke. And leaving him, they went away.
And they send to him some of the Pharisees and of the Herodians, that him they might catch in word.

They having come they say to him: O teacher, we know, that true thou art, and not cares thee about no one; not for thou lookest into face of men, but in truth the way of the God thou teachest; is it lawful tribute to Caesar to give, or not? should we give, or not should we give?
He but knowing of them the hypocrisy, said to them: Why me do you tempt? bring you to me a denarius, that I may see.
They and brought. And he says to them: Of whom the likeness this, and the inscription? They and said to him: Of Caesar.
And answering the Jesus said to them: Give you back the things of Caesar to Caesar, and the things of the God, to the God. And they wondered at him.
And come Sadducees to him, who say a resurrection not to be; and they asked him, saying:

O teacher, Moses wrote for us, that if any brother should die, and should leave behind a wife, and children not should leave, that should take the brother of him the wife of him, and should raise up seed, to the brother of himself.
Seven brothers were; and the first took a wife, and dying not left seed.
And the second took her, and died, and neither he left seed; and the third in like manner.
And took her the seven, and not left seed. Last of all died also the woman.
In the therefore resurrection when they shall rise, of whom of them shall be a wife? the for seven had her a wife.
And answering the Jesus said to them: Not through this do you err, not knowing the writings, neither the power of the God?
When for out of dead (ones) they may rise, neither they marry, nor are given in marriage, but are as messengers in the heavens.
Concerning but the dead (ones), that they rise, not have you read in the book of Moses, at the bush as said to him the God, saying: I the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob?
Not is the God of dead (ones), but of living (ones). You therefore greatly err.
And approaching one of the scribes, having heard them disputing, knowing that well to them he answered, asked him: Which is first of all commandment?
The and Jesus replied to him: That first of all commandment; Hear you Israel, a Lord, the God of us, Lord one is;

and thou shalt love a Lord the God of thee out of whole of the heart of thee, and out of whole of the soul of thee, and out of whole of the mind of thee, and out of whole of the strength of thee. This first commandment.
And second like, this: Thou shalt love the neighbor of thee as thyself. Greater of these another commandment not is.
And said to him the scribe: Well, O teacher, in truth thou speakest, that one he is and not is another besides him;

and the to love him out of whole of the heart, and out of whole of the understanding, and out of whole the soul, and out of whole of the strength, and the to love the neighbor as himself, more is of all of the whole burnt offerings and sacrifices.
And the Jesus, seeing him, that discreetly he answered, said to him: Not far thou art from the kingdom of the God. And no one no longer presumed him to ask.
And answering the Jesus said, teaching in the temple: How say the scribes, that the Anointed a son is a David?
Himself for the David said by spirit holy: Says the Lord to the lord of me: Sit thou at right of me, till I may place the enemies of thee a footstool of the feet of thee.
himself therefore David calls him lord; and whence a son is he? And the great crowd heard him gladly.
And he said to them in the teaching of himself: Beware you of the scribes, those desiring in long robes to walk about, and salutations in the markets,
and first seats in the synagogues, and upper couches at the feasts;
those devouring the houses of the widows, and for a show long are praying; these will receive heavier judgment.
And sitting the Jesus over against the treasury, he beheld how the crowd casts copper into the treasury. And many rich cast much.
And coming one widow poor, cast mites two, which is a farthing.
And having called the disciples of himself, he said to them: Indeed I say to you, that the widow this the poor more of all has cast of those casting into the treasury.
All for out of the abounding fulness to them have cast; this but out of the poverty of herself all as much as she had cast, whole the living of herself.
And departing of him out of the temple, says to him one of the disciples of him: O teacher, see, what stones and what buildings.
And the Jesus answering said to him: Seest thou these the great buildings? not not may be left a stone upon stone, which not not may be thrown down.
And sitting of him on the mountain of the olive trees, over against the temple, asked him privately Peter, and James, and John, and Andrew;
Say to us, when these things shall be, and what the sign, when are about all these things to be ended?
The and Jesus answering them began to say: Take heed not any one you may deceive.
Many for shall come in the name of me, saying: That I am; and many they will deceive.
When and ye all hear wars and reports of wars, not be disturbed; it behooves for to take place; but not yet the end.
Shall be raised up for nation against nation, and kingdom against kingdom; and shall be earthquakes in places, and shall be famines and commotions. Beginnings of sorrow these.

Take heed but you yourselves; they will deliver up for you to sanhedrims, and to synagogues you will be beaten, and before governors and kings you will stand, on account of me, for a testimony to them.
And among all the nations it behooves, first, to be published the glad tidings.

When but they may lead you deliver up, not be anxious beforehand what you should speak, nor be concerned; but whatever may be given to you in that the hour, this speak you; not for are you the speaking, but the spirit the holy.
Will deliver up and a brother a brother to death and father a child; and they shall rise up children against parents, and deliver to death them.
And you will be being hated by all through the name of me. He but persevering to end, this will be saved.
When but you may see the abomination of the desolation having stood where not it ought; (he reading let him think); then those in the Judea, let them flee to the mountains;
he and on the roof, not let him go down into the house, nor enter, to take any thing out of the house of himself;
and he in the field being, not let him turn into the back, to take the mantle of him.
Woe but to the in womb having and to the giving suck in those the days.
Pray you but, that not may be the flight of you of winter.
Shall be for the days those affliction, such as not has been go great from a beginning of creation, which created the God, till the now, and not not may be.
And if not a Lord shortened the days, not should be saved all flesh; but on account of the chosen (ones), whom he has chosen, he has shortened the days.
And then if any one to you should say: Lo, here the Anointed; or, Lo, there; not believe you.
Shall be raised for false anointed ones and false prophets, and shall give signs and wonders, to the to deceive, if possible, even the chosen.
You but take heed; lo, I have foretold to you all.
But in those the days, after the affliction that, the sun shall be darkened, and the moon not shall give the light of herself;
and the stars of the heaven shall be falling, and the powers, those in the heavens, shall be shaken.
And then they shall see the son of the man coming on clouds, with power much and glory.
And then he will send the messengers of himself, and he will gather the chosen (ones) of himself from the four winds, from an extremity of earth to an extremity of heaven.
From but the figtree learn you the parable; when of her now the branch tender may become, and may put forth the leaves, you know, that near the summer is.
So also you, when these things you may see coming to pass, know you, that near he is at doors.
Indeed I say to you, that not not may pass away the generation this, till of whom all these may be done.
The heaven and the earth shall pass away; the nut words of me not not may pass away.
Concerning but the day that or the hour no one knows, nor the messengers, those in heaven, nor the son, if not the Father.
Take heed, watch you and pray you; not you know for when the season is.
As a man going abroad leaving the house of himself, and having given to the slaves of himself the authority, and to each one the work of himself and to the porter he commanded that he should watch.
Watch you therefore; not you know for, when the lord of the house comes, evening, or midnight, or cockcrowing, or morning;
lest coming suddenly, he may find you sleeping.
What and to you I say, to all I say: Watch you.
Was now the passover and the unleavened cakes after two days; and sought the highpriests and the scribes, how him by deceit seizing they might kill.
They said but: Not in the feast, lest a tumult shall be of the people.

And being of him in Bethany in the house of Simon the leper, reclining of him, came a woman having an alabaster box of balsam, of spikenard genuine very costly; and breaking the alabaster box, she poured of it down on the head.
Were and some being angry to themselves, and saying: For what the loss this of the balsam has been made?
Could for this of the balsam to be sold more three hundred denarii, and to be given to the poor. And they censured her.
The but Jesus said: Let alone her; why to her troubles present you? good a work she has wrought in me.
Always for the poor you have with yourselves, and, when you will, you can them good to do; me but not always you have.
The having this, she has done; beforehand to anoint of me the body for the burial.
Indeed I say to you, wherever may be published the glad tidings this in whole the world, also what she did this shall be spoken, for a memorial of her.
And the Judas the Iscariot, one of the twelve, went to the highpriests, that he might deliver up him to them.
They and hearing were glad; and promised him silver to give. And he sought, how conveniently him he might deliver up.
And the first day of the unleavened cakes, when the paschal lamb was sacrificed, they say to him the disciples of him: Where wilt thou having gone we make ready, that thou mayest eat the passover?
And he sends two of the disciples of himself, and he says to them: Go you into the city; and will meet you a man a pitcher of water carrying; follow him;
and wherever he may enter, say to the householder: That the teacher says: Where is the guestchamber, where the passover with the disciples of me I may eat?
And he to you will show an upper room large having been furnished ready; there prepare you for for us.
And went forth the disciples of him, and came into the city, and found even as he said to them; and they prepared the passover.
And evening being come, he comes with the twelve.
And reclining of them and eating, said the Jesus: Indeed I say to you, that one of you will deliver up me, who is eating with me.
They and began to be sorrowful, and to say to him one by one: Not I? and another: Not I?
He but answering said to them: One of the twelve, that dipping in with me into the bowl.

The indeed son of the man goes away, even as it has been written concerning him; woe but to the man that, through whom the son of the man is delivered up; good it was to him, if not was born the man that.
And eating of them, taking the Jesus a loaf, having blessed he broke and gave to them, and said: Take; this is the body of me.
And taking the cup, having given thanks he gave to them; and they drank out of it all.
And he said to them: This is the blood of me, that of the new covenant, that concerning many being shed.
Indeed I say to you, that no more not not I will drink of the product the vine till the day that, when it I drink new in the kingdom of the God.
And having sung a hymn, they departed to the mountain of the olive trees.
And says to them the Jesus: That all will be stumbled at me in the night this; for it written: I will smite the shepherd, and will be scattered the sheep.
But after the to be raised me, I will go before you into the Galilee.
The but Peter said to him: Even if all shall be stumbled, yet not I.
And says to him the Jesus: Indeed I say to thee, that thou thisday in the night this, before twice a cock to have crowed, thrice thou wilt deny me.
He but with vehemence spoke more: If me must to die with thee, not not thee I will deny. In like manner and also all they said.
And they came to a place, of which the name Gethsemane; and he says to the disciples of himself: Sit you here, till I shall pray.
And he takes the Peter and James and John with himself; and began to be greatly amazed and to be in anguish.
And he says to them: Extremely sorrowful is the soul of me even to death; remain you here, and watch.
And going forward a little, he fell on the ground; and prayed, that, if possible it is, might pass from him the hour.
And he said: Abba the Father, all (things) possible to thee; take the cup from me this. But not, what I will, but what thou.
And he comes, and finds them sleeping; and he says to the Peter: Simon, sleepest thou? not couldst thou one hour to watch?
Watch you and pray you, that not you enter into temptation; the indeed spirit ready, the but flesh weak.
And again going away he prayed, the same word saying.
And having returned, he found them again sleeping; were for the eyes of them weighed down and not they knew, what to him they might answer.
And he comes the third, and he says to them: Do you sleep the now and rest you? it is enough, is come the hour; lo, is delivered up the son of the man into the hands of the sinners.
Arise, let us go, lo, he delivering up me has come near.
And immediately, while of him speaking, comes Judas, one being of the twelve, and with him crowd great with swords and clubs, from the highpriests and the scribes and the elders.
Had given and he delivering up him a signal to them, saying: Whoever I may kiss, he it is; seize him and lead away safely.
And coming, immediately approaching to him, he says: Rabbi, rabbi; and kissed him.
They then laid on him the hands of them, and seized him.
One and a certain of those standing, drawing the sword, struck the slave of the highpriest, and cut off of him the ear.
And answering the Jesus said to them: As upon a robber came you out with swords and clubs, to take me.
Every day I was with you in the temple teaching, and not you seized me; but that must be fulfilled the writings.
And leaving him all they fled.
And one a certain young man followed him, wrapped about a linen cloth on naked; and they seized him the young men.
He but leaving the linen cloth, naked he fled from them.
And they led the Jesus to the highpriest; and came together to him all the highpriests, and the elders, and the scribes.
And the Peter at a distance followed him even to into the place of the highpriest; and was sitting in company with the attendants, and warming himself to the light.
The and highpriests and whole the high council sought against the Jesus testimony for the to put to death him; and not they found.
Many for testified falsely against him, but consistent the testimonies not were.
And some having stood up, testified falsely against him, saying:
That we heard him saying: That I will destroy the temple this the made with hands, and in three days another made without hands I will build.
And not even thus consistent was the testimony of them.
And arising the highpriest in midst, he asked the Jesus, saying: Not answerest thou nothing? what these of thee testify against?
He but was silent and nothing he answered. Again the highpriest asked him and says to him: Thou art the Anointed, the son of the Blessed?
The and Jesus said: I am; and you shall see the son of the man at right sitting of the power, and coming with the clouds of the heaven.
The and highpriest, having rent the clothes of himself, says: What further need we have of witnesses?
You have heard the blasphemy; what to you appears? They but all condemned him to be deserving of death.
And began some to spit upon him, and to cover the face of him, and to beat with the fist him, and to say to him: Prophesy. And the attendants with open hands him beat.
And being the Peter in the courtyard below, comes one of the maidservants of the highpriest;
and seeing the Peter warming himself, she looking to him says: And thou with the Nazarene Jesus wast.
He but denied, saying: Not know, nor comprehend what thou sayest. And he went out into the outer court; and a cock crew.
And the maidservant seeing him again began to say to the having stood by: That this of them is.
He and again denied. And after a little again those having stood by said to the Peter: Truly of them thou art; also for a Galilean thou art, and the speech of thee is like.
He then began to curse and swear: That not I know the man this, of whom you say.
And of second cock crew. And remembered the Peter the word, of which said to him the Jesus: That before a cock to have crowed twice, thou wilt deny me thrice. And reflecting he wept.
And immediately on the morning a council having been held the highpriests with the elders and scribes, even whole the sanhedrim, binding the Jesus, carried and delivered up to the Pilate.
And asked him the Pilate: Thou art the king of the Jews? He and answering said to him: Thou sayest.
And accused him the highpriests many things.
The and Pilate again asked him, saying: Not answerest thou nothing? see, how many things of thee they testify against.
The but Jesus no longer nothing answered; so as to surprise the Pilate.
At now feast he used to release to them one prisoner whomever they asked.
Was and he being named Barabbas with the insurgents having been bound, who in the sedition murder had committed.
And crying out the crowd began to demand, as always he did to them.
The but Pilate answered them saying: Do you wish I shall release to you the King of the Jews?
He knew for, that through envy had delivered up him the highpriests.
The and highpriests stirred up the crowd, that rather the Barabbas he should release to them.
The but Pilate answering again said to them: What then you wish I shall do whom you call a king of the Jews?
They but again cried out: Crucify him.
The and Pilate said to them: What for evil has he done? They but vehemently cried out: Crucify him.
The then Pilate, being willing to the crowd the satisfaction to make, released to them the Barabbas, and delivered up the Jesus, having scourged, that he might be crucified.
The and soldiers led away him within the court, which is a judgment hall; and they call together whole the company.
And they clothed him purple, and placed it around him braiding an acanthine wreath.
And theybegan to salute him: Hail the king of the Jews.
And they struck of him the head with a reed, and spit upon him, and placing the knees did homage to him.
And when they mocked him, they took off him the purple, and put on him the clothes the own; and they led out him, that they might crucify him.
And they compel passing by one Simon a Cyrenian, coming from country, (the father of Alexander and Rufus), that he might bear the cross of him.
And they bring him to Golgotha place; which is being translated, of a skull a place.
And they gave him to drink having been mixed with myrrh wine; he but not received.
And crucifying him, they divide the clothes of him, casting lots on them, who what should take.
It was and hour third, and they crucified him.
And was the inscription of the accusation of him was written over: The king of the Jews.
And with him they crucify two robbers; one at right, and one at left of him.
And was fulfilled the writing that saying: And with lawlessness he was numbered.
And those passing along reviled him, shaking the heads of them, and saying: Ah, he destroying the temple, and in three days building;
save thyself, and come down from the cross.
In like manner also the highpriests, mocking to one another with the scribes, said: Others he saved, himself not is able to save?
The Anointed the king of the Israel, let him descend now from the cross, that we may see and may believe. And those having been crucified with him reproached him.
Being come and hour sixth, darkness was on whole the land, till hour ninth.
And the hour the ninth cried the Jesus with a voice loud, saying: Eloi, Eloi; lamma sabachthani? which is being translated: The God of me, the God of me; to what me hast thou left?
And some of those standing by hearing, said: Lo, Elias he calls.
Running and one, and filling a sponge of vinegar, attaching and to a reed, gave to drink him saying: Let alone; we may see, if comes Elias to take down him.
The then Jesus uttering a voice loud, breathed out.
And the curtain of the temple was rent into two, from above to below.
Seeing but the centurion, that having stood by over against him, that thus having cried he breathed out, said: Truly the man this a son was of a god.
Were and also women from a distance beholding; among whom was also Mary the Magdalene, and Mary the of the James the little and Joses mother, and Salome;
who also when he was in the Galilee, followed him, and served him; and others many, those having come up with him to Jerusalem.
And now evening being come (since it was preparation, that is before sabbath),
came Joseph that from Arimathea, of rank a senator, who also himself was expecting the kingdom of the God, assuming courage went in to Pilate, and asked for the body of the Jesus.
The and Pilate wondered, if already he was dead; and having called the centurion he asked him, if already he had died.
And knowing from the centurion, he gave the body to Joseph.
And having bought lien, and having taken down him, he wrapped the lien; and laid him in a tomb, which was having been hewn out of a rock; and rolled a stone against the door of the tomb.
The but Mary the Magdalene and Mary of Joses beheld, where he was laid.
And being past the sabbath, Mary the Magdalene, and Mary that of the James, and Salome bought aromatics, that coming they might anoint him.
And very early of the first of week they came to the tomb, having risen the sun.
And they said to themselves: Who will roll away for us the stone from the door of the tomb?
And looking up they saw, that had been rolled away the stone; it was for great very.
And having entered into the tomb, they saw a youth sitting on the right, having been clothed a robe white; and they were awestruck.
He but says to them: Not be you amazed; Jesus you seek the Nazarene, the having been crucified; he has been raised, not he is here; see the place, where they laid him.
But go, say to the disciples of him, and to the Peter, that he goes before you into the Galilee; there him you will see, as he said to you.
And having gone out, they fled from the tomb; had seized and them trembling and astonishment, and to no one nothing they said; they were afraid for.
Having risen and early first of week he appeared first to Mary the Magdalene, from whom he had cast seven demons.
She going brought back word to those with him having been, mourning and weeping.
And those having heard that he was alive and had been seen by her, they did not believe.
After but these things to two of them walking he appeared in another aspect, going into country.
And those having gone brought back word to the rest; neither to them did they give credit.
Afterwards, reclining with them to the eleven he appeared; and reproached the unbelief of them and hardness of heart, because of those having seen him having been raised not they gave credit.
And said to them: Having gone into the world all, publish the glad tidings to all the creation.
He having believed and having been dipped, shall be saved; he but not having believed, shall be condemned.
Signs and to those having believed these shall attend: In the name of me demons they shall cast out; with tongues they shall speak new;
serpents they shall take up; and if deadly thing they may drink, not not them it may hurt; upon sick ones hands they shall place, and well they will be.
The indeed then Lord, after the to have spoken to them, he was taken up into the heaven, and sat at right of the God;
those and having gone forth published everywhere, the Lord working with and the word ratifying through the accompanying signs.
Since many have undertaken to prepare a narrative about those having been fully established among us facts,
even as delivered to us those from a beginning eyewitnesses and ministers having been of the word;
it seemed right also to me, having traced from the first all accurately, in an orderly manner to thee to write, O most excellent Theophilus,
that thou mayest know concerning which thou hast been taught of words the certainly.
Was in the days of Herod, the king of the Judea, a priest certain name Zacharias, of course of Abia; and the wife of him of the daughters of Aaron, and the name of her Elisabeth.
They were and righteous both in presence of the God, walking in all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord blameless.
And not was to them a child, because the Elisabeth was barren, and both having been advanced in the days of them were.
It happen now in the to perform sacred rites him in the order of the course of him before of the God,
according to the custom of the priesthood it fell to his lot of the to burn incense, entering into the temple of the Lord;
and whole the multitude was of the people praying without to the hour of the incense burning.
Appeared and to him a messenger of a Lord, standing at right of the altar of the incense.
And was troubled Zacharias seeing, and fear fell upon him.
Said but to him the messenger: Not fear, Zacharias; because has been heard the prayer of thee, and the wife of thee Elisabeth shall bear a son to thee; and thou shalt call the name of him John.
And he shall be a joy to thee and exultation, and many at the birth of him shall be glad.
He shall be for great in sight of a Lord; and wine and strong drink not not he may drink; and a spirit of holy shall be filled yet out of womb of mother of himself.
And many of the sons of Israel shall he turn to a Lord the God of them.

And he shall precede in the sight of him in spirit and power of Elias, to turn hearts of fathers to children, and disobedient by wisdom of just (ones), to make ready for a Lord a people having been prepared.
And said Zacharias to the messenger: By what shall I know this? I for am an old man, and the wife of me far advanced in the days of herself.
And answering the messenger said to him: I am Gabriel, the having attended in presence of the God; and I am sent to speak to thee, and to tell glad tidings to thee these.

And lo, thou shalt be having been dumb, and not being able to speak, till which day may be done these; because of which not thou hast believed the words of me, which shall be fulfilled into the season of them.
And was the people waiting for the Zacharias; and wondering in the to delay him in the temple.
Coming out but not he was able to speak to them; and they perceived, that a vision he has been in the temple; and he was making signs to them, and remained dumb.
And it happened as were filled the days of the ministration of him, he went to the house of himself.
After and these the days conceived Elisabeth the wife of him; and hid herself months five, saying:
That thus to me has done the Lord in days, which he looked on to take away the reproach of me among men.
In now the month the sixth was sent the messenger Gabriel by the God to a city of the Galilee, to which a name Nazareth,
to a virgin having been betrothed to a man, to whom a name Joseph, of house of David; and the name of the virgin, Mary.
And coming the messenger to her, said: Hail, having been favored; the Lord with thee. having been blessed thou among women.
She but at the word was greatly agitated, and pondered, what could be the salutation this.
And said the messenger to her: Not fear, Mary; thou hast found for favor with the God.
And lo, thou shalt conceive in womb, and shalt bear a son, and thou shalt call the name of him Jesus.
This shall be great, and a son of highest he shall be called; and shall give to him a Lord the God the throne of David the father of him;
and he shall reign over the house of Jacob to the ages, and of the kingdom of him not shall be and end.
Said but Mary to the messenger: How shall be this, since a man not I know?
And answering the messenger said to her: A spirit holy shall come upon thee, and a power of highest shall overshadow thee; therefore and the being begotten holy, shall be called a son of God.
And lo, Elisabeth the kinswoman of thee, even she having conceived a son in old age of her; and this month sixth is to her the being called barren.
For not shall be impossible with the God every word.
Said and Mary: Lo, the handmaid of a Lord; may it be done to me according to the word of thee. And went from her the messenger.
Arising and Mary in the days those, she went into the hilly country with haste, into a city of Juda.
And entered into the house of Zacharias, and saluted the Elisabeth.
And it happened, as heard the Elisabeth the salutation of the Mary, leaped the babe in the womb of her; and was filled a spirit of holy the Elisabeth, and she cried out with a voice great and said:
Having been blessed thou among women; and having been blessed the fruit of the womb of thee.
And whence to me this, that should come the mother of the Lord of me to me?
Lo for, as came the voice of the salutation of thee into the ears of me, leaped the babe in exultation in the womb of me.
And happy she having believed, that shall be a fulfillment to those having been told to her from a Lord.
And said Mary: Magnifies the soul of me the Lord,
and has exulted the spirit of me in the God the savior of me;
for he looked upon the low state of the handmaid of himself. Lo for, from the now will call happy me all the generations;
for has done to me great things the mighty one; and holy the name of him,
and the mercy of him to generations of generations to those fearing him.
He has showed strength with arm of himself; he has dispersed arrogant ones in thought of hearts of them.
He has cast down mighty ones from thrones, and lifted up humble ones.
Hungering one he filled of good things, and being rich be sent away empty.
He aided Israel a child of himself, to remember mercy.
(as he spoke to the fathers of us), to the Abraham and to the seed of him even to an age.
Abode and Mary with her about months three; and returned to the house of her.
To the now Elisabeth was fulfilled the time of the to bear her; and she brought forth a son.
And heard the neighbors and the kindred of her, that had magnified a Lord the mercy of himself towards her; and they rejoiced with her.
And it came to pass, in the eight day they came to circumcise the little child; and called it, after the name of the father of him, Zacharias.
And answering the mother of him said: No; but he shall be called John.
And they said to her: That no one is among the kindred of thee, who is called to the name this.
They made signs then to the father of him, the what he would desire to be called him.
And having requested a tablet, he wrote, saying: John is the name of him. And they wondered all.
Was opened and the mouth of him immediately, and the tongue of him and he spoke blessing the God.
And came on all a fear those dwelling around them; and in whole the hillycountry of the Judea talked of through out all the things these.
And placed all those having heard in the heart of themselves, saying: What then the child this will be? And hand of Lord was with him.
And Zacharias the father of him was filled a spirit of holy, and prophesied, saying:
Blessed Lord, the God of the Israel; for he was visited and wrought redemption to the people of himself,
and raised up a horn of salvation to us in the house of David the servant of himself
(even as he spoke through mouth of the holy ones, of those from age, of prophets of himself);
a salvation from enemies of us, and from hand of all those hating us;
to perform mercy with the fathers of us, and to remember covenant holy of himself,
an oath, which he swore to Abraham the father of us, of the to give to us,
without fear, from hand of the enemies of us having been rescued, to worship him
in holiness and righteousness in presence of him, all the days of us.
And thou, little child, a prophet of highest shalt be called; thou shalt go for before face of a Lord, to prepare ways of him,
of the to give knowledge of salvation to the people of him, in forgiveness of sins of them,
on account of tender mercies of God of us, by which he has visited us a rising from on high
to shine to those in darkness and shade of death sitting, of the to guide the feet of us into a way of peace.
The now little child grew, and became strong in spirit; and was in the deserts, till day of manifestation of him to the Israel.
It came to pass and in the days those, went forth a decree from Caesar Augustus, to register all the habitable.
(This the registry first was made being governor of the Syria Cyrenius.)
And they went all to be registered, each into the his own city.
Went up and also Joseph from the Galilee, out of city Nazareth, into the Judea, into a city of David, which is called Bethleem, (because the to be him of house and family of David,)
to be registered with Mary the having been espoused to him a wife, being with child.
It happened but in the to be them there, were fulfilled the days of the to bear her.
And she brought forth the son of her the firstborn, and swathed him, and laid him in the manger; because not was to them a place in the guestchamber.
And shepherds were in the country the this abiding in the fields, and keeping watches of the night over the flock of them.
And lo, a messenger of a Lord stood near to them, and glory of a Lord shone round them; and they feared a fear great.
And said to them the messenger: Not fear you; lo for, I bring glad tidings to you a joy great, which shall be to all the people;
that was born to you today a savior, who is Anointed, Lord, in a city of David.
And this to you the sign: You shall find a babe having been swathed lying in a manger.
And suddenly was with the messenger a multitude of host of heaven, praising the God, and saying:
Glory in highest heavens to God, and on earth peace; among men good will.

And it came to pass, when went from them into the heaven the messengers, and the men, the shepherds, said to one another: We should go now to Bethleem, and see the thing this the having been done, which the Lord has made known to us.
And they came having made haste, and they found the both Mary and the Joseph, and the babe lying in the manger.
Having seen and, they published around the declaration that having been told to them concerning the little child this.
And all those having heard wondered about those having been told by the shepherds to them.
The but Mary all kept the words these, pondering in the heart of herself.
And returned the shepherds glorifying and praising the God for all which they had heard and seen, even it had been told to them.
And when were fulfilled days eight of the to circumcise him, and he was called the name of him Jesus, that being called by the messenger before of the was conceived him in the womb.
And when were fulfilled the days of the purification of them, according to the law of Moses, they brought him to Jerusalem, to present to the Lord,
(as it is written in law of Lord: That every male opening a womb, holy to the Lord shall be called);
and of the offer a sacrifice, according to that having been said in law of Lord: A pair of turtle doves, or two young pigeons.
And lo, was a man in Jerusalem, to whom a name of Simeon; and the man this just and pious, waiting for consolation of the Israel. And a spirit was holy upon him,
and it was to him having been informed by the spirit of the holy, not to see death, before he should see the Anointed of Lord.
And he came by the spirit into the temple; and in the to bring the parents the little child Jesus, of the to do them according to that having been instituted of the law concerning him;
also he took it into the arms of himself, and blessed the God, and said:
Now dost thou dismiss the servant of thee, O Sovereign, according to the word of thee, in peace;
for have seen the eyes of me the salvation of thee,
which thou hast prepared before face of all the people;
a light for a revelation of nations, and a glory of people of thee Israel.
And was the father of him and the mother wondering at those being spoken about him.
And blessed them Simeon, and said to Mary the mother of him: Lo, this is placed for a fall and rising of many in the Israel, and for a sign being spoken against;
(also of thee and of thyself the soul shall pierce through a sword); so that may be disclosed of many hearts reasonings.
And was Anna a prophetess, a daughter of Phanuel, of tribe of Aser; she having been advanced in days many, having lived years with a husband seven from the virginity of herself;
also she a widow about years eightyfour, who not withdrew from the temple, fastings and prayers serving night and day.
And she, this the hour standing by, acknowledged the Lord, and spoke about him to all those looking for redemption in Jerusalem.
And when they finished all the things according to the law of Lord, they returned into the Galilee, into the city of themselves, Nazareth.
The and little child grew, and was strengthened in spirit being filled with wisdom; and favor of God was on it.
And went the parents of him every year to Jerusalem of the feast of the passover.
And when he was years twelve, having gone up of them to Jerusalem according to the custom of the feast;
and having ended the days, in the to return them, remained Jesus the boy in Jerusalem; and not knew Joseph and the mother of him.
Having supposed and him in the company to be, they went of a day a journey, and they sought him among the kinsmen and the acquaintances.
And not finding, they returned to Jerusalem, seeking him.
And it happened, after days three they found him in the temple sitting in middle of the teachers, and hearing of them, and asking them.
Were amazed and all those hearing him, upon the understanding and the answers of him.
And seeing him, they were amazed; and to him the mother of him said: O child, why hast thou done to us thus? lo, the father of thee and I being in distress have sought thee.
And he said to them: Why for did you seek me? not know you, that in the of the father of me must to be me?
And they not understood the word, which he spoke to them.
And he went down with them, and came into Nazareth; and was being subject to them. And the mother of him treasured all the words these in the heart of herself.
And Jesus advanced in wisdom, and in vigor, and in favor with God and men.

In year now fifteenth of the government of Tiberius Caesar, being governor Pontius Pilate of the Judea, and being tetrarch of the Galilee Herod, Philip and the brother of him being tetrarch of the Ituria and Trachonitis region, and Lysanias of the Abilene being tetrarch,
under highpriests Annas and Caiaphas, came a word of God to John, the of Zacharias son, in the desert.
And he went into all the country about the Jordan, preaching a dipping of reformation into a forgiveness of sins;
as it is written in a book of words of Esaias the prophet, saying: A voice crying in the desert; Make you ready the way of a Lord, straight make you the beaten tracks of him.
Every ravine shall be filled up, and every mountain and hill shall be made low; and shall be the crooked into straight; and the rough into ways smooth;
and shall see all flesh the salvation of the God.
He said then to those coming out of crowds to be dipped by him: O broods of venomous serpents, who pointed out to you to flee from the coming wrath?

Bring forth then fruits worthy of the reformation; and not you should begin to say in yourselves: A father we have the Abraham. I say for to you, that is able the God out of the stones of these to rise up children to the Abraham.
Now and even the axe to the root of the trees is placed; every therefore tree not bearing fruit good, is cut down, and into the fire is cast.
And asked him the crowds, saying: What then should we do?
Answering and he says to them: He having two tunics, let him share with the not having; and he having meats, in like manner let him do.
Came and also taxgathers to be dipped, and said to him: O teacher, what should we do?
He said to them: Nothing more from that having been appointed to you collect you.
Asked and him also soldiers, saying: And we what should we do? And he said to them: No one may you extort from, neither may you accuse wrongfully; and be you content with the wages of you.
Expecting and of the people, and reasoning all in the hearts of them about the John, whether he were the Anointed,
answered the John to all saying: I indeed in water dip you; comes but the mightier of me, of whom not I am worthy to loose the strap of the sandals of him; he you will dip in spirit holy and fire.

Of whom the winnowing shovel in the hand of him, and he will thoroughly cleanse the floor of him; and he will gather the wheat into the storehouse of himself, the but chaff he will burn up in fire inextinguishable.
Many indeed then also other things exhorting he preached glad tidings the people.
The but Herod the tetrarch, being reproved by him about Herodias of the wife of the brother of him, and about all of which had done evils the Herod,
added also this to all, and shut up the John in the prison.
It occurred and in the to have been dipped all the people, and Jesus having been dipped and praying, to have been opened the heaven,
and to descend the spirit the holy in a bodily form, like a dove, upon him, and a voice out of heaven to have come saying Thou art the son of me the beloved in thee I delight.
And he was the Jesus about years thirty, beginning, being, as was allowed, a son of Joseph, of the Heli,
of the Matthat, of the Levi, of the Melchi, of the Janna, of the Joseph,
of the Mattathias, of the Amos, of the Naoum, of the Esli, of the Naggai,
of the Maath, of the Mattathias, of the Semei, of the Joseph, of the Juda,
of the Joanna, of the Rhesa, of the Zorobabel, of the Salathiel, of the Neri,
of the Melchi, of the Addi, of the Cosam, of the Elmodam, of the Er,
of the Jose, of the Eliezer, of the Jorem, of the Matthat, of the Levi,
of the Simon, of the Juda, of the Joseph, of the Jonan, of the Eliakim,
of the Melea, of the Mainan, of the Mattatha, of the Nathan, of the David,
of the Jesse, of the Obed, of the Booz, of the Salmon, of the Naasson,
of the Aminadab, of the Aram, of the Esrom, of the Phares, of the Juda,
of the Jacob, of the Isaac, of the Abraham, of the Thara, of the Nachor,
of the Serouch, of the Ragau, of the Phalec, of the Eber, of the Sala,
of the Cainan, of the Arphaxad, of the Sem, of the Noah, of the Lamech,
of the Mathusala, of the Enoch, of the Jared, of the Malaleel, of the Cainan,
of the Enos, of the Seth, of the Adam, of the God.
Jesus and spirit of holy full returned from the Jordan; and was led about by the spirit into the desert,
days forty being tempted by the accuser. And not he ate nothing in the days those; and being ended of them, afterwards he was hungry.
And said to him the accuser: If a son thou art of the God, say to the stone this, that it may become a loaf.
And answered Jesus to him, saying: It is written: That not on bread alone shall live the man, but on every word of God.
And having led up him the accuser into mountain high, he showed to him all the kingdom of the habitable in a moment of time.
And said to him the accuser: To thee I will give the authority this all, and the glory of them; that to me it has been prepared, and to whoever I will, I give her;
thou then if thou wilt do homage before me, shall be to thee all.
And answering to him said the Jesus: It is written: Thou shalt worship a Lord the God of thee, and to him alone thou shalt render service.
And he brought him to Jerusalem, and placed him on the wing of the temple; and said to him: If a son thou art of the God, cast thyself from this place down.
It is written for: That to the messengers of himself he will give charge concerning thee, of the to guard thee;
and that on hands they shall bear thee, lest thou shouldst strike against a stone the foot of thee.
And answering said to him the Jesus: That it is said: Not thou shalt tempt a Lord the God of thee.
And having ended every temptation the accuser, departed from him for a season.
And returned the Jesus in the power of the spirit into the Galilee; and a report went out through whole the surrounding region about him.
And he taught in the synagogues of them, being glorified by all.
And he came into the Nazareth, where he was having been brought up; and entered, according to the custom to him in the day of the sabbaths, into the synagogue; and stood up to read.
And was delivered to him a roll of Esaias the prophet; and having unrolled the roll, he found the place, where it was having been written:

A spirit of a Lord upon me; of which on account of he has anointed me to publish glad tidings to poor ones, he has sent me to publish to captives a deliverance, and to build ones recovery of sight, to sent away those having been crushed in freedom,
to publish a year of a Lord acceptable.
And having rolled up the roll, having given back to the attendant, he sat down; and of all in the synagogue the eyes were looking steadily to him.
He began and to say to them: That today is fulfilled that writing this in to the ears of you.
And all bore testimony to him, and wondered at the words of the graciousness, those proceeding out of the mouth of him, and said: Not this is the son of Joseph?
And he said to them: Surely you will say to me the illustration this: Physician, heal thyself; what things we have heard having been done in Capernaum, do thou also here in the country of thee.
He said and: Indeed I say to you, that no one a prophet acceptable is in the country of himself.
In truth but I say to you, many widows were in the days of Elias in the Israel, when was shut up the heaven for years three and months six, so that came a famine great over all the land;
and to no one of them was sent Elias, if not into Sarepta of the Sidon to a woman a widow.
And many lepers were in of Elisha the prophet in the Israel; and no one of them were cleansed, if not Naaman the Syrian.
And they were filled all of wrath in the synagogue, having heard these things.
And rising up they cast out him outside of the city; and they led him even to a brow of the mountain, on which the city of them was built, so as to cast down him;
he but passing through midst of them, went away.
And he came down into Capernaum, a city of the Galilee; and he was teaching them in the sabbaths.
And they were astonished on the teaching of him; for with authority was the word of him.
And in the synagogue was a man having a spirit of a demon unclean, and he cried out with a voice loud,
saying: Ah, what to us and to thee, Jesus O Nazarene? comest thou to destroy us; I know thee who thou art, the holy of the God.
And rebuked him the Jesus, saying: Be silent, and come out out of him. And having thrown him the demon into midst, came out of him, nothing hurting him.
And came amazement on all; and talked to one another, saying: What the word this, for with authority and power he commands the unclean spirits, and they come out?
And went forth a report concerning him into every place of the country around.
Having risen up and out of the synagogue, he entered into the house of Simon; motherinlaw and of the Simon was seized with fever great; and they asked him about her.
And standing above her, he rebuked the fever; and it left her. Forthwith and rising up she served them.
Setting and of the sun, all as many as had being afflicted with disease various, brought them to him; he and one by one separately of them the hands having placed, he healed them.
Came out and also demons from many, crying out and saying: That thou art the son of the God. And rebuking not he permitted them to say, that they knew the Anointed him to be.
Being come and day, coming out he went into a desert place; and the crowds sought him, and came to him, and urged him not to depart from them.
He but said to them: That also to the other cities to publish glad tidings me must the kingdom of the God; because for this I have been sent forth.
And he was preaching in the synagogue of Galilee.
It happened but in to the the crowd to press him of the to hear the word of the God, and he was standing by the lake Gennesaret;
and he saw two ships standing by the lake; the but fisherman having gone from them, were washing the nets.
Entering and into one of the ships, which was of the Simon; he asked him from the land to put off a little; and sitting down he taught out of the ship the crowds.
When and he ceased speaking, he said to the Simon: Put out into the deep, and let down the nets of you for a draught.
And answering the Simon said to him: O master, through whole of the night having toiled, nothing we have taken; at but the word of thee I will let down the net.
And this having done, they enclosed a multitude of fishes great; was rending and the net of them.
And they beckoned to the partners of those in the other ship, of the coming to help them; and they came, and filled both the ships, so as to sink them.
Seeing and Simon Peter, fell down to the knees to the Jesus, saying: Depart from me, for a man a sinner I am, O lord.
Amazement for seized him and all those with him, at the draught of the fishes, which they had taken.
In like manner and also James and John, sons of Zebedee, who were partners with the Simon. And said to the Simon the Jesus: Not fear; from of the now men thou will be catching.
And having brought the ships to the land, having left all, they followed him.

And it happened in to the to be him in one of the cities, and lo, a man full of leprosy; and seeing the Jesus, having fallen on face, entreated him saying: O lord, if thou wilt, thou art able me to cleanse.
And stretching out the hand, he touched him, saying: I will, be thou cleansed. And immediately the leprosy departed from him.
And he commanded him no one to tell: but going show thyself to the priest, and offer on account of the cleansing of thee, as enjoined Moses, for a witness to them.
Spread abroad but more the word concerning him; and came together crowds great to hear, and to be healed by him from the weakness of them;
He but was retiring in the deserts, and praying.

And it happened in one of the days, and he was teaching; and were sitting Pharisees and teachers of the law, they were having come out of all villages of the Galilee and Judea, and Jerusalem; and power of Lord was into the to heal them.
And lo, men bringing on a couch a man, who was having been palsied; and sought him to bring in, and to place in presence of him.
And not finding how they might bring in him, through the crowd, having gone up to the roof, through the tiles they let down him with the little bed into the midst in presence of the Jesus.
And seeing the faith of them, he said: O man, have been forgiven to thee the sins of thee.
And began to reason the scribes and the Pharisees, saying: Who is this who speaks blasphemies? who is able to forgive sins, if not alone the God?
Knowing but the Jesus the reasonings of them, answering said to them: Why do you reason in the hearts of you?
Which is easier to say: Have been forgiven to thee the sins of thee? or to to say: Arise and walk?

That but you may know, that authority has the son of the man on the earth to forgive sins, (he said to the having been palsied:) To thee I say: Arise, and having taken up the little bed of thee, go into the house of thee.
And instantly arising in presence of them, having taken up on which he had been laid, went into the house of himself, glorifying the God.
And amazement too all, and they glorified the God; and were filled of fear; saying: That we have seen wonderful things today.
And after these he went out, and saw publican with a name Levi, sitting at the customhouse; and he said to him: Follow me.
And forsaking all rising up he followed him.
And made a feast great Levi to him in the house of himself; and was a crowd of publicans great, and of others, who were with them reclining.
And murmured the scribes of them and the Pharisees to the disciples of him, saying: Why with the publicans and sinners do you eat and drink?
And answering the Jesus said to them: No need have those being in health of a physician, but those sick being;
not I have come to call just (ones), but sinners to reformation.
They and said to him: Why the disciples of John fast often, and prayers make, in like manner and those of the Pharisees; those but to thee eat and drink?
He said to them: Not you are able the sons of the bridalchamber, in which the bridegroom with them is, to make to fast?
Will come but days, and when may be taken from them the bridegroom, then they will fast in those the days.
He spoke and also a parable to them: That no one a patch of a mantle new sews to a mantle old; if nut not, and the new it rends and the old not agrees a patch that from the new.
And no one puts wine new into skins old; if but not, will burst the new wine the skins, and he will be split, and the skins will be destroyed;
but wine new into skins new requires to be put; and both are preserved.
And no one having drink old, immediately desires new; he says for: The old better is.
It happened and in sabbath secondfirst to pass him through the grainfields; and plucked the disciples of him the ears of grain, and ate, rubbing the hands.
Some and of the Pharisees said to them: Why do you, which not it is lawful to do in the sabbath?
And answering to them said the Jesus: Not even this have you read, what did David, when he was hungry he and those with him being?
how he entered into the house of the God, and the loaves of the presence he took, and ate, and gave also to those with him; which not it is lawful to eat, if not alone the priests?
And he said to them: That a lord is the son of the man also of the sabbath.
It happened and also in another sabbath to enter him into the synagogue, and to teach; and was there a man, and the hand of him the right was withered.
Watched and him the scribes and the Pharisees if in the sabbath he will heal, so that they might find an accusation of him.
He but knew the purposes of them, and said to the man the withered having the hand: Arise and stand into the midst. He and having arisen stood.
Said then the Jesus to them: I will ask you: What is it lawful to the sabbath? to do good or to do evil? a life to save, or to kill?
And looking around on all them, he said to him: Stretch out the hand of thee. He and did; and was restored the hand of him as the other.
They and were filled madness, and they talked to one another, what they should do to the Jesus.
It came to pass and in the days those, he went out into the mountain to pray; and was passing the night in the place of prayer of the God.
And when it came day, he called to the disciples of himself; and having chosen from them twelve, whom also apostles he named;
(Simon, whom also he named Peter, and Andrew the brother of him, James and John, Philip and Bartholomew,
Matthew and Thomas, James the of the Alpheus, and Simon the being called Zelotes,
