And they asked him, saying: O teacher, we know, that rightly thou speakest and thou teachest, and not thou dost accept a countenance, but in truth the way of the God thou teachest.
Is it lawful for us to Caesar tax to give, or not?
Perceiving but to them the craftiness, he said to them: Why me tempt you?
Show you to me a denarius; of whom has it a likeness and inscription? Answering and they said: Of Caesar.
He and said to them: Give you back then the things of Caesar, to Caesar; and the things of the God, to the God.
And not they were able to take hold of him of a word in presence of the people; and wondering at the answer of him, they were silent.
Approaching and some of the Sadducees, those denying a resurrection not to be, asked him,

saying: O teacher, Moses wrote for us, If any one a brother should die having a wife, and this childless should die, that should take the brother of him the wife, and should raise up seed to the brother of himself.
Seven now brothers were; and the first having taken a wife, died childless.
And took the second the wife, and this died childless.
And the third took her; in like manner and also the seven; not they left children, and died.
Last and of all died also the woman.
In the therefore resurrection, of which of them will be a wife? the for seven had her a wife.
And answering he said to them the Jesus: The sons of the age this marry and are given marriage;
those but having been accounted worthy of the age that to obtain, and of the resurrection that out of dead ones, neither marry, nor are given in marriage;
nor for to die more are able; like angels for they are, and sons they are of the God, of the resurrection sons being.
That but rise the dead ones, even Moses declared at the bush, when he calls a Lord, the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.
A God now not he is of dead ones, but of living ones; all for to him live.
Answering and some of the scribes said: O teacher, well thou hast spoken.
No longer and they presumed to ask him nothing.
He said and to them: How say they the Anointed a son of David to be?
And yet himself David says in a book of psalms: Said the Lord to the lord of me:
Sit thou at right hand of me till I may place the enemies of thee a footstool of the feet of thee.
David therefore a lord him calls, and how a son of him is he?
Hearing and all of the people, he said to the disciples of himself:
Beware of the scribes, those wishing to walk in robes, and loving salutations in the markets, and first seats in the synagogues, and first places in the feasts;
they devour the houses of the widows, and for a show long they pray; the so will receive greater judgment.
Looking and he saw those casting the gifts of them into the treasury rich ones.
He saw and also a certain widow poor casting there two lepta;
and he said: Truly I say to you, that the widow that poor this more of all has cast.
All for they out of the abundance of them cast into the gifts of the God; she but out of the want of herself all the living, which she had, she cast.
And some speaking about the temple that with stones beautiful and offerings it was adorned, he said:
These which you behold, will come days in which not will be left a stone upon a stone, which not will be thrown down.
They asked and him, saying: O teacher, when then these will be? and what the sign, when may be about these to be done?
He but said: Look you, not you may be deceived. Many for will come in the name of me, saying: That I am, and the season has approached. Not therefore go you after them.
When and you may hear of wars and commotions, not you may be terrified, must for these come to pass first; but not immediately the end.
Then he said to them: Will rise a nation on a nation, and a kingdom on a kingdom;
earthquakes and great in many places, and famines, and pestilences will be; fearful sights also and signs from heaven great will be.
Before but this all they will lay on you the hands of them, and they will persecute, delivering up to synagogues and prisons, dragging to kings and governors, on account of the name of me.
It will turn out and to you for a testimony.
Settle therefore in the hearts of you, not to premeditate to make a defence.
I for will give to you a mouth and wisdom, which not will be able to gainsay or resist all the opponents to you.
You will be delivered up and also by parents, and brothers, and relatives, and friends; and they will put to death of you.
And you will be being hated by all through the name of me.
And a hair from the head of you not not will perish.
In the patient endurance of you preserve you the lives of you.
When and you may see surrounded by encampments the Jerusalem, then you may know, that has come near the desolation of her.
Then those in the Judea, let them flee to the mountains; and those in midst of her, let them go out; and those in the country places, not let them enter into her.
For days of vengeance these are, of the to be fulfilled all the things having been written.
Woe but to the in womb holding and to the giving suck in those the days; will be for distress great upon the land, and wrath to the people this;
and they will fall by edge of a sword, and they will be led captive into all the nations; and Jerusalem will be trodden down by Gentiles, till may be fulfilled seasons of Gentiles.
And will be signs in sun and moon and stars; and on the earth anguish of nations in perplexity of a roar of sea and of tossing;
fainting men from fear and expectation of the things coming on the habitable; the for powers of the heavens will be shaken.
And then they will see the son of the man coming in a cloud, with power and glory great.
Beginning and of these to occur, raise yourselves and lift up the heads of you; because draws near the deliverance of you.
And he spoke a parable to them: See you the figtree and all the trees;
when they shoot forth now, beholding, from of yourselves you know, that now near the summer is.
So also you, when you may see these occurring, know you, that near is the kingdom of the God.
Indeed I say to you, that not not may pass away the generation this, till all may be done.
The heaven and the earth shall pass away; the but words of me not not may pass away.
Take heed but to yourselves, lest should be burdened of you the hearts with surfeiting, and drunkenness, and anxieties of life; and suddenly on you may come the day that.
As a snare for it will come on all those dwelling on face of all of the earth.
Watch you then in every season, praying, that you may be accounted worthy to escape these all the things being about to occur, and to stand in presence of the son of the man.
He was and the days in the temple teaching; the and nights going out he lodged in the mountain that being called of olive trees.
And all the people came early to him in the temple to hear him.
Drew near now the feast of the unleavened cakes, that being called passover;
and sought the highpriests and the scribes, the how they might kill him; they feared for the people.
Entered and adversary into Judas that being surnamed Iscariot, being of the number of the twelve.
And going he talked with the highpriests and the officers, the how him he might deliver up to them.
And they were glad; and agreed to him silver to give.
And he consented; and he sought opportunity of the to deliver up him to them without of a crowd.
Came and the day of the unleavened cakes, in which it is necessary to sacrifice the paschal lamb;
and he sent Peter and John, saying: Going prepare you for us the passover, that we may eat.
They and said to him: Where wilt thou we make ready?

He and said to them: Lo, having entered of you into the city, will meet you a man a pitcher of water carrying; follow you him into the house, where he enters; and say you to the householder of the house:
Says to thee the teacher: Where is the greatchamber, where the passover with the disciples of me I may eat?
And he to you will show an upper room large having been furnished; there prepare you.
Having gone and they found even as he had said to them; and they prepared the passover.
And when came the hour, he reclined, and the twelve apostles with him.
And he said to them: With desire I have desired this the passover to eat with you, before the me to suffer.
I say for to you, that no more not not I may eat it, till it may be fulfilled in the kingdom of the God.
And having taken a cup, having given thanks he said: Take you this, and divide you among yourselves.
I say for to you, that not not I may drink of the product of the vine, till the kingdom of the God may come.
And having taken a loaf, having given thanks he broke, and gave to them, saying: This is the body of me, that in behalf of you being given; this do you in the my remembrance.
In like manner also the cup, after the supper, saying: This the cup, the new covenant in the blood of me, that in behalf of you being poured out.
But lo, the hand of the delivering up me with mine on the table.
And the indeed son of the man goes away according to that having been appointed; but woe to the man that, through whom he is delivered up.
And they began to inquire among themselves, the, which then it could be of them the this being about to do.
There had been and also a strife among them, the, which of them thinks to be greater.
He but said to them: The kings of the nations exercise lordship over them; and those having authority of them; benefactors are called.
You but not so; but the greater among you, let him become as the younger; and the governor, as he serving.
Which for greater? he reclining, or he serving? not he reclining? I but am in the midst of you as he serving.
You but are those having continued with me in the trials of me.
And I covenant for you, even as has covenanted for me the Father of me a kingdom,
that you may eat and you may drink at the table of me in the kingdom of me; and you may sit on thrones, judging the twelve tribes of the Israel.
Said and the Lord: Simon, Simon, lo, the adversary has asked for you, the to sift as the wheat.
I but prayed for thee, that not may fail the faith of thee. And thou when having been turned, strengthen the brethren of thee.
He and said to him: O lord, with thee ready I am both to prison and to death to go.
He but said: I say to thee, O Peter, not not will crow today a cock, before thrice thou wilt deny not to have known me.
And he said to them: When I sent you without a purse, and a bag, and sandals, not anything wanted you? They and said; Nothing.
He said then to them: But now, he having a purse, let him take, in like manner and a bag; and he not having, let him sell the mantle of himself, and let him buy a sword.
I say for to you, that yet this the having been written must to be finished in me, that: And with lawbreakers he was counted. Also for the things about me an end has.
They but said: O lord, lo, swords here two. He and said to them: Enough it is.
And going out he went according to the custom to the mountain of the olivetrees; followed and him also the disciples of him.
Having come and to the place, he said to them: Pray you not to enter into temptation.
And he was withdrawn from them about of a stone throw, and having placed the knees he prayed, saying:
O Father if thou art willing to take away the cup this from me; but not the will of me, but the thine be done.
Appeared and to him a messenger from heaven, strengthening him.
And being in agony, very earnestly he prayed. Was and the sweat of him like clots of blood falling down to the ground.
And having stood up from the prayer, coming to the disciples, he found them sleeping from the grief; and he said to them:
Why sleep you? having stood up pray you, that not you may enter into temptation.
While and of him speaking, lo, a crowd, and he being called Judas, one of the twelve, went before them, and drew near to the Jesus to kiss him.
The but Jesus said to him: Judas, with a kiss the son of the man betrayest thou?
Seeing and those about him the was going to be, said to him: O lord, if shall we strike with a sword?
And struck one a certain of them the slave of the highpriest, and cut off of him the ear the right.
Answering and the Jesus said: Let you be till this. And touching the ear of him, he healed him.
Said and the Jesus to those having come on him highpriests, and offices of the temple, and elders: As on a robber you have come out with swords and clubs;
every day being of me with you in the temple, not you did stretch out the hands on me; but this of you it is the hour, and the authority of the darkness.
Having seized and him they led, and brought him into the house of the highpriest. The but Peter followed at a distance.
Having kindled and a fire in midst of the court, and having sat down of them, sat the Peter in midst of them.
Seeing and him a maidservant certain sitting by the light, and looking steadily to him, she said: Also this with him was.
He but denied him, saying: O woman, not I know him.
And after a little another seeing him, said: Also thou of them art. The but Peter said: O man, not I am.
And having intervened about hour one, another person confidently affirmed, saying: In truth also this with him was also for a Galilean he is.
Said but the Peter: O man, not I know what thou sayest. And immediately, while speaking of him, crew a cock.
And having turned the Lord looked to the Peter; and was reminded the Peter of the word of the Lord, as he said to him: That before a cock to crow, thou mayest deny me thrice.
And going out, he wept bitterly.
And the men those having in custody the Jesus, mocked him, scourging;
and having blindfolded him, they struck of him the face, and they asked him, saying: Prophesy, who is he striking thee?
And other many blaspheming they spoke against him.
And as it became day, were assembled the eldership of the people, highpriests and and scribes, and brought him into the sanhedrim of themselves,
saying: If thou art the Anointed, tell us. He said and to them: If to you I tell, not not you will believe;
if but also I ask, not not you would answer me, or would loose.
From of the now shall be the son of the man sitting at right hand of the power of the God.
Said and all: Thou then art the son of the God? He and to them said: You say; that I am.
They and said: What further need have we of testimony? Ourselves for we have heard from the mouth of him.
And having stood up whole the multitude of them, they led him to the Pilate.
They began and to accuse him, saying: This we found misleading the nation, and forbidding to Caesar tax to give, saying himself an Anointed king to be.
The and Pilate asked him, saying: Thou art the king of the Jews? He and answering to him said: Thou sayest.
The and Pilate said to the highpriests and the crowds: Nothing I find criminal in the man this.
They but were urgent, saying: That he stirs up the people, teaching in whole of the Judea, having begin from the Galilee to here.
Pilate and having heard of Galilee, he asked: If the man a Galilean is.
And having learned, that of the authority of Herod he is, he sent him to Herod, being also him in Jerusalem in those the days.
The and Herod seeing the Jesus, rejoiced greatly; he was for wishing of a long time to see him, because the to hear many things about him; and hoped some sign to see by him being done.
He asked and him in words many; he and nothing answered him.
Stood up and the highpriests and the scribes, vehemently accusing him.
Having despised and him the Herod with the soldiers of himself, and having mocked, casting around him a robe splendid, sent again him to the Pilate.
Became and friends the, both Pilate and the Herod in this the day with each other; formerly for in hatred being with themselves.
Pilate and having summoned the highpriests and the chiefs and the people,
said to them: You have brought to me the man this, as misleading the people; and lo, I in presence of you having examined, nothing I found in the man this a fault, of which you accuse against him.
But not even Herod; I sent for you to him, and lo, nothing worthy of death is having been done to him.
Having scourged therefore him I will release.
Necessary now it was to release to them at a feast one.
Cried out and all together, saying: Take away this, release and to us the Barabbas.
Who was through a sedition certain having occurred in the city, and a murder, having been cast into prison.
Again therefore the Pilate spoke to, wishing to release the Jesus.
They but cried, saying: Crucify, crucify, him.
He and third said to them: What for evil has done this? nothing a cause of death I found in him; having scourged therefore him I will release.
They but pressed with voices loud, demanding him to be crucified; and prevailed the voices of them and of the highpriests.
The and Pilate decided to satisfy the request of them.
He released and the through sedition and murder having been cast into the prison, whom they asked; the but Jesus he delivered to the will of them
And as they led him, having laid hold of Simon a certain Cyrenian coming from country, they placed to him the cross, to carry after the Jesus.
Followed and him a great multitude of the people, and of women; who also lamented and bewailed him.
Turning but to them the Jesus said: Daughters of Jerusalem, not weep you for me, but for yourselves weep you, and for the children of you.
For lo, come days, in which they will say: Blessed the barren ones, and wombs which not bore, and breasts which not suckled.
Then they will begin to say to the mountain: Fall you on us; and to the hills: Cover you us.
For if in the green tree these they do, in the dry what will be done?
Were led and also others two malefactors with him to be put to death.
And when they came to the place, that being called Skull, there they crucified him, and the malefactors; one indeed at right, one at left.
The and Jesus said: O Father, forgive them; not for they know what they do. Having divided and the garments of him, they cast a lot.
And stood the people gazing; scoffed at and also the rulers with them, saying: Others he saved, let him save himself, if this is the Anointed, the of the God chosen.
Mocked and him also the soldiers, coming near and vinegar offering to him,
and saying: If thou art the king of the Jews, save thyself.
Was and also an inscription having been written over him letters in Greek, and Latin, and Hebrew: This is the king of the Jews.
One and of those having been hanged malefactors spoke against him, saying: If thou art the Anointed, save thyself and us.
Answering but the other rebuked him saying: Not even fearest thou the God, since in the same condemnation thou art?
And we indeed justly; due for which has been done we receive; this but nothing amiss has done.
And he said to the Jesus: Do thou remember me, O lord, when thou mayest come in the kingdom of thee.
And said to him the Jesus: Indeed I say to thee today, with me thou shalt be in the Paradise.
It was and about hour sixth, and darkness came over whole the land, till hour ninth.
And was darkened the sun; and was rent the veil of the temple midst.
And crying with a voice loud the Jesus, said: O Father, into hands of thee I commit the breath of me. And these having said, he breathed out.
Seeing and the centurion that having occurred, glorified the God, saying: Truly the man this just was.
And all the having come together crowds to the sight this, beholding the things having occurred, striking of themselves the breasts returned.
Stood but all the acquaintance of him at a distance, and women those having followed him from the Galilee, beholding these things.
And lo, a man with a name Joseph, a counsellor being, a man good and just,
(this not was having assented to the will and the act of the,) from Arimathea a city of the Jews, who and was looking for also himself the kingdom of the God;
this having gone to the Pilate, asked the body of the Jesus.
And having taken down it, he wrapped it in linen, and laid it, in a tomb hewn in a rock, where not was ever yet no one being laid.
And day was preparation, and sabbath approached.
Having followed after and also women, who were having been with him out of the Galilee, beheld the tomb, and now they laid the body of him.
Having returned and they prepared aromatics and ointments; and the indeed sabbath they rested according to the commandment.
In the and first of the weeks, of morning very early, came to the tomb, bringing what they prepared aromatics; and some with them.
They found and the stone having been rolled from the tomb.
And having entered not they found the body of the Lord Jesus.
And it happened in the to be perplexed them about this, and lo, men two stood by them in clothing shining.
Afraid and having become of them, and bowing the face to the earth, they said to them: Why seek you the living among the deadones?
Not he is here, but has been raised. Remember you how he spoke to you, while being in the Galilee,
saying: That it behooves the son of the man to be delivered into hands of men of sinners, and to be crucified, and the third day to stand up.
And they remembered the words of him;
and having returned from the tomb, they related these all to the eleven and to all the others.
Were and the Magdalene Mary, and Joanna, and Mary of James, and the others with them, who spoke to the apostles these.
And appeared in presence of them as an idle tale the words of them, and they believed not them.
The and Peter arising ran to the tomb, and having stooped down he sees the linen bands lying alone; and he departed by himself, wondering that having occurred.
And lo, two of them were going in this the day into a village being distant furlongs sixty from Jerusalem, to which a name Emmaus.
And they were talking to each other about all of the having happened of these.
And it occurred in the to talk them and to reason, even he the Jesus having come near went with them.
The but eyes of them were held, the not to know him.
He said and to them: What the words these, which you throw to one another walking, and are sad?
Answering and the one, to whom a name Cleopas, said to him: Thou alone sojournest Jerusalem, and not thou knowest the things having been done in her in the days these?
And he said to them: What things? They and said to him: The things about Jesus the Nazarene, who was a man a prophet, powerful in work and word in presence of the God and all the people.
How and delivered up him the highpriests and the chiefs of us to a sentence of death, and crucified him.
We but hoped, that he it is the being about to redeem the Israel; but besides all these third this day goes away today, from of which these occurred;
but also women some of us astonished us, having been early at the tomb;
and not having found the body of him, came, saying also a vision of messengers to have seen, who say him to be alive.
And went some of those with us to the tomb, and found thus even as also the women said; him but not they saw.
And he said to them: O thoughtless and slow with the heart of the to believe in all, which spoke the prophets.
Not these it was binding to have suffered the Anointed, and to enter into the glory of himself?
And beginning from Moses and from all of the prophets, he explained to them in all the writings the things about himself.
And they drew near to the village, where they were going; and he seemed intending further to go.
But they pressed him, saying: Abide with us, for towards evening it is, and has declined the day. And he went in the to abide with them.
And it happened in the to recline him with them, having taken the loaf, be blessed, and having broken he gave to them.
Of them and were opened the eyes, and they knew him; and he disappeared from them.
And they said to each other: Not the heart of us burning was, in us, as he was talking to us in the way, and as he was opening to us the writings?
And rising up in this the hour, they returned to Jerusalem; and found having been assembled the eleven and those with them,
saying: That has been raised the Lord indeed, and has appeared to Simon.
And they related the things in the way, and how he was known to them in the breaking of the loaf.
These and of them speaking, he stood in midst of them, and says to them: Peace to you.
Being terrified but and affrighted having become they thought a spirit to see.
And he said to them: Why having been agitated are you? and why reasonings rise in the hearts of you?
See you the hands of me and the feet of me, that he I am; handle you me and see you; for a spirit flesh and bones not has, as me you perceive having.
And this saying, he showed to them the hands and the feet.
While and not believing of them from the joy, and were wondering, he said to them: Have you anything eatable here?
They and gave to him of a fish broiled a piece, and from a honey comb.
And having taken, in presence of them he eat.

He said and to them: These the words, which I spoke to you, while being with you, that must to be fulfilled all the things having been written in the law of Moses, and prophets, and psalms concerning me.
Then he opened of them the mind, of the to understand the writings;
and he said to them: That thus it is written, and thus it behooved to have suffered the Anointed, and to stand up out of dead ones in the third day,
and to be proclaimed in the name of him reformation and forgiveness of sins to all the nations, beginning from Jerusalem.
You and are witnesses of these.
And lo, I send forth the promise of the Father of me on you; you but remain you in the city, till you may be clothed power from on high.
He led and them out even to Bethany; and having lifted up the hands of himself, be blessed them.
And it happened in the to bless him them, he stood apart from them, and was carried up into the heaven.
And they having prostrated to him, returned to Jerusalem with joy great;
and were continually in the temple, praising and blessing the God.
In a beginning was the Word, and the Word was with the God, and a god was the Word.
This was in a beginning with the God.
All through it was done; and without it was done not even one, that has been done.
In it life was, and the life was the light of the men;
and the light in the darkness shines, and the darkness it not apprehended.
Was a man having been sent from God, a name to him John;
this came for a witness, that he might testify about the light, that all might believe through him.
Not was he the light, but that he might testify about the light.
Was the light the true, which enlightens every man coming into the world.
In the world he was, and the world through him was, and the world him not knew.
Into the own he came, and the own him not received.
As many as but received him, he gave to them authority children of God to become, to those believing into the name of him;
who not from bloods, nor from a will of flesh, nor from a will of a man, but from God were begotten.
And the Word flesh became, and tabernacled among us, (and we beheld the glory of him, a glory as of an onlybegotten from a father,) full of favor and truth.
John testifies concerning him, and cried saying: This was, of whom I said; He after me coming, before me has become; for first of me he was.
Because out of the fulness of him we all received, and favor upon favor.
For the law through Moses was given; the favor and the truth through Jesus Anointed came.
God no one has seen ever; the onlybegotten son, that being in the bosom of the Father, he has made known.
And this is the testimony of the John, when sent the Jews from Jerusalem priests and levites, that they might ask him: Thou who art?
And he confessed and not denied; and confessed: That not am I the Anointed.
And they asked him: What thou? Elias art thou? And he says: Not I am. The prophet art thou? And he answered: No.
They said then to him: Who art thou? that an answer we may give to those having sent us; what sayest thou about thyself?
He said: I: A voice crying in the desert; Make you straight the way of a lord, as said Esaias the prophet.
And those having been sent were of the Pharisees;
and they asked him, and said to him: Why then dippest thou, if thou not art the Anointed, nor Elias, nor a prophet?
Answered then the John, saying: I dip in water; midst but of you stands, whom you not know,
he after me coming, of whom I not am worthy, that I may loose of him the strap of the sandal.
These in Bethany were done beyond the Jordan, where was John dipping.
In the morrow he beholds the Jesus coming to him, and he says: Behold the lamb of the God, he taking away the sin of the world.
This is he, about whom I said: After me comes a man, who before me has become; because first of me he was.
And I not knew him; but that he might be manifested to the Israel, because of this am come I in the water dipping.
And bore testimony John, saying: That I saw the spirit coming down like a dove out of heaven, and it abode on him.
And I not knew him; but he having sent me to dip in water, he to me said: On whom thou mayest see the spirit coming down, and abiding on him, this is he dipping in spirit holy.
And I have seen, and have testified, that this is the son of the God.
The morrow again was standing the John, and of the disciples of him two.
And having looked on the Jesus walking, he says: Behold the lamb of the God.
And heard him the two disciples speaking, and they followed the Jesus.
Having turned and the Jesus, and seeing them following, he says to them: What seek you? They and said to him: Rabbi, (which means being interpreted, O teacher,) were dwellest thou?
He says to them: Come you and see you. They came and saw, where he dwells; and with him abode the day that. Hour it was about tenth.
Was Andrew, the brother of Simon Peter, one of the two of those having heard from John, and having followed him.
Finds he first the brother that own Simon, and he says to him: We have found the Messiah (which is being interpreted, Anointed.)
And he brought him to the Jesus. Having looked to him the Jesus said: Thou art Simon, the son of Jona; thou shalt be called Cephas; which means Peter.
The morrow he desired to go forth into the Galilee; and he finds Philip, and says to him: Follow me.
Was and the Philip from Bethsaida of the city of Andrew and Peter.
Finds Philip the Nathanael, and says to him: Whom wrote Moses in the law, and the prophets, we have found, Jesus the son of the Joseph, that from Nazareth.
And said to him Nathanael: Out of Nazareth is able any good to be? Says to him Philip: Come and see.
Saw the Jesus the Nathanael coming to him, and he says concerning him: Behold indeed an Israelite, in whom guile not is.
Says to him Nathanael: Whence me knowest thou? Answered Jesus and said to him: Before the thee Philip to have called, being under the figtree, I saw thee.
Answered Nathanael and says to him: Rabbi, thou art the son of the God, thou art the king of the Israel.
Answered Jesus and said to him: Because I said to thee; I saw thee underneath the figtree, believest thou? greater of these thou shalt see.
And he says to him: Indeed indeed I say to you, from now you shall see the heaven having been opened, and the messengers of the God ascending and descending on the son of the man.
And in the day the third a marriagefeast occurred in Cana of the Galilee; and was the mother of the Jesus there.
Was invited and also the Jesus and the disciples of him to the marriagefeast.
And having fallen short of wine, says the mother of the Jesus to him: Wine not they have.
Says to her the Jesus: What to me and to thee, O woman? Not yet has come the hour of me.
Says the mother of him to the servants; whatever he may say to you, do you.
Were and there waterpots of stone six being placed according to the mode of cleansing of the Jews, holding each measures two or three.
Says to them the Jesus: Fill you the waterpots of water. And they filled them to top.
And he says to them: Draw you now, and carry to the ruler of the feast. And they carried.
When and tasted the ruler of the feast the water wine having become; (and not he knew whence it is; the but servants knew, those having drawn the water;) calls the bridegroom the ruler of the feast,
and says to him: Every man first the good wine places, and when they may have drunk freely, then the worse; thou has kept the good wine till now.
This did the beginning of the signs the Jesus in Cana of the Galilee, and manifested the glory of himself; and believed into him the disciples of him.
After this he went down into Capernaum, he and the mother of him, and the brothers of him, and the disciples of him, and there remained not many days.
And nigh was the passover of the Jews, and went up to Jerusalem the Jesus.
And he found in the temple those selling oxen and sheep and doves, and the moneychangers sitting.
And having made a whip out of rushes, all he drove out of the temple, the and sheep and the oxen; and of the moneychangers he poured out the coin, and the tables overturned;
and to those the doves selling he said: Take these hence; not make you the house of the Father of me a house of merchandise.
Remembered and the disciples of him, that having been written it is: The zeal of the house of thee will consume me.
Answered then the Jews and said to him: What sign showest thou to us, that thee thou doest?
Answered the Jesus and said to them: Destroy the temple this, and in three days I will raise it.
Said then the Jews: Forty and six years was being built the temple this; and thou in three days will raise it?
He but spoke concerning the temple of the body of himself.
When therefore he was raised out of dead ones, remembered the disciples of him, that this he spoke; and they believed the writing, and the word which said the Jesus.
When and was in the Jerusalem at the passover at the feast, many believed into the name of him, beholding of him the signs which he did.
He but the Jesus not committed himself to them, because the him to know all;
and because not need he had, that any one should testify concerning the man; he for knew, what was in the man.
Was and a man of the Pharisees, Nicodemus a name to him, a ruler of the Jews;
this came to him by night, and said to him: Rabbi, we know that from God thou hast come a teacher; no one for these the signs is able to do, which thou doest, except may be the God with him.
Answered the Jesus and said to him: Indeed indeed I say to thee, if not any one may be born from above, not is able to see the kingdom of the God.
Says to him the Nicodemus: How is able a man to be born old being? not is able into the womb of the mother of himself a second time to enter, and to be born?
Answered Jesus: Indeed indeed I say to thee, if not any one may be born out of water and spirit, not is able to enter into the kingdom of the God.
That having been born out of the flesh, flesh is; and that having been born out of the spirit, a spirit is.
Not thou mayest wonder, that I said to thee: Must you to be born from above.
The spirit where it wills breathes; and the sound of it thou hearest, but not thou knowest, whence it comes, and where it goes; thus is every one the having been born out of of the spirit.
Answered Nicodemus and said to him: How is able these to be?
Answered Jesus and said to him: Thou art the teacher of the Israel, and these not thou knowest?
Indeed indeed I say to thee, that which we know we speak, and what we have seen we testify; and the testimony of us not you receive.
If the things earthly I told you, and not you believed; how, I tell you the things heavenly, will you believe?
And no one has ascended into the heaven, except he out of the heaven having descended, the son of the man, the being in the heaven.
And even as Moses raised aloft the serpent in the desert, thus to be raised it behooves the son of the man;
that every one who believing into him, not may be destroyed, but may have life agelasting.
Thus for loved the God the world, so that the son of himself the onlybegotten he gave, that every one who believing into him, not may be destroyed, but may have life agelasting.
Not for sent the God the son of himself into the world, that he might judge the world, but that might be saved the world through him.
He believing into him, not is judged; he but not believing, already is judged, became not he has believed into the name of the onlybegotten son of the God.
This and is the judgment, that the light has come into the world, and loved the man rather the darkness, than the light; was for evil of them the works.
Every one for the vile things doing, hates the light, and not comes to the light, that not may be detected the works of him.
He but doing the truth comes to the light, so that may be made manifest of him the works, that in God it is having been done.
After these came the Jesus and the disciples of him into the Judean land; and there remained with them, and was dipping.
Was and also John dipping in Enon, near the Salim, because waters many was there; and they were coming, and were being dipped.
Not yet for was having been cast into the prison the John.
Occurred then a disciple of the disciples of John with a Jew about cleansing.
And they came to the John, and said to him: Rabbi, who was with thee beyond the Jordan, to whom thou has testified, behold, he dips, and all come to him.
Answered John and said: Not is able a man to receive nothing, except it may be having been given to him from the heaven.
Yourselves you to me bear testimony, that I said: Not am I the Anointed, but that having been sent I am in presence of him.

He having the bride, a bridegroom is; the but friend of the bridegroom, that standing and hearing him, with joy rejoices through the voices of the bridegroom. This therefore the joy that of me has been completed.
Him it behooves to increase, me but to increase.
He from above coming, over all is. He being from the earth, from the earth is, and from the earth speaks; he from the heaven coming, over all is,
and what he has seen and heard, this he testifies; and the testimony of him no one receives.
He receiving of him the testimony, has set his seal, that the God true is.
Whom for has sent the God, the words of the God speaks; not for by measure gives the God the spirit.
The Father loves the son, and all has been given in the hand of him.
He believing into the son, has life agelasting; he but disobeying the son, not shall see life, but the anger of the God abides on him.
When therefore knew the Lord that heard the Pharisees, that Jesus more disciples made and dipped, than John;
(though indeed Jesus himself not dipped, but the disciples of him;)
he left the Judea, and went again into the Galilee.
It behooved and him to pass through the Samaria.
He comes therefore into a city of the Samaritans, being called Sychar, near by the field, of which gave Jacob Joseph to the son of himself.
Was and there a spring of the Jacob. The then Jesus having become weary from the journey, sat down thus over the spring; hour was about six.
Comes a woman of the Samaria, to draw water. Say to her the Jesus: Give to me a drink.
(The for disciples of him had gone into the city, that provisions they might buy.)
Says then to him the woman that Samaritan: How thou, a Jew being, from me to drink askest, being a woman a Samaritan? (Not for associate with Jews Samaritans.)
Answered Jesus and said to her: If thou hast known the gift of the God, and who is be saying to thee: Give to me to drink; thou wouldst ask him, and he would give thee water living.
Says to him the woman: O lord, nothing to draw with thou hast, and the well is deep; whence then hast thou the water the living?
Not thou greater art the father of us, Jacob? who gave to us the well, and he of it drank, and the sons of him, and the cattle of him.
Answered Jesus and said to her: All the drinking of the water this, will thirst again;

who but ever may drink of the water, of which I shall give to him, not not may thirst to the age; but the water, which I shall give him, shall be in him a well of water springing into life agelasting.
Says to him the woman: O lord, give to me this the water, that not I may thirst, nor may come in this place to draw.
Says to her the Jesus: Go, call the husband of thee, and come here.
Answered the woman and said: Not I have a husband. Says to her the Jesus: Rightly thou didst say: That a husband not I have.
Five for husbands thou hast had; and now whom thou hast not is of thee a husband; this truly thou hast said.
Says to him the woman: O lord, I see, that a prophet art thou.
The fathers of us in the mountain this worshipped; and you say, that in Jerusalem is the place, where it is necessary to worship.
Says to her the Jesus: O woman, believe thou me, that comes an hour, when neither in the mountain this, nor in Jerusalem you shall worship the Father.
You worship what not you know; we worship what we know; because the salvation from the Jews is.
But comes an hour, and now is, when the true worshippers shall worship the Father in spirit and truth; and for the Father such like seeks those worshipping him.
A spirit the God; and those worshipping him, in spirit and truth it behooves to worship.
Says to him the woman: I know, that Messiah comes; (the being called Anointed;) when may come he, he will relate to us all.
Says to her the Jesus: I am, he talking to thee.
And on this came the disciples of him, and wondered, that with a woman he talked. No one nevertheless said: What seekest thou? or, why talkest thou with her?
Left therefore the bucket of herself the woman, and went into the city, and says to the men:
Come you, see a man, who told me all what I did; not this is the Anointed?
They went out of the city, and were coming to him.
In and the meantime were asking him the disciples saying: Rabbi, eat.
He but said to them: I food have to eat, which you not know.
Said then the disciples to each other: Not any one brought to him food?
Says to them the Jesus: My food is, that I may do the will of the sending me, and may finish of him the work.
Not you say, that yet four months it is, and the harvest comes? Lo, I say to you, lift up the eyes of you, and see you the fields, that white they are to harvest already.
He reaping a reward receives, and gathers fruit for life agelasting; so that both he sowing together may rejoice, and he reaping.
In for this the word is the true, that one is the sowing, and another the reaping.
I sent you to reap what you have labored; others labored, and you into the labor of them are entered.
Out of and the city that many believed into him of the Samaritans, through the word of the woman, testifying: That he told me all what I did.
When therefore came to him the Samaritans, asking him to abide with them; and he abode there two days.
And many more believed through the word of him.
To the and woman they said: That no longer through the they saying we believe; ourselves for we have heard, and we know, that this is truly the savior of the world the Anointed.
After and the two days he went out thence, and went out into the Galilee.
Himself for Jesus testified, that a prophet in the own country honor not has.
When therefore he came into the Galilee, received him the Galileans, all having seen what he did in Jerusalem at the feast; also themselves for came to the feast.
He came then again into the Cana of the Galilee, where he made the water wine. And was certain courtier, of whom the son was sick, in Capernaum.
This hearing that Jesus was come out of the Judea into the Galilee, went to him, and was asking him, that he would come down, and heal of him the son; he was about for to die.
Said therefore the Jesus to him: If not signs and prodigies you may see, not not you may believe.
Says to him the courtier: O sir, come down, before to die the child of me.
Says to him the Jesus: Go; the son of thee lives. And believed the man the word which said to him Jesus, and went.
Already and of him was going down, the slaves of him met him, and reported, saying: That the child of thee lives.
He inquired then of them the hour, in which better he was. And they said to him: That yesterday hour seventh left the fever.
Knew then the father, that in that the hour, in which said to him the Jesus: That the son of thee lives. And he believed himself, and the house of him all.
This again a second sign did the Jesus, having come out of the Judea into the Galilee.
After these things was a feast of the Jews, and went up the Jesus to Jerusalem.
Is now in the Jerusalem, by the sheepgate, a swimming bath, that being called in Hebrew Bethesda, five porches having.
In these were lying a multitude great of those sick, blind, blame, withered waiting the of the water moving.
A messenger for at a season went down in the swimmingbath, and agitated the water; he then first stepping in after the agitation of the water, sound became, who indeed was held by disease.
Was and a certain man there, thirty and eight years being in the feeble health.
This seeing the Jesus lying, and knowing that long already time he had been, he says to him: Do thou wish sound to become?
Answered him he sick being: O sir, a man not I have, that when may be agitated the water, he may put me into the swimmingbath; in which but am coming I, another before me goes down.
Says to him the Jesus: Rise, take up the bed of thee, and walk.
And immediately became sound the man, and took up the bed of himself, and walked. It was and a sabbath in that the day.
Said then the Jews to the having been healed: A sabbath it is; not it is lawful for thee to carry the bed.
He answered them: He having made a sound, he to me said: Take up the bed of thee, and walk.
They asked then him: Who is the man, he saying to thee: Take up the bed of thee, and walk?
He but having been cured not knew who it is; the for Jesus slipped out, a crowd being in the place.
After these finds him the Jesus in the temple, and said to him: See, sound thou hast become; no longer do thou sin, that so worse to thee anything may happen.
Went away the man, and told to the Jews, that Jesus it is, he having made him sound.
And through this persecuted the Jesus the Jews, because these he did in a sabbath.
The and Jesus answered them: The father of me till now works, and I work.
Through this therefore more sought him the Jews to kill, because not only he was breaking the sabbath, but also a Father his own said the God, equal himself making to the God.

Answered then the Jesus and said to them: Indeed indeed I say to you, not is able the son to do of himself nothing, if not anything he may see the Father doing; what for ever he may do, these also the son in like manner does.
The for Father loves the son, and all shows to him, what he does; and greater of these shows to him works, so that you may wonder.
As for the Father raises the dead ones and makes alive; thus also the son, whom he will, makes alive.
Not even for the Father judges any one; but the judgment all has given to the son;
so that all may honor the son, even as they honor the Father. He not honoring the son, not honors the Father, that having sent him.
Indeed indeed I say to you, that he the word of me hearing, and believing, the having sent me has life agelasting, and into judgment not comes, but has passed out of the death into the life.
Indeed indeed I say to you, that comes an hour, and now is, when the dead ones shall hear the voice of the son of the God; and those having heard will live.
As for the Father has life in himself; so he gave also the son life to have in himself.
And authority he gave to him also judgment to execute, because a son of man he is.
Not wonder you this; because comes an hour, in which all those in the tombs, shall hear the voice of him,
and shall come forth, those the good things having done, to a resurrection of life; those and the evil things having done, to a resurrection of judgment.
Not am able I to do of myself nothing. Even as I hear, I judge, and the judgment the mine just is; that not I seek the will the mine, but the will of the sending me.
If I testify concerning myself, the testimony of me out not is true.
Another is he testifying concerning me; and I know, that rue is the testimony, which he testifies concerning me.
You have sent to John, and he has testified to the truth.
I but not from a man the testimony receive; but these things I say, that you may be saved.
He was the lamp the burning and shinning; you and were willing to rejoice for an hour in the light of him.

I but have the testimony greater of the John; the for works, which gave to me the Father, that I might finish them, these the works, which I do, testifies concerning me, because the Father me has sent.
And he having sent me Father himself has testified concerning me. Neither a voice of him have you heard at any time, nor form of him have you seen.
And the word of him not you have abiding in you; because whom sent he, this you not believe.
You search the writings, because you think in them life agelasting to have; and they are those testifying concerning me;
and not you are willing to come to me, so that life you may have.
Glory from men not I receive;
but I have known you, that the love of the God not you have in yourselves.
I have come in the name of the Father of me, and not you receive me; if another should come in the name the own, him you will receive.
How are able you to believe, glory from one another receiving, and the glory that from the only God not you seek?
Not think you, that I will accuse you to the Father; is he accusing you, Moses, into whom you have hoped.
If for you believe Moses, you would believe me; concerning for me he wrote.
If but the of him writings not you believe, how the my words will you believe.
After these things went the Jesus over the sea that of Galilee, of the Tiberias.
And was following him a crowd great, because they saw the signs, which he was doing on those being sick.
Went and into the mountain the Jesus, and there he was sitting with the disciples of himself.
Was and near the passover, the feast of the Jews.
Lifted up then the Jesus the eyes, and seeing that great a crowd was coming to him, says to the Philip: Whence shall we buy loaves, that may eat these?
(This but he said trying him; he for knew, what he was about to do.)
Answered him Philip: Two hundred denarii of loaves not are enough for them, so that each of them a little may take.
Says to him one of the disciples of him, Andrew, the brother of Simon Peter:
Is little boy one here, who has five loaves barley, and two small fishes; but these what are for so many?
Said and the Jesus: Make you the men to recline. Was and grass much in the place. Reclined therefore the men the number about five thousand.
Took and the loaves the Jesus, and having thanks distributed to the disciples, the and disciples to those reclining; in like manner also of the fishes what they wished.
When and they were filled, he says to the disciples of himself: Collect the remaining fragments, so that not any may be lost.
They collected therefore, and filled twelve baskets of fragments, out of the five loaves of the barley, which remained to those having eaten.
The therefore men seeing what did a sign the Jesus, said: That this is truly the prophet, he coming into the world.
Jesus therefore knowing that they were about to come, and to seize him, that they might make him a king, retired again into the mountain himself alone.
As and evening it became, went down the disciples of him on the sea.
And stepping into the ship, they were going over the sea to Capernaum. And dark now it had become, and not had come to them the Jesus.
The and sea, a wind great blowing was becoming agitated.
Having driven therefore about furlongs twentyfive or thirty, they see the Jesus walking on the sea, and near the ship was coming; and they were afraid.
He but says to them: I am, not fear you.
They were willing therefore to receive him into the ship; and immediately the ship was at the land, to which they were going.

The next day the crowd, that standing over the sea, seeing, that boat other not was there, if not one, and that not went with the disciples of himself the Jesus into the boat, but alone the disciples of him went away;
(other but came boats from Tiberias near the place, where they ate the bread, having given thanks the Lord;)
when therefore saw the crowd, that Jesus not is there, nor the disciples of him, they entered themselves into the boats, and came to Capernaum, seeking the Jesus.
And finding him beyond the sea, they said to him: Rabbi, when here didst thou come?
Answered them the Jesus and said: Indeed indeed I say to you: You seek me, not because you saw signs, but because you ate of the loaves, and were filled.
Work you not the food that perishing, but the food that abiding into life agelasting, which the son of the man to you will give; him for the Father sealed the God.
Said therefore to him: What shall we do, that we may work the works of the God?
Answered the Jesus and said to them: This is the work of the God, that you may believe into whom sent he.
They said therefore to him: What then doest thou sign, that we may see and we may believe thee? what doest thou work?
The fathers of us the manna ate in the desert, as it is having been written: Bread from the heaven gave them to eat.
Said therefore to them the Jesus: Indeed indeed I say to you, not Moses has given to you the bread from the heaven; but the Father of me gives to you the bread from the heaven the true.
The for bread of the God is he coming down from the heaven, and life is giving to the world.
They said then to him: O sir, always give to us the bread this.
Said but to them the Jesus: I am the bread of the life; he coming to me, not not may hunger; and he believing into me, not not may thirst ever.
But I said to you, that even you have seen me, and not you believe.
All what gives to me the Father, to me will come; and the coming to me, not not I will cast out;
because I have come down from heaven, not that I may do the will the mine, but the will of having sent me.
This and is the will of the having sent me, that every which he has given to me, not I may lose out of it, but raise up it in the last day.
This for is the will of the having sent me, that all who seeing the son, and believing into him, may have life agelasting; and will raise him I in the last day.
Were murmuring then the Jews about him, because he said: I am the bread that having come down from the heaven;
and they said: Not this is Jesus the son of Joseph, of whom we know the father and the mother? How then he says this: That from the heaven I have come down?
Answered the Jesus and said to them: Not murmur you with one another.
No one is able to come to me, if not the Father, that having sent me, may draw him, and I will raise up him in the last day.
It is having been written in the prophets: And they shall be all taught of God. Every one who having heard from the Father and having learned, comes to me.
Not that the Father any one has seen, if not he being from the God; this has seen the Father.
Indeed indeed I say to you, he believing into me, has life agelasting.
I am the bread of the life.
The fathers of you ate the manna in the desert, and died:
This is is the bread, that from the heaven coming down, so that any one of it may eat, and not may die.

I am the bread that living, that from the heaven having come down; if any one may eat of this the bread, he shall live into the age. And the bread also, which I will give, the flesh of me is, which I will give in behalf of the world life.
Were contending therefore with one another the Jews, saying: How is able this to us to give the flesh to eat?
Said them to them the Jesus: Indeed indeed I say to you, if not you may eat the flesh of the son of the man, and you may drink of him the blood, not have life in yourselves.
He eating of me the flesh, and drinking of me the blood, has life agelasting; and I will raise up him in the last day.
The for flesh of me truly is food, and the blood of me truly is drink.
He eating of me the flesh, and drinking of me the blood, in me abides, and I in him.
As sent me the living Father, and I live through the Father; also he eating me, even he shall live through me.
This is the bread, that from the heaven having come down; not as ate the fathers of you, and died; he eating this the bread, shall live into the age.
These things he said in a synagogue teaching in Capernaum.
Many therefore having heard of the disciples of him, said: Hard is this the saying; who is able it to hear?
Knowing but the Jesus in himself, that were murmuring about this the disciples of himself, he said to them: This you offends?
If then you should see the son of the man ascending, where he was the first?
The spirit is that making alive; the flesh not profits nothing. The words, which I speak to you, spirit is and life is.
But are of you some, who not believe; knew for from beginning the Jesus, some are who not believing, and who is he about betraying him.
And he said: Through this I have said to you that no one is able to come to me, if not may be having been given to him from the Father of me.
From this many went the disciples of him into the things behind; and no longer with him were walking.
Said therefore the Jesus to the twelve: Not and you wish to go?
Answered him Simon Peter: O lord, to whom shall we go? words of life agelasting thou hast;
and we have believed and have known, that thou art the holy one of the God.
Answered them the Jesus: Not I you the twelve choose? and of you one an accuser is.
He spoke now the Judas of Simon Iscariot; this for was about him to deliver up, one being of the twelve.
And was walking the Jesus after these things in the Galilee; not for he wished in the Judea to walk, because were seeking him the Jews to kill.
Was and near the feast of the Jews, the feast of tabernacles.
Said therefore to him the brothers of him: Depart hence, and go into the Judea, so that also the disciples of thee may see the works of thee, which thou doest.
No one for in secret anything does, and he seeks himself in public to be. If these things thou doest, manifest thyself to the world.
Not even for the brothers of him believed into him.
Says then to them the Jesus: The season the mine not yet is present; the but season the yours always is ready.
Not is able the world to hate you; me but it hates, because I testify concerning it, that the works of it evil is.
You go up to the feast this; I not go up to the feast this, because the season the mine not yet has fully come.
These things saying to them, he remained in the Galilee.
When but had gone up the brothers of him, then also he went up to the feast, not openly, but as in secret.
The then Jews sought him in the feast, and said: Where is he?
And murmuring much about him was among the crowds. The some said: That good he is; other said: No; but he deceives the crowd.
No one however with freedom spoke about him, because of the fear of the Jews.
Now and of the feast being half out, went up the Jesus into the temple, and taught.
And wondered the Jews, saying: How this letters knows, not having learned?
Answered them the Jesus and said: The my teaching not is mine, but of the sending me.
If any one may wish the will of him to do, he shall know concerning the teaching, whether from the God it is, or I from myself speak.
He from himself speaking, the glory the own seeks; he but seeking the glory of the sending him, this true is, and unrighteousness in him not is.
Not Moses has given to you the law? and no one of you does the law; why me do you seek to kill?
Answered the crowd and said: A demon thou hast; who thee seeks to kill?
Answered the Jesus and said to them: One work I did, and all you wonder because of this.
Moses has given to you the circumcision; (not that of the Moses it is, but of the fathers,) and in a sabbath you circumcise a man.
If circumcision receives a man in a sabbath, that not may be loosed the law of Moses, with me are you angry, because whole a man sound I made in a sabbath?
Not judge you according to appearance, but the righteous judgment judge you.
Said then some of the Jerusalemites: Not this is he, whom they seek to kill?
and lo, boldly he is talking, and nothing to him they say; not truly did know the rulers, that this is the Anointed?
But this we know, whence he is; the but Anointed when he comes, no one knows, whence he is.
Cried then in the temple teaching the Jesus, and saying: And me you know, and you know whence I am; and of myself not I have come, but is true he having sent me, whom you not know.
I know him, because from him I am, and he me sent.
They sought therefore him to seize; and no one put on him the hands, because not yet had come the hour of him.
Many and out of the crowd believed into him, and said: That the Anointed when he may come, not more signs of these will do, which he did?
Heard the Pharisees of the crowd murmuring about him these things; and sent the Pharisees and the highpriests officers, that they might seize him.
Said then the Jesus: Yet a little time with you I am, and I go to the sending me.
You will seek me, and not will find; and where I am I you not are able to come.
Said therefore the Jews to themselves: Where this he is about to go, that we not shall find him? not into the dispersion of the Greeks is about to go, and to teach the Greeks?
What is this the word, which he said: You will seek me, and not you will find; and whence am I you not are able to come?
In and the last day the great of the feast stood the Jesus, and cried, saying: If any one may thirst, let him come to me, and let him drink.
He believing into me, as said the scripture, rivers out of the belly of him shall flow of water living.
This but said concerning the spirit, of which was about to receive the believing into him; not yet for was spirit holy, because the Jesus not yet was glorified.
Many therefore out of the crowd having heard the word, said: This is truly the prophet.
Others said: This is the Anointed. Others but said: Not for out of the Galilee the Anointed comes?
Not the writing said, that of the seed of David, and from Bethlehem the village, where was David, the Anointed comes?
And division then in the crowd occurred through him.
Some and wished of them to seize him; but no one put on him the hands.
Came therefore the officers to the highpriests and Pharisees. And said to them these: Why not did you bring him?
Answered the officers: Never thus spoke a man, as this the man.
Answered then them the Pharisees: Not also you have been deceived?
not any one of the rulers believed into him, or of the Pharisees?
but the crowd this the not knowing the law; accursed are.
Says Nicodemus to them, he coming of night to him, one being of them:
Not the law of us judges the man, if not it may hear from him first, and may know what he does?
They answered and said to him: Not also thou of the Galilee art? search and see, that a prophet out of the Galilee not has been raised.
And went every one into the house of himself.
Jesus but went into the mountain of the olivetrees;
early morn and again he came into the temple, and all the people came to him; and having sat down he taught them.
Bring and the scribes and the Pharisees to him a woman in adultery having been taken, and placing her in middle,
they say to him: O teacher, this the woman was taken in the very act committing adultery.
In now the law Moses to us commanded the such like to be stoned? thou therefore what sayest thou?
This but they said tempting him, that they might have to accuse him. The but Jesus down stooping, with the finger wrote on the ground.
When but they continued asking him, having raised up he said to them: He without sin of you, first the stone on her let him cast.
And again down stooping, wrote on the ground.
They and having heard, and by the conscience being convinced, went out one by one, beginning from the elders even to the last ones; and left alone the Jesus, and the woman in middle standing.
Having raised up and the Jesus, and no one seeing but the woman, said to her: The woman, where are those the accusers of thee? no one thee condemned?
She and said: No one, O lord. Said and to her the Jesus: Neither I thee condemn; go, and no longer do thou sin.
Again therefore the Jesus to them spoke, saying: I am the light of the world; he following me, not not shall walk in the darkness, but shall have the light of the life.
Said therefore to him the Pharisees: Thou concerning thyself dost testify; the testimony of thee not is true.
Answered Jesus and said to them: Even if I testify concerning myself, true is the testimony of me; because I know, whence I came, and where I go; you but not know, whence I came, or where I go.
You according to the flesh judge, I not judge no one.
Even if judge but I, the judgment the my true is; because alone not I am, but I and the having sent me Father.
Also in the law and the your it has been written: That two of men the testimony true is.
I am he testifying concerning myself, and testifies concerning me the having sent me Father.
They said then to him: Where is the father of thee? Answered Jesus: Neither me you know, nor the Father of me. If me you knew, also the Father of me you would know.
These the words he spoke in the treasury, teaching in the temple; and no one seized him, because not yet had come the hour of him.
Said therefore again to them the Jesus: I go away, and you will seek me, and in the sin of you you will die; where I go, you not are able to come.
Said then the Jews: Not will he kill himself, because he says: Where I go, you not are able to come?
And he said to them: You from the beneath are, I from the above am; you from the world this are, I not am from the world this.
I said therefore to you, that you will die in the sins of you; if for not you may believe, that I am, you will die in the sins of you.
They said therefore to him: Thou who art? And said to them the Jesus: The beginning what, what even I say to you.
Many things I have about you to say, and to judge; but he having sent me true is; and I what I heard from him, these things I say to the world.
Not they knew, that the Father to them he spoke.
Said then to them the Jesus: When you may left up the son of the man, then you will know that I am; and from myself I do nothing, but as taught me the Father of me these things I say;
and he having sent me, with me is; not left me alone the Father, because I the things pleasing to him do always.
These of him speaking, many believed into him.
Said then the Jesus to those having believed him Jews: If you may abide in the word the my, truly disciples of me you are,
and you shall know the truth, and the truth shall make free you.
They answered him: Seed of Abraham we are, and to no one have we been slaves at any time; how thou sayest: That free you shall become?
Answered them the Jesus: Indeed indeed I say to you, that every one who is doing the sin, a slave is of the sin.
The but slave not abides in the house to the age; the son abides to the age.
If then the son you may make free, really free you shall be.
I know, that seed of Abraham you are; but you seek me to kill, because the word the mine not has place in you.
I what have seen from the Father of me, I speak; and you therefore what you have seen from the father of you, do.
They answered and said to him: The father of us Abraham is. Says to them the Jesus: If children of the Abraham you are, the works of the Abraham you would do.
Now but you seek me to kill, a man, who the truth to you has spoken, which I have heard from the God; this Abraham not did. You do the works of the father of you.
They said then to him: We from fornication not have been born; one father we have, the God.
Said to them the Jesus: If the God a father of you was, you would love me; I for from the God came out and am come; not even for of myself I have come, but he me sent.
Why the speech the mine not know you? Because not you are able to hear the word the mine.

You from the father the accuser are, and the lusts of the father of you you wish to do. He a manslayer was from a beginning, and in the truth not has stood; because not is truth in him. When may speak the falsehood, from the own he speaks; because a liar is, also the father of him.
I but because the truth I speak, not you believe me.
Who of you convicts me concerning sin? If truth I speak, why you not believe me?
He being from the God, the words of the God hears; through this you not hear, because from the God not you are.
Answered the Jews and said to him: Not well say we, that a Samaritan art thou, and a demon thou hast?
Answered Jesus: I a demon not have, but I honor the Father of me, and you dishonor me.
I but not seek the glory of me; it is he seeking and judging.
Indeed indeed I say to you, if any one the word the mine may keep, death not not he may see to the age.
Said then to him the Jews: Now we know, that a demon thou hast; Abraham died and the prophets, and thou sayest: If any one the word of me may keep, not not may taste of death to the age.
Not thou greater art of the father of us Abraham, who died? and the prophets died; whom thyself makest thou?
Answered Jesus: If I glorify myself, the glory of me nothing is. He is the Father of me he glorifying me, whom you say, that a God of you he is,
and not you know him; I but know him. And if I say, that not I know him, I shall be like you, a liar. But I know him, and the word of him I keep.
Abraham the father of you ardently desired, that he might see the day the my; and he saw, and was glad.
Said then the Jews to him: Fifty years not yet thou art, and Abraham hast thou seen?
Said to them the Jesus: Indeed indeed I say to you, before Abraham to have been born, I am.
They took up therefore stones, that they might cast on him; Jesus but hid himself, and went out of the temple.
And passing by, he saw a man blind from birth.
And asked him the disciples of him, saying: Rabbi, who sinned? this, or the parents of him, that blind he should be born?
Answered Jesus: Neither this sinned, nor the parents of him; but that may be manifested the works of the God in him.
Me it behooves to work the works of the sending me, while day it is; comes night, when no one is able to work.
While in the world I may be, light I am of the world.
These things saying, he spit on the ground, and made clay of the spittle, and rubbed the clay on the eyes of the blind,
and said to him: Go, wash thyself in the pool of the Siloam; (which is interpreted, having been sent.) He went away therefore, and washed himself, and came seeing.
The then neighbors, and those seeing him the before, because a beggar he was, said: Not this is he sitting and begging?
Others said: That this is. Others but: That like him it is. He said: That I am.
They said then to him: How were opened of thee the eyes?
Answered he and said: A man, being named Jesus, clay made, and rubbed of me the eyes, and said to me: Go into the Siloam, and wash thyself. Going and and washing myself, I obtained sight.
They said then to him: Where is he? He says: Not I know.
They bring him to the Pharisees, that once blind.
It was and a sabbath, when the clay made the Jesus, and opened of him the eyes.
Again therefore asked him also the Pharisees, how he obtained sight. He and said to them: Clay he put of me on the eyes, and I washed myself, and see.
Said therefore of the Pharisees some: This the man not is from the God, because the sabbath not he keeps. Others said: How is able a man a sinner such signs to do? And a division was among them.
They say to the blind again: Thou what sayest concerning him, seeing that he opened of thee the eyes? He and said: That a prophet he is.
Not believed therefore the Jews concerning him, that blind he was, and obtained sight, till when they called the parents of him the having obtained sight.
And they asked them, saying: This is the son of you, whom you say, that blind he was born? how then now he sees?
Answered them the parents of him and said: We know, that this is the son of us, and that blind he was born;
how but now he sees, not we know; or who opened of him the eyes, we not know, he full age has, him ask you; he concerning himself shall speak.
These things said the parents of him, because they feared the Jews. Already for had agreed the Jews, that if any one him should confess Anointed, from a synagogue should be.
Through this the parents of him said: That full age he has, him ask you.
They called therefore a second time the man, who was blind, and said to him: Give glory to the God; we know, that the man this a sinner is.
Answered then he and said: If a sinner he is, not I know; one I know, that blind being, now I see.
They said and to him again: What did he to thee? how opened of thee the eyes?
He answered them: I said to you already, and not you did hear; why again do you wish to hear? not also you wish of him disciples to be?
They reviled him, and said: Thou art a disciple of him; we but of the Moses are disciples.
We know, that to Moses has spoken the God; this but not we know whence is.
Answered the man and said to them: In for this a wonder is, that you not know whence he is, and he has opened of me the eyes.
We know but, that sinners the God not hears; but if any one a worshipper of God may be, and the will him may do, this he hears.
From the age not it was heard, that opened any one eyes of blind having been born.
If not was this from God, not were able to do nothing.
They answered and said to him: In sins thou wast born wholly; and thou teachest us? And they cast him out.
Heard the Jesus, that they cast him out; and having found him, said to him: Thou believest into the son of the God?
Answered he and said: And who is he, O sir, that I may believe into him?
Said and to him the Jesus: Even thou hast seen him, and he talking with thee, he is.
He and said: I believe, O sir; and he prostrated to him.
And said the Jesus: For judgment I into the world this came, that those not seeing might see, and those seeing blind might become.
And heard of the Pharisees these things those being with him, and said to him: Not also we blind are?
Said to them the Jesus: If blind you were, not you would have sin; now but you say: That we see; the therefore sin of you remains.
Indeed indeed I say to you, he not entering through the door into the fold of the sheep, but going up another way, he a thief is and a robber;
he but entering through the door, a shepherd is of the sheep.
To him the doorkeeper opens; and the sheep the voice of him hears; and the own sheep he calls by name, and he leads out them.
And when the own sheep he puts forth, before them he goes; and the sheep him follows, because they know the voice of him.
A stranger but not not they may follow, but will flee from him; because not they know of the strangers the voice.
This the parable said to them the Jesus; they but not knew, what was, which he spoke to them.
Said then again to them the Jesus: Indeed indeed I say to you, that I am the door of the sheep.
All as many as came before me, thieves are and robbers; but not heard them the sheep.
I am the door; through me if any one may come in, he shall be saved, and shall come in and go out, and pasture shall find.
The thief not come, if not that he may steal and may kill, and may destroy; I come, that life they may have, and abundance may have.
I am the shepherd the good; the shepherd the good the life of himself lays down in behalf of the sheep.
The hireling but, and not being a shepherd, of whom not are the sheep own, see the wolf coming, and leaves the sheep, and flees; and the wolf seizes them, and scatters the sheep.
The but hireling flees, because an hireling he is, and not it concerns him about the sheep.
I am the shepherd the good; and know the mine, and am known by the mine,
as knows me the Father, and I know the Father; and the life of me I lay down in behalf of the sheep.
And other sheep I have, which not is of the fold this; also them me it behooves to lead; and the voice of me they will hear, and there will be one flock, one shepherd.
Through this the Father me loves, because I lay down the life of me, that again I may receive her;
no one takes her from me, but I lay down her of myself; authority I have to lay down her, and authority I have again to receive her; this the command I received from the Father of me.
A division then again occurred among the Jews through the words these.
Said and many of them: A demon he has, and is mad; why him hear you?
Others said: These the words not are of one being demonized; not a demon is able blind eyes to open?
Occurred now the feast of dedication in the Jerusalem, and winter it was;
and was walking the Jesus in the temple, in the porch of Solomon.
Surrounded therefore him the Jews, and said to him: Till when the life of us dost thou take? If thou art the Anointed, tell us plainly.
Answered them the Jesus: I told you, and not you believe. The works, which I do in the name of the Father of me these testify concerning me.
But you not believe; not for you are of the sheep the mine.
As I said to you, the sheep the mine the voice of me hears, and I know them, and they follow me;
and I life agelasting give to them, and not not they will perish into the age, and not will wrest any one them out of the hand of me.
The father of me, who has given to me, greater of all is; and no one is able to wrest out of the hand of the Father of me;
I and the Father one are.
Took up then again stones the Jews, that they might stone him.
Answered them the Jesus: Many good works I showed you from the Father of me; because of which of them work do you stone me?
Answered him the Jews saying: Concerning a good work not we stone thee, but concerning blasphemy, and that thou, a man being, makest thyself a god.
Answered them the Jesus: Not is it having been written in the law of you: I said, gods you are?
If them he called gods, to whom the word of the God came, and not is able to be broken the writing;
whom the Father set apart, and sent into the world, you say: That thou blasphemest, because I said, A son of the God I am?
If not I do the works of the Father of me, not you believe me.
If but I do, and if me not you believe, the works believe you; that you may know and you may believe, that in me the Father, and I in him.
They sought therefore again him to seize; and he went forth out of the hand of them.
And he went again beyond the Jordan, to the place where was John the first dipping; and abode there.
And many came to him, and said: That John indeed a sign did not one; all but what things said John concerning this, true was.
And believed many there into him.
Was and certain sick one, Lazarus, from Bethany, out of the village of Mary and Martha the sister of her.
(Was and Mary the having anointed the Lord with balsam, and wiped the feet of him with the hairs of herself; of whom the brother Lazarus was stick.)
Sent therefore the sisters to him, saying: O lord, lo, whom thou lovest is sick.
Having heard and the Jesus said: This the sickness not is to death, but on account of the glory of the God, that may be glorified the son of the God through her.
Loved now the Jesus the Martha, and the sister of her, and the Lazarus.
When then he heard, that he was sick, then indeed he abode in which he was place two days.
Then after this he says to the disciples: Let us go into the Judea again.
Say to him the disciples: Rabbi, now sought thee to stone the Jews, and again goest thou there?
Answered Jesus: Not twelve are hours of the day? If any one may walk in the day, not he stumbles, because the light of the world this he sees.
If but any one may walk in the night, he stumbles, because the light not is in him.
