These things he said; and after this he says to them: Lazarus the friend of us is fallen asleep; but I go, that I may awake him.
Said then the disciples of him: O lord, if he is fallen asleep, he shall be saved.
Had spoken but the Jesus about the death of him; they but thought, that concerning the repose of the sleep he speaks.
Then therefore said to them the Jesus plainly: Lazarus died;
and I rejoice because of you, that you may believe, that not I was there; but we may go to him.
Said then Thomas, that being called a twin, to the fellowdisciples: May go also we, that we may die with him.
Coming therefore the Jesus found him four days already been in the tomb.
Was now the Bethany near the Jerusalem, about from furlongs fifteen.
And many of the Jews had come to those about Martha and Mary, that they might comfort them concerning the brother of them.
The then Martha when she heard, that Jesus was coming, met him; Mary but in the house was sitting.
Said then the Martha to the Jesus: O lord, if thou hadst been here, the brother of me not would have died;
but and now I know, that whatever things thou mayest ask the God, will give to thee the God.
Says of her the Jesus: Will rise again the brother of thee.
Says to him Martha: I know, that he will rise again, in the resurrection in the last day.
Said to her the Jesus: I am the resurrection and the life; he believing into me, even if he may die, he shall live;
and all the living and believing into me, not not may die into the age. Believest thou this?
She says to him: Yes, O lord, I have believed, that thou art the Anointed, the son of the God, he into the world coming.
And these things saying, she went, and called Mary the sister of her privately, saying: The teacher is present, and calls thee.
She when she heard, rises up quickly, and comes to him.
(Not yet now had come the Jesus into the village; but was in the place, where met him the Martha.)

The therefore Jews, those being with her in the house and were comforting her, seeing the Mary, that quickly she rose up and went out, followed her, saying: That she goes into the tomb, that she may weep there.
The therefore Mary when came where was the Jesus, seeing him, she fell of him to the feet, saying to him: O lord, if thou hadst been there, not would have died of me the brother.
Jesus therefore when he saw her weeping, and those having come with her Jews weeping, he was agitated in the spirit, and troubled himself,
and said: Where have you laid him? They say to him: O lord, come, and see.
Wept the Jesus.
Said then the Jews: See, how he loved him.
Some but of them said: Not was able this, he having opened the eyes of the blind to have caused, that even this not should die?
Jesus therefore again being agitated in himself, comes to the tomb. It was now a cave, and a stone was lying on it.
Says the Jesus: Take away the stone. Says to him the sister of the having died, Martha: O lord, now he smelling; fourth day for it is.
Says to her the Jesus: Not I said to thee, that if thou wouldst believe, thou shalt see the glory of the God?
They took away then the stone. The but Jesus lifted up the eyes above, and said: O Father, I give thanks to thee, that thou didst hear me.
I and knew, that always me thou hearest; but on account of the crowd that standing I spoke, so that they may believe, that thou me has sent.
And these things saying, with a voice loud he cried out: O Lazarus, come out.
Came out he having been dead, having been bound the feet and the hands with bandages, and the face of him with a napkin bound about. Says to them the Jesus: Loose you him, and allow to go.
Many therefore of the Jews, those having come to the Mary, and having gazed upon what he did, believed into him.
Some but of them went to the Pharisees, and told them what did the Jesus.
Assembled then the highpriests and the Pharisees a high council, and said: What are we doing? because this the man many signs does.
If we allow him thus, all will believe into him; and will come the Romans, and will take away of us both the place and the nation.
One and a certain of them, Caiaphas, highpriest being of the year that, said to them: You not know nothing.
Neither do you consider, that it is better for us, that one man should die in behalf of the people, and not whole the nation should perish.
This but from himself not he said; but highpriest being of the year that, he prophesied, that was about Jesus to die in behalf of the nation;
and not in behalf of the nation alone, but that also the children of the God those having been scattered he should gather into one.
From that therefore the day they took counsel together, that they might kill him.
Jesus therefore no longer publicly walked among the Jews, but went away thence into the country near the desert, into Ephraim being called a city; and there remained with the disciples of himself.
Was and near the passover the Jews; and went up many into Jerusalem out of the country before the passover, that they might purify themselves.
They sought then the Jesus, and said with each other in the temple standing: What think you? that not not he may come to the feast?
Had given now both the highpriests and the Pharisees a commandment, that if any one should know where he is, he should show, how they might seize him.
The therefore Jesus before six days the passover came into Bethany, where was Lazarus he having been dead, whom he raised out of dead ones.
They made therefore him a supper there, and the Martha served; the but Lazarus one was of those reclining with him.

The then Mary having taken a pound of balsam of spikenard genuine of great price, anointed the feet of the Jesus, and wiped with the hairs of herself the feet of him; the and house was filled with the odor of the balsam.
Says therefore one of the disciples of him, Judas of Simon Iscariot, he being about him to deliver up:
Why this the balsam not sold three hundred denarii, and given to poor ones?
He said now this, not because about the poor it concerned him, but because a thief he was, and the box he had, and the things being put in he carried off.
Said therefore the Jesus: Let alone her; for the day of the embalming of me she has kept it.
The poor for always you have with yourselves, me but not always you have.
Knew therefore a crowd great of the Jews, that there he is; and they came not on account of the Jesus alone; but that also the Lazarus they might see, whom he raised out of dead ones.
Took counsel but the highpriests, that also the Lazarus they might kill;
because many on account of him went away of the Jews, and believed into the Jesus.
On the morrow a crowd great, who having come to the feast, having heard, that was coming Jesus into Jerusalem,
they took the branches of the palmtrees, and went out to a meeting with him, and cried out: Hosanna, worthy of blessing he coming in name of Lord, the king of the Israel.
Finding and the Jesus a young ass, he sat on it, as it is having been written:
Not fear, O daughter of Sion; lo, the king of thee comes sitting on a foal of an ass.

These things now not knew the disciples of him the first; but when was glorified the Jesus, then they remembered, that these things was about him having been written, and these things they did to him.
Testified then the crowd, that being with him, that the Lazarus he called out of the tomb, and raised him out of dead ones.
On account of this also met him the crowd, because they heard this him to have done the sign.
The then Pharisees said to themselves: You see that not you gain nothing; see, the world after him is going away.
Were and some Greeks of those going up, that they might worship in the feast.
These therefore came to Philip, that from Bethsaida of the Galilee, and were asking him, saying: O sir, we wish the Jesus to see.
Come Philip, and says to the Andrew; and again Andrew and Philip say to the Jesus.
The but Jesus answered them, saying: Has come the hour, that may be glorified the son of the man.
Indeed indeed I say to you, if not the grain of the wheat falling into the ground should die, he alone abides; if but it may die, much fruit it bears.
He loving the life of himself, shall lose her; and he hating the life of himself in the world this, into life agelasting shall keep her.
If me may serve any one, me let him follow; and where am I, there also the servant the mine shall be; if any one me may serve, will honor him the Father.
Now the soul of me is troubled; and what shall I say? O Father, save me from the hour this? But on account of this I came to the hour this.
O Father, glorify of thee the name. Came then a voice out of the heaven: Both I glorified, and again will glorify.
The therefore crowd that standing and hearing, said thunder to have been. Others said: A messenger to him has spoken.
Answered the Jesus and said: Not on account of me this the voice had come, but on account of you.
Now a judgment is the world this; now the ruler of the world this, will be cast out.
And if I should be lifted up from the earth, all will draw to myself.
This but he said, signifying by what death he was about to die.
Answered him the crowd: We heard out of the law, that the Anointed abides into the age; and how thou sayest, that it behooves to be lifted up the son of the man? who is this the son of the man?
Said then to them the Jesus: Yet a little time the light among you is. Walk you, while the light you have, that not darkness you may overtake; and he walking in the darkness not knows where he goes.
While the light you have, believe into the light, that sons of light you may become. These things spoke the Jesus, and going away he was hid from them.
So many but of him signs having been done in presence of them not they did believe into him;
that the word of Esaias the prophet might be fulfilled, which he said: O lord, who believed the report of us? and the arm of Lord to whom was it revealed?
On account of this not they were able to believe; because again said Esaias:
He has blinded of them the eyes, and has hardened of them the heart; so that not they might see with the eyes, and understand with the heart, and should turn back, and I should heal them.
These things said Esaias, because he saw the glory of him, and spoke concerning him.
Nevertheless truly and of the rulers many believed into him; but on account of the Pharisees not did confess, so that not from synagogues they might be;
they loved for the glory of the men more, than the glory of the God.
Jesus and cried and said: He believing into me, not believe into me, but into him having sent me;
and he seeing me, see him having sent me.
I a light into the world have come, that all the believing into me, in the darkness not may abide.
And if any one of me may hear the words, and not may believe, I not judge him; (not for I came, that I might judge the world, but that I might save the world);
he rejecting me, and not receiving the words of me has that judging him; the word which I spoke, that shall judge him in the last day.
Because I from myself not spoke; but the having sent me Father he me a commandment gave, what I should say and what I should I speak.
And I know, that the commandment of him life agelasting is. What therefore say I, as has spoken to me the Father, so I speak.
Before and the feast of the passover, knowing the Jesus, that was come of himself the hour, that he should depart out of the world this to the world, to an end he loved them.
And supper being done, (the accuser already having put into the heart Judas of Simon Iscariot, that him he might betray,)
knowing the Jesus, that all things had given him the Father into the hands, and that from God he came out and to the God he goes;
rises from the supper, and puts off the mantles, and having taken a towel, girded himself.
Afterward he puts water into the washbasin, and began to wash the feet of the disciples, and to wipe with the towel with which he was having been girded.
He comes then to Simon Peter; and says to him he: O lord, thou of me washest the feet?
Answered Jesus and said to him: What I do, thou not knowest now, thou shalt know but after these things.
Says to him Peter: Not not thou mayest wash the feet of me into the age. Answered him the Jesus: If not I may wash thee, thou hast a part of me.
Says to him Simon Peter: O lord, not the feet of me alone, but also the hands, and the head.
Says to him the Jesus: He having been bathed not need has than the feet to wash, but is clean wholly; and you clean are, but not all.
He knew for the betraying him; on account of this he said: Not all clean you are.
When therefore he had washed the feet of them, and taken the mantles of himself, falling down again, he said to them: Know you what I have done to you:
You call me: The teacher and the lord; and well you say; I am for.
If then I washed of you the feet, the lord and the teacher, also you are bound of one another to wash the feet.
An example for I gave to you, that as I did to you, also you should do.
Indeed indeed I say to you, not is a slave greater of the lord of himself, nor a messenger greater of the sending him.
If these things you know, blessed are you, if you should do them.
Not about all of you I speak; I know whom I chose; but, that the writing may be fulfilled: He eating with me the loaf, lifted up against me the heel of himself.
From now I say to you, before the to happen, that when it may happen, you may believe, that I am.
Indeed indeed I say to you: He receiving if any one I may send, me receives; he and me receiving, receives him having sent me.
These things saying the Jesus was troubled in the spirit, and testified, and said: Indeed indeed I say to you, that one of you will betray me.
Looked then to each other the disciples, doubting about whom he was speaking.
Was now reclining one of the disciples of him in the bosom of the Jesus, whom loved the Jesus.
Nods then to him Simon Peter, to ask who it might be concerning of whom he speaks.
Falling and he on the breast of the Jesus, he says to him: O lord, who is it?
Answers the Jesus: He it is, to whom I have dipped the little piece shall give. And having dipped the little piece, he gives to Judas of Simon Iscariot.
And after the little piece, then answered into him the adversary. Says then to him the Jesus: What thou doest, do thou quickly.
This now no one knew of those reclining with why he said to him.
Some for thought, seeing that the box had the Judas, that says to him the Jesus: Buy what things need we have for the feast; or to the poor that something he should give.
Having taken then the little piece he immediately went out; it was and night.
When he went out, says the Jesus: Just now was glorified the son of the man, and the God was glorified in him.
If the God was glorified in him, also the God will glorify him in himself, and immediately will glorify him.
O little children, yet a little with you I am. You will seek me; and as I said to the Jews: That where I go, you not are able to come; even to you I say now.
A commandment new I give to you, that you may love each other; as I loved you, that also you might love each other.
By this will know all that to me disciples you are, if love you have in each other.
Says to him Simon Peter: O lord, where goest thou? Answered him the Jesus: Where I go, not thou art able me now to follow; afterwards but thou shalt follow me.
Says to him Peter: O lord, why not I am able thee to follow now? the life of me in behalf of thee I will lay down.
Answered him the Jesus: The life of thee in behalf of me wilt thou lay down? Indeed indeed I say to thee not not a cock will crow, till not thou wilt deny me thrice.
Not let be troubled of you the heart; believe you into the God, and into me believe you.
In the house of the Father of me dwellings many are; if but not, I would have told you. I am going to prepare a place for you;
and if I should go, and should prepare for you a place, again I am coming, and will receive you to myself; so that where am I, also you may be.
And where I am going you know, and the way you know.
Says to him Thomas: O lord, not we know where thou art going? and how are we able the way to know?
Says to him the Jesus: I am the way, and the truth, and the life; no one comes to the Father, if not through me.
If you had known me, also the Father of me you would have known; and from now you know him, and have seen him.
Says to him Philip: O lord, show to us the Father, and it is enough for us.
Says to him the Jesus: So long a time with you am I, and not knowest thou me, O Philip? He having seen me, has seen the Father; and how thou sayest: Show to us the Father?
Not believest thou, that I in the Father, and the Father in me is? The words which I speak to you, from myself not I speak; the but Father, he in me abiding, he does the works.
You believe me, because I in the Father, and the Father in me, if but not, on account of the works themselves believe me.
Indeed indeed I speak to you, he believing into me, the works which I do, also he shall do, and greater of these shall he do; because I to the Father of me am going,
and what any thing you may ask in the name of me, this I will do; that may be glorified the Father in the son.
If any thing you may ask in the name of me, I will do.
If you love me, the commandments the mine keep you;
and I will ask the Father, and another helper he will give to you, that he may abide with you into the age;
the spirit of the truth, which the world not is able to receive, because not it beholds it, nor knows it; you but know it, because with you it abides, and in you it will be.
Not I will leave you orphans; I am coming to you.
Yet a little, and the world me no more beholds; you but behold me; because I live, also you shall live.
In that the day shall know you, because I in the Father of me, and you in me, and I in you.
He having the commandments of me, and keeping them, that is he loving me; he and loving me, shall be loved by the Father of me; and I will love him, and will manifest to him myself.
Says to him Judas (not the Iscariot): O lord, and how has it happened, that to us thou art about to manifest thyself, and not to the world?
Answered Jesus and said to him: If any one love me, the word of me he will keep; and the Father of me will love him; to him we will come, and a dwelling with him we will make.
He not loving me, the words of me not will keep; and the word which you hear, not is mine, but of the sending me Father.
These things I have spoken to you, with you abiding;
but the helper, the spirit the holy, which will send the Father in the name of me, that you will teach all things, and will remind you all things which I told you.
Peace I leave to you, peace the mine I give to you; not as the world gives, I give to you. Not let be troubled of you the heart nor let it be afraid.
You heard, that I said to you: I am going away, and I am coming to you. If you loved me, you would rejoice, that I am going to the Father; because the Father of me greater of me is.
And now I have told you before it happens, so that when it happens, you may believe.
No more much I will speak with you. Is coming for he of the world ruling, and in me not has nothing.
But that may know the world, that I love the Father, and as commanded me the Father, so I do. Arise you, let us go from this place.
I am the vine the true, and the Father of me the vinedresser is.
Every branch in me, not bearing fruit, he takes away it; and every one the fruit bearing, he cleanses it, that more fruit it may bear.
Already you clean are, through the word, which I have spoken to you.
Abide you in me, and I in you. As the branch not is able fruit to bear of itself, if not it may abide in the vine; so neither you, if not in me you abide.
I am the vine, you the branches. He abiding in me, and I am in him, this bears fruit much; because apart from me not you are able to do nothing.
If not any one may abide in me, he is cast out, like the branch, and is withered; and they gather them, and into a fire they cast, and it is burned.
If you abide in me and the words of me in you may abide, whatever you may wish you shall ask, and it shall be for you.
In this was glorified the Father of me, that fruit much you might bear, and you shall be to me disciples.
As loved me the Father, and I loved you; abide you in the love the mine.
If the commandments of me you may keep, you will abide in the love of me; as I the commandments of the Father of me have kept, and abide of him in the love.
These things I have spoken to you, that the joy the mine in you may abide, and the joy of you may be fulfilled.
This is the commandment the mine, that you love each other, as I loved you.
Greater of this love no one has, that any one the life of himself may lay down in behalf of the friends of himself.
You friends of me are, if you may do what things I command you.
No more you I call slaves; because the slaves not knows what does of him the lord; you but I have called friends, because all things which I heard from the Father of me, I made known to you.

Not you me did choose, but I chose you, and appointed you, that you might go and fruit might bear, and the fruit of you might abide; so that whatever you may ask the Father in the name of me, he may give to you.
These things I command you, that you may love each other.
If the world you hates, you know, that me before you it has hated.
If of the world you were, the world would the own kiss, because but of the world not you are, but I chose you out of the world, on account of this hates you the world.

Remember you the world, of which I said to you. Not is a slave greater of the lord of himself. If me they persecuted, also you they will persecute; if the word of me they kept, also the yours they will keep.
But these things all they will do to you on account of the name of me, because not they know him sending me.
If not I had come and spoken to them, sin not they had; now but an excuse not they have about the sin of them.
He me hating, also the Father of me hates.
If the works, not I had done among them, which no one other has done, sin not they had; now but even they have seen, and have hated both me and that Father of me.
But, that may be fulfilled the word of having been written in the law of them: That they hated me without cause.
When but may come the helper, whom I will send to you from the Father, (the spirit of the truth, which from the Father shall come out,) that will testify concerning me.
Also you and shall testify, because from a beginning with me you are.
These things I have spoken to you, that not you may be ensnared.
From synagogues they will put you; but comes an hour, that every one the killing you, may think a service to offer to the God.
And these things they will do, because not they know the Father, nor me.
But these things I have spoken to you, that when may come the hour, you may remember them, that I said to you. These things but to you from a beginning not I said, because with you I was.
Now but I go to him having sent me, and no one of you asks me: Where goest thou?
But because these things I have spoken to you, the sorrow has filled of you the heart.
But I the truth say to you; it is better for you, that I should go away. If for not I should go away, the helper not will come to you; if but I go, I will send him to you.
And having come he will convict the world concerning sin, and concerning righteousness, and concerning judgment.
Concerning sin indeed, because not they believe into me;
concerning righteousness but, because to the Father of me I go away, and no more you behold me;
concerning and judgment, because the ruling of the world this has been judged.
Yet many things I have to say to you, but not you are able to bear now.

When but many may come he the spirit of the truth, he will lead you into all the truth. Not for he will speak from himself, but whatever he may hear, he will speak, and the things coming he will declare to you.
He me will glorify, because out of the mine will take, and will declare to you.
All things what was the Father, mine is. On account of this I said, that out of the mine he takes, and declares to you.
A little while, and not you see me; and again a little while, and you shall see me, because I am going to the Father.

Said then of the disciples of him to each other: What is this which he says to us: A little while, and not you see me; and again a little while and you shall see me; and: Because I am going to the Father?
They said therefore: This what is which he says, the little while? Not we know what he says.

Knew the Jesus, that they wish him to ask, and said to them: Concerning this inquire you with each other, because I said: A little while, and not you see me; and again a little while, and you shall see me?
Indeed indeed I say to you, that will weep and will lament you, the but world will rejoice; you and will be sorrowful, but the sorrow of you into joy shall become.

The woman when she may bear, sorrow has, because has come the hour of her; when but she may have borne the child, no more she remembers of the distress, on account of the joy, that was born a man into the world.
And you therefore sorrow indeed now have; again but I will see you, and will be rejoiced of you the heart, and the joy of you no one takes from you;
and in that the day me not you will ask nothing; Indeed indeed I say to you, that whatever you may ask the Father in the name of me, he will give to you.
Till now not you asked nothing in the name of me; ask you, and you shall receive, so that the joy of you may be completed.
These things in figures I have spoken to you; comes an hour, when no more in figures I will speak to you, but plainly concerning the Father i will tell you.
In that the day in the name of me you will ask; and not I say to you, that I will entreat the Father concerning you;
himself for the Father loves you, because you me have loved and have believed, that I from the God came out.
I came out from the Father, and have come into the world; again I leave the world; and am going to the Father.
Say to him the disciples of him: Lo, now plainly thou speakest, and a figure not one thou sayest.
Now we know, that thou knowest all things, and no need has, that any one thee should ask; in this we believe, that from God thou didst come out.
Answered them the Jesus: Now do you believe.
Lo, comes an hour, and now is come, that you will be scattered every one to the own, and me alone you may leave; and not I am alone, because the Father with me is.
These things I have spoken to you, that in me peace you may have. In the world affliction you have; but be you of good courage, I have overcome the world.
These things spoke the Jesus, and lifted up the eyes of him to the heaven, and said: O Father, is come the hour; glorify of thee the son, that also the son of thee may glorify thee;
as thou gavest to him authority over all flesh, so that all which thou hast given to him, he may give to them life agelasting.
This and is the agelasting life, that they might know thee the only true God, and whom thou hast sent Jesus Anointed.
I thee glorified on the earth; the work I finished, which thou hast given me, that I might do.
And now glorify me, thou O Father, with thyself, with the glory, which I had, before of the the world to be, with thee.
I manifested of thee the name to the men, whom thou hast given to me out of the world; thine they were, and to me them thou hast given; and the word of thee they have kept.
Now they know, that all things whatever thou hast given me, from thee is;
because the words which thou hast given me, I have given to them; and they received, and knew truly, that thou thee I came out, and believed, that thou me didst send.
I concerning them ask; not concerning the world I ask, but concerning whom thou hast given me, because thine they are;
and the mine all thine is, and the thine mine, and I have been glorified in them.
And no more I am in the world, and these in the world are, and I to thee am coming. O Father holy, keep them in the name of thee, by which thou hast given to me; that they may be one, as we.

When I was with them in the world, I kept them in the name of thee; whom thou hast given to me I guarded, and no one of them was destroyed, if not the son of the destruction, that the writings may be fulfilled.
Now and to thee I am coming, and these things I say in the world, that they may have the joy the mine fulfilled in them.
I have given to them the word of thee; and the world hated them, because not they are of the world, as I not am of the world.
Not I ask, that thou wouldst take them out of the world, but that thou wouldst keep them from the evil one.
Of the world not they are, as I of the world not am.
Sanctify them in the truth of thee; the word the thine truth is.
As me thou didst send into the world, also I sent them into the world.
And in behalf of them I sanctify myself, so that also they may be sanctified in truth.
Not concerning these and I ask alone, but also concerning those believing through the word of them into me.
That all one may be; as thou, Father, in me, and I in thee, that also they in us one may be; that the world may believe, that thou me didst send.
And I the glory which thou hast given to me, have given to them; that they may be one, as we one are;
(I in them, and thou in me); that they may be perfected into one, and that may know the world, that thou me didst send, and thou didst love them, as me thou didst love.

O Father, whom thou given to me, I wish, that where am I, also they may be with me; that they may behold the glory the mine, which thou didst give to me, because thou didst love me before a laying down of a world.
O Father righteous, and the world thee not knew; I but thee knew, and these knew that thou me didst send.
And I made known to them the name of thee, and will make known; that the love which thou didst love me, in them may be, and I in them.
These things saying the Jesus went out with the disciples of himself beyond the brook of the Kedron, where was a garden, into which entered himself and the disciples of him.
Knew and also Judas, he delivering up him, the place; because often met the Jesus there with the disciples of himself.
The then Judas having taken then band, and from the highpriests and Pharisees officers, comes there with torches and lamps and weapons.
Jesus therefore knowing all the things coming on him, going out said to them: Whom seek you?
They answered him: Jesus the Nazarene. Says to them the Jesus: I am. (Was standing and also Judas, the delivering up him, with them.)
When therefore he said to them: That I am; they went into the behind, and fell on the ground.
Again then them he asked: Whom seek you? They and said: Jesus the Nazarene.
Answered Jesus: I said to you, that I am; if therefore me you seek, suffer these to go.
So that might be fulfilled the word, which he said: That whom thou hast given to me, not I lost of them no one.
Simon then Peter having a sword, drew her, and struck the of the highpriest slave, and cut off of him the ear the right. Was now a name to the slave Malchus.
Said therefore the Jesus to the Peter: Put up the sword into the sheath; the cup which has given to me the Father, not not should I drink it?
The then band and the commander and the officers of the Jews apprehend the Jesus, and bound him,
and led him to Annas first; he was for fatherinlaw of the Caiaphas, who was highpriest of the year that.
Was now Caiaphas he having advised the Jews, that it is better one man to be destroyed in behalf of the people.
Followed and the Jesus Simon Peter, and the other disciples. The and disciples that was known to the highpriest, and went in with the Jesus into the palace of the highpriest.
The but Peter stood at the door without. Went out therefore the disciples the other, who was known to the highpriest, and spoke to the doorkeeper, and brought in the Peter.
Says then the femaleservant the doorkeeper to the Peter: Not also thou of the disciples art the man this? Says he: Not I am.
Stood and the slaves and the officers a coal fire having made, because cold it was, and warmed themselves; was and with them the Peter standing and warming himself.
The therefore highpriest asked the Jesus concerning the disciples of him, and concerning the teaching of him.
Answered him the Jesus: I publicly spoke to the world; I always taught in a synagogue and in the temple, where all the Jews come together, and in secret I said nothing.
Why me dost thou ask? ask those having heard, what I said to them; lo, they know what things said I.
These things and of him having said, one of the officers having stood by gave a blow to the Jesus, saying: Thus dost thou answer the highpriest?
Answered him the Jesus: If evil I spoke, testify concerning the evil; if but well, why me dost thou beat?
Sent him the Annas having been bound to Caiaphas the highpriest.
Was and Simon Peter standing and warming himself. They said therefore to him: Not also thou of the disciples of him thou art? Denied he, and said: Not I am.
Says one of the slaves of the highpriest, a relative being of whom cut off Peter the ear: Not I thee saw in the garden with him?
Again therefore denied the Peter; and immediately cock crew.

They led then the Jesus from of the Caiaphas into the Jerusalem hall; it was and morning. And they not went into the judgment hall, that not they might be defiled, but that they might eat the passover.
Went out therefore the Pilate to them, and said: What accusation bring you against the man this?
They answered and said to him: If not was this an evildoer, not would to thee we delivered up him.
Said then to them the Pilate: Take him you, and according to the law of you judge him. Said therefore to him the Jews: To us not it is lawful to kill no one.
So that the word of the Jesus might be fulfilled, which he said, pointing out by what death he was about to die.
Went then into the judgment hall again the Pilate, and called the Jesus, and said to him: Thou art the king of the Jews?
Answered him the Jesus: From thyself thou this sayest, or others to thee told concerning me?
Answered the Pilate: Not I a Jew am? the nation the thine and highpriests delivered up thee to me; what didst thou do?

Answered Jesus: The kingdom the mine not is of the world this; if of the world this was the kingdom the mine, the officers would those for me contend, that not I might be delivered up to the Jews, now but the kingdom the mine not is from this place.

Said then to him the Pilate: Not then a king art thou? Answered the Jesus: Thou sayest; that a king am I. I for this have been born, and for this I have come into the world, that I may testify to the truth. Every one who being of the truth, hears of me the voice.
Says to him the Pilate: What is truth? And this saying, again he went out to the Jews, and says to them: I not one fault find in him.
It is but a custom for you, that one to you I release in the passover; are you willing therefore, to you I release the king of the Jews?
They cried out then again all saying: Not this, but the Barabbas. Was now the Barabbas a robber.
Then therefore took the Pilate the Jesus, and scourged.
And the soldiers braiding a crown of thorns, placed of him the head, and a mantle purple threw about him,
and said: Hail the king of the Jews; and they gave him blows.
Went again out the Pilate, and says to them: Lo, I bring to you him out, that you may know, that in him not one fault I find.
(Came then the Jesus out, wearing the thorny crown, and the purple mantle.) And he says to them: See the man.
When therefore saw him the highpriests and officers, they cried out saying: Crucify, crucify him. Says to them the Pilate: Take him you, and crucify; I for not find in him a fault.
Answered him the Jews: We a law have, and according to the law of us he ought to die, because himself, a son of God he made.
When therefore heard the Pilate this the word, more he was afraid;
and went into the judgment hall again, and says to the Jesus: Whence art thou? The but Jesus an answer not gave to him.
Says then to him the Pilate: To me not thou doest speak? not knowest thou, that authority I have to crucify thee; and authority I have to release thee?
Answered Jesus: Not thou couldst have authority not any against me, if not it was to thee having been given from above; on account of this he delivering up me to thee, greater sin has.
From this seeks the Pilate to release him. The but Jews cried out, saying: If this thou release, not thou art a friend of the Caesar; every one the king himself making, speaks against the Caesar.
The therefore Pilate having heard this the word, brought out the Jesus, and sat down on the tribunal into a place being called Pavement, in Hebrew but Gabbatha;
(it was and a preparation of the passover, hour and about sixth;) and he says to the Jews: See the king of you.
They but cried out: Away, away; crucify him. Says to them the Pilate: The king of you shall I crucify? Answered the highpriests: Not we have a king, if not Caesar.
Then therefore he delivered up him to them, that he might be crucified. They took and the Jesus and led.
And carrying the cross of himself, he went out into the being called of a skull a place, which is called in Hebrew Golgotha.
Where him they crucified, and with him others two, hence and hence, in middle and the Jesus.
Wrote and also a title the Pilate, and placed upon the cross. It was and having been written: Jesus the Nazarene, the king of the Jews.
This therefore the title many read of the Jews, because near was the place of the city, where was crucified the Jesus; and it was having been written in Hebrew, in Greek, in Latin.
Said therefore to the Pilate the highpriests of the Jews: Not write thou: The king of the Jews; but that he said: A king I am of the Jews.
Answered the Pilate: What I have written, I have written.

The then soldiers, when they crucified the Jesus, took the mantles of him, (and made four parts, to each soldier a part,) and the coat. Was but the coat without seam, from the top woven throughout whole;

they said then to each other: Not let us tear him, but we may cast lots about him, of whom it shall be. That the writing might be fulfilled that saying: They divided the mantles of me for themselves, and on the raiment of me they cast a lot. The indeed therefore soldiers these things did.
Stood now by the cross of the Jesus the mother of him, and the sister of the mother of him, Mary that of the Klopas, and Mary the Magdalene.
Jesus therefore seeing the mother, and the disciples standing by, whom he loved, he says to the mother of himself: O woman, lo, the son of thee.
Then he says to the disciples: Lo, the mother of thee. And from that the hour took the disciple her into the own.
After this knowing the Jesus, that all things already had been finished that might be finished the writing, says: I thirst.
A vessel therefore stood of vinegar full; they and filling a sponge of vinegar, and to a hyssopstalk putting round, brought of him to the mouth.
When therefore took the vinegar the Jesus said: It has been finished; and having inclined the head, he gave up the spirit.

The then Jews (that not might remain on the cross the bodies in the sabbath; since a preparation it was; was for great the day that of the sabbath) asked the Pilate, that might be broken of them the legs, and they might be taken away.
Came therefore the soldiers, and of the indeed first, they brake the legs, and of the other that having been crucified with him.
To but the Jesus having come, when they saw him already having died, not they broke of him the legs;
but one of the soldiers with a spear of him the side pierced, and immediately came out blood and water.
And he having seen has testified, and true of him is the testimony; and he knows, that rue things he says, so that also you may believe.
Occurred for these things, that the writing might be fulfilled: A bone not shall be broken of him.
And again another writing says: They shall look into whom they pierced.

After and these things, asked the Pilate the Joseph that from Arimathea, (being a disciple of the Jesus, having been hid but through the fear of the Jews,) that he might take away the body of the Jesus, and permitted the Pilate. He came therefore and took away the body of the Jesus.
Came and also Nicodemus, (the having come to the Jesus by night the first,) bringing a mixture of myrrh and aloes about pounds a hundred.
They took therefore the body of the Jesus, and bound it with linen cloths with the spices, as customary it is with the Jews to embalm.
Was and in the place, where he was crucified, a garden, and in the garden a tomb new, in which not yet no one was laid.
There therefore on account of the preparation of the Jews, because near was the tomb, they laid the Jesus.
The and first of the week Mary the Magdalene comes early, dark yet being, into the tomb; and sees the stone having been taken away out of the tomb,
she runs therefore and comes to Simon Peter, and to the other disciple, whom loved the Jesus, and says to them: They took away the Lord out of the tomb, and not we know, where they laid him.
Went out then the Peter and the other disciples, and they came into the tomb.
Ran and they two together; and the other disciple ran before more quickly of the Peter, and came first into the tomb;
and stooping down he sees lying the linen cloths; not however he went in.
Comes then Simon Peter following him, and entered into the tomb, and sees the linen cloths lying,
and the napkin which was on the head of him, not with the linen cloths lying, but apart having been folded up into one place.
Then therefore went in also the other disciple, he coming first into the tomb, and saw, and believed.
Not yet for they knew the writing, that it behooved him out of dead ones to have been raised.
Went then again to themselves the disciples.
Mary but stands by the tomb weeping outside. As therefore she wept, she stopped down into the tomb,
and sees two messengers in white sitting, one at the head, and one at the feet, where was laid the body of the Jesus.
And say to her they: O woman, why weepest thou? She says to them: Because they took away the Lord of me, and not I know where they laid him.
These things having said, she turned into the behind, and sees the Jesus standing; and not knew, that Jesus it is.

Says to her the Jesus: O woman, why weepest thou? whom seekest thou? She, supposing that the gardener it is, says to him: O sir, if thou didst carry off him, tell me where thou didst lay him, and I him will take away.
Says to her the Jesus: Mary. Turning round she says to him: Rabboni, which means, O teacher.

Says to her the Jesus: Not me touch; not yet for I have gone up to the Father of me; go but to the brethren of me, and say to them: I go up to the Father of me and Father of you, even God of me and God of you.
Comes Mary the Magdalene telling the disciples, that she had seen the Lord, and these things he said to her.

Being then evening in the day that the first of the week, and the doors having been shut, where were the disciples having been assembled, through the fear of the Jews, came the Jesus, and stood into the midst, and says to them: Peace to you.
And this having said, he showed to them the hands and the side of himself. Were glad therefore the disciples, seeing the Lord.
Said then to them the Jesus again: Peace to you; as sent me the Father, also I send you.
And this having said, he breathed on, and says to them: Receive you a spirit holy.
If of whom you may forgive the sins, they are forgiven them; if of whom you may retain, they have been retained.
Thomas but, one of the twelve, he being called a twin, not was with them when came the Jesus.

Said then to him the other disciples: We have seen the Lord. He but said to them: If not I may see in the hands of him the mark of the nails, and may put the finger of me into the mark of the nails, and may put the hand of me into the side of him, not not I will believe.
And after days eight again were within the disciples of him, and Thomas with them. Comes the Jesus, the doors having been shut, and stood into the midst, and said: Peace to you.
Afterwards he says to the Thomas: Bring the finger of thee here, and see the hands of me, and bring the hand of thee, and put into the side of me; and not be thou unbelieving, but believing.
Answered Thomas and said to him: The Lord of me and the God of me.
Says to him the Jesus: Because thou hast seen me, thou hast believed; blessed they not having seen, and having believed.
Many indeed then and other signs did the Jesus in presence of the disciples of him, which not it is having been written in the book this.
These things but have been written, that you may believe, that Jesus is the Anointed, the son of the God, and that believing life you may have in the name of him.
After these things manifested himself again the Jesus to the disciples on the sea of the Tiberias. He manifested and thus.
Were together Simon Peter, and Thomas he being called a twin, and Nathanael he from Cana of the Galilee, and they of the Zebedee, and others of the disciples of him two.
Says to them Simon Peter: I am going to fish. They say to him: Are going also we with thee. They went out, and entered into the ship immediately, and in that the night they caught nothing.
Morning but now being come, stood the Jesus on the shore; not however knew the disciples, that Jesus it is.
Says therefore to them the Jesus: Children, not any food have you? They answered him: No.
He and said to them: Cast you into the right parts of the ship the net, and you will find. They cast then, and no longer it to draw were able from the multitude of the fishes.

Says therefore the disciple that whom loved the Jesus, to the Peter: The Lord it is; Simon then Peter, having heard that the Lord it is, the upper garment he girded; he was for naked; and threw himself into the sea.
The but other disciples by the little ship came (not for they were far from the land, but about from cubits two hundred), dragging the net of the fishes.
When therefore they went up to the land, they see a fire of coals lying, and a fish lying on, and bread.
Says to them the Jesus: Bring you from the fishes, which you caught just now.
Went up Simon Peter, and drew the net to the land, full of fishes, great a hundred fiftythree; and so many being, not was torn the net.
Says to them the Jesus: Come, breakfast you. No one but presumed of the disciples to ask him: Thou who art? knowing, that the Lord it is.
Comes the Jesus, and takes the bread, and gives to them, and the fish in like manner.
This already third was manifested the Jesus to the disciples of himself, having been raised out of the dead ones.

When therefore they had breakfasted, says to the Simon Peter the Jesus: Simon of Jona, lovest thou me more of these? He says to him: Yes, O lord, thou knowest, that I dearly love thee. He says to him: Feed the lambs of me.
He says to him again a second time: Simon of Jona, lovest thou me? He says to him: Yes, O lord, thou knowest, that I dearly love thee. He says to him: Tend thou the sheep of me.

He says to him the third: Simon of Jona, dearly lovest thou me? Was grieved the Peter, because he said to him the third, Dearly lovest me thou? and he said to him: O lord, thou all things knowest; thou knowest, that i dearly love thee. Says to him the Jesus: Feed the sheep of me.

Indeed indeed I say to thee, when thou wast younger, thou didst gird thyself, and didst walk where thou didst wish; when but thou art old, thou wilt stretch out the hands of thee, and another thee will gird, and will carry where not thou wishest.
This now he said, signifying, by what death he will glorify the God. And this having said, he says to him: Follow me.
Having turned about and the Peter sees the disciples, whom loved the Jesus, following (who also reclined at the supper on the breast of him, and said: O lord, who is he betraying thee?)
Him seeing the Peter says to the Jesus: O lord, this and what?
Says to him the Jesus: If him I wish to abide till I come, what to thee? thou follow me.
Went out therefore the word this among the brethren, that the disciple that not dies. And not said to him the Jesus, that not he dies; but: If him I wish to abide till I come, what to thee?
This is the disciple, he testifying concerning these things, and having written these things; and we know, that true is the testimony of him.
Is and also other many things did the Jesus, which if they should be written every one, not even him I suppose the world to contain the being written books.
The indeed first account I made concerning all things, O Theophilus, which began the Jesus to do and also to teach,
even to which day, having given charge to the apostles, through spirit holy whom he chose, he was taken up.
To whom also he presented himself living after the to suffer him, in many clear proofs, through days forty being seen by them, and saying the things concerning the kingdom of the God.
And assembling them he command them, from Jerusalem not to depart, but to wait for the promise of the Father, which you heard from me;
that John indeed dipped in water, you but shall be dipped in spirit holy, not after many these days.
They indeed therefore having come together, asked him; saying: O lord, if in the time this thou restorest the kingdom to the Israel?
He said and to them: Not for you it is to know times or seasons, which the Father placed in the own authority.
But you shall receive power having come the holy spirit upon you; and you shall be to me witnesses in both Jerusalem, and in all the Judea and in Samaria, and even to farthest part of the land.
And these things having said, beholding of them he was lifted up; and a cloud withdrew him from the eyes of them.
And as fixedly gazing they were into the heaven, going away of him, and lo, men two were standing by them in raiment white,
they and said: Men of Galilee, why stand you looking into the heaven? this the Jesus, he being taken up from you into the heaven, thus will come, which manner you saw him going into the heaven.
Then they returned into Jerusalem from a mountain that being called of olivetrees, which is near Jerusalem, a sabbath being distant journey.

And when they came into, they went up into the upper room, where were remaining, the, both Peter and James, and John and Andrew, Philip and Thomas, Bartholomew and Matthew, James of Alpheus also Simon the zealot and Judas of James.
These all were being constantly engaged with one mind in the prayer, with women, and Mary the mother of the Jesus, and with the brothers of him.
And in the days these having stood up Peter in middle of the disciples, he said: (was and a crowd of names, in the same about a hundred twenty;)

Men brethren, it was necessary to be fulfilled the writing this, which spoke before the spirit the holy through mouth of David, about Judas that having become a guide to those having seized the Jesus;
because having been numbered he was among us, and obtained the lot of the service this.
This indeed therefore bought a field out of a reward of the wickedness; and headforemost having fallen, he burst in middle, and were poured out all the bowels of him;
and known became to all those dwelling in Jerusalem, so as to be called the field that in the own language of them, Aceldama, this is, a field of blood.
It is written for in book of psalms: Let be the dwelling of him desolate, and not let be the dwelling in her; and, The charge of him let take another.
It is necessary therefore of those having associated with us men in all time, in which went in and went out among us the Lord Jesus,
beginning from the dipping of John to the day which he was taken up from us, a witness of the resurrection of him to become with us one of these.
And they set forth two, Joseph that being call Barsabas, who was surnamed Justus, and Matthias.
And praying they said: Thou, O Lord, heartknower of all, show which thou didst select out of these the two one,
to take the lot of the service this and apostleship, from which stepped aside Judas, to go into the place the own.
And they gave lots of them; and fell the lot on Matthias, and he was counted with the eleven apostles.
And in the to be fully come the day of the Pentecost, were all with one mind in the same.
And were suddenly from the heaven a sound as of a rushing wind violent, and it filled whole the house, were they were sitting;
and they saw with them being divided tongues like fire; sat and on one each one of them,
and they were filled all spirit holy, and they began to speak with other tongues, as the spirit gave to them to speak.
Were now in Jerusalem dwelling Jews, men pious, from every nation of those under the heaven.
Having happened and the sound this, came together the multitude, and were perplexed; because heard one each in the own language speaking of them.
Were astonished and all and wondered, saying to each other: Not lo all these are who are speaking Galileans?
And how we hear each one in the own language of us, in which we were born,
Parthians and Medes and Elamites, and those dwelling the Mesopotamia, Judea both and Cappadocia, Pontus and the Asia,
Phrygia both and Pamphylia, Egypt and the parts of the Lybia that upon Cyrene, and those sojourning Romans, Jews both and proselytes,
Cretans and Arabians, we hear speaking them in the our tongues the great things of the God?
Were astonished and all and perplexed, one to another saying: What will this to be?
Others but deriding said: That sweet wine having been filled they are.
Standing up but Peter with the eleven, lifted up the voice of himself, and said to them: Men Jews, and those dwelling in Jerusalem all, this to you known let be, and listen you the words of me.
Not for, as you suppose, these are drunk; it is for hour third of the day;
but this is that having been spoken through the prophet Joel:

And it shall be in the last the days, say the God, I will pour out from of the spirit of me upon all flesh; and shall prophesy the sons of you and the daughters of you, and the young men of you visions shall see, and the old men of you dreams shall dream;
and even on the maleslaves of me and on the femaleslaves of me in the days those I will pour out from of the spirit of me, and they shall prophesy.
And I will give prodigies in the heaven above, and signs on the earth below, blood and fire and a cloud of smoke;
the sun shall be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood, sooner than to come the day of Lord the great and illustrations.
And it shall be, every one who may call upon the name of Lord, shall be saved.

Men Israelites, hear you the words these: Jesus the Nazarene, a man from the God having been pointed out to you by mighty works and prodigies and signs, (which did through him the God in midst of you, as also yourselves you know,)
this by the having been fixed purpose and foreknowledge of the God given up having been taken, by hands of lawless ones having affixed to you killed.
Whom the God raised up; having loosed the pains of the death, in as much as not was possible to be held him under it.
David for says concerning him: I saw the Lord in presence of me always, because at right hand of he is, so that not I may be shaken.
Through this rejoiced the heart of me, and exulted the tongue of me; moreover and also the flesh of me will repose in hope;
because not thou will abandon the life of me to invisibility, nor thou wilt abandon the holy one of thee to see corruption.
Thou didst make known to me ways of life; thou will fill me of joy with the face of thee.
Men brethren, it is lawful to speak with freedom to you concerning the patriarch David, that both he died and was buried, and the tomb of him is among us till of the day this.
A prophet there being, and knowing that with an oath swore to him the God, out of fruit of the loins of him to cause to sit on the throne of him,
foreseeing he spoke concerning the resurrection of the Anointed, that not he was abandoned into invisibility, nor the flesh of him saw corruption.
This the Jesus raised up the God, of which all we are witnesses.
To the right hand therefore of the God having been exalted, the and promise of the holy spirit having received from the Father, he poured out this, which you see and hear.
Not for David ascended into the heavens; he says but himself: Said the Lord to the lord of me: Sit thou at right hand of me,
till I may place the enemies of thee a footstool for the feet of thee.
Certainly therefore let know all house of Israel, that both Lord him and Anointed the God made, this the Jesus, whom you crucified.
Having heard and they were pierced to the heart, said and to the Peter and the other apostles: What shall we do, men brethren?
Peter and said to them: Reform you, and be dipped each one of you in the name of Jesus Anointed, for forgiveness of sins, and you shall receive the gifts of the holy spirit.
To you for is the promise and to the children of you, and to all those at a distance as many as may call Lord the God of us.
Other and words with many he testified, and exhorted, saying: Be saved from the generation of the perverse this.
They indeed therefore gladly having received the word of him, were dipped; and were added the day that souls about three thousand.
Were and constantly attending to the teachings of the apostles, and to the distribution, and to the breaking of the loaf, and to the prayers.
Came and to every soul fear, many and prodigies and signs through the apostles were done.
All and those believing were in the same, and had all things common,
and the possessions and the goods they were selling; and they were dividing them to all, as any one need had.
Every day and constantly attending with one mind in the temple, breaking and at home bread, they were partaking of food in gladness and singleness of heart,
praising the God, and having favor with whole the people. The and Lord was adding those being saved everyday to the congregation.
In the same now Peter and John were going up into the temple at the hour of the prayer the ninth.

And a certain man lame from womb of mother of himself being, was being carried; whom they placed every day at the door of the temple that being called beautiful, the to ask alms from those entering into the temple.
Who seeing Peter and John being about to go into the temple, asked alms to receive.
Looking steadily and Peter on him with the John, said: Look on us.
He and gave heed to them, expecting something from them to receive.
Said and Peter: Silver and gold not are possessed by me; what but I have, this to thee I give. In the name of Jesus Anointed the Nazarene do thou arise and walk.
And having taken him the right hand he rose up; immediately and were strengthened of him the feet and the anklebones.
And leaping up he stood, and walked; and entered with them into the temple, walking and leaping, and praising the God.
And saw him all the people walking and praising the God;
they knew and him, that he was who for the alms sitting at the beautiful gate of the temple; and they were filled with wonder and amazement at that having happened to him.
Holding fast and of him the Peter and John, ran together to them all the people to the porch that being called of Solomon, awestruck.
Seeing and Peter answered to the people: Men Israelites, why do you wonder at this? or to us why look you earnestly, as by own power or piety having been made of the to walk him?

The God of Abraham and Isaac and Jacob, the God of the fathers of us, glorified the servant of himself Jesus, whom you indeed delivered up, and denied him in face of Pilate, having judged he to release.
You but the holy and righteous denied, and asked a man a murderer to be granted to you,
the and prince of the life you killed; whom the God raised out of dead ones, of whom we witnesses are;
and by the faith of the name of him, this whom you behold and know, strengthened the name of him; and the faith that through him gave to him the perfect soundness this in presence of all of you.
And now, brethren, I know that in ignorance you did, as also the rulers of you.
The but God what he foretold through mouth of all of the prophets of himself, to suffer the Anointed, he fulfilled thus.
Reform you therefore and turn you, in order that the to be wiped out of you the sins, that may come seasons of refreshing from face of the Lord,
and he may send him having been before destined for you Jesus Anointed;
whom must heaven indeed to receive till time of restoration of all things, which spoke the God through mouth of the holy of himself prophets from an age.
Moses indeed to the fathers said: That a prophet to you shall raise up Lord the God of you, from of the brethren of you; like me; of him you shall hear in all things, which he may speak to you.
It shall be and, every soul whatever not may hear the prophet that, shall be destroyed out of the people.
Also all and the prophets from Samuel and those succeeding as many as spoke also told of the days these.
You are the sons of the prophets, and of the covenant, which ratified the God to the fathers of us, saying to Abraham: And in the seed of thee shall be blessed all the families of the earth.
To you first the God, having raised up the servant of himself, sent him blessing you, in the to turn each one from the evil deeds of you.
Speaking and of them to the people, and came upon them the priests and the captain of the temple and the Sadducees,
being grieved through the to teach them the people, and to announce in the Jesus the resurrection that out of dead ones.
And they laid on them the hands, and put into keeping to the morrow; it was for evening now.
Many but of those having heard the word believed; and became the number of the men about thousand five.
It happened and on the morrow to be assembled of them the rulers and elders and scribes at Jerusalem;
also Annas the highpriest, and Caiaphas and John and Alexander, and as many as were of the family of highpriesthood.
And having placed them in middle they asked: By what power, or in what name did this you?
Then Peter being filled with spirit holy, said to them: Rulers of the people, and elders of the Israel,
if we today be examined to for kindness a man sick, by what he has been saved.

Known be it all to you and to all the people of Israel, that in the name of Jesus Anointed the Nazarene, whom you crucified whom the God raised out of the dead ones, by him this has stood in presence of you sound.
This is the stone that having been despised by you the builders, the having been made into a head of a corner.
And not is in another to any one the salvation; not even for a name is another under the heaven, that having been given among men, in which must to be saved us.
Seeing and the of the Peter boldness and of John, and having perceived, that men unlearned they are and ungifted, they wondered, they knew and them, that with the Jesus they were;
the and man beholding with them standing that having been healed, nothing they had to say against.
Having ordered and them outside of the highcouncil to go, they consulted with each other,
saying: What shall we do to the men these? that indeed for known a sign has been done by them, to all those dwelling in Jerusalem manifest, and not we were able to deny.
But that not to more it may spread among the people, with a threat let us threaten them, no longer to speak in the name this to any man.
And having called them, they charged them not at all not to speak nor to teach in the name of the Jesus.
The but Peter and John answering to them said: If just it is in presence of the God, you to hearken rather than the God, judge you.
Not are able for we, what we saw and heard, not to speak.
They and having again threatened them dismissed them, nothing finding the how they might punish them, on account of the people; because all glorified the God on account of that having been done.
Years for was more forty the man; on whom was wrought the sign this of the cure.
Having been dismissed and they came to the own friends, and related what things to them the highpriests and the elders said.
They and having heard, with one mind lifted up a voice to the God, and said: O Sovereign, thou the God, that having made the heaven and the earth and the sea, and all the things in them;
who through mouth of David a servant of thee having said: Why raged nations, and peoples devised vain things?
Stood up the kings of the earth, and the rulers were assembled in the same, against the Lord, and against the Anointed of him.
Were gathered for in truth in the city this against the holy servant of thee Jesus, whom thou didst anoint, Herod both and Pontius Pilate, with Gentiles and peoples of Israel,
to do what things the hand of thee and the will of thee before marked out to be done.
And now, O Lord, look thou upon the treats of them, and grant to the slaves of thee, with freedom all to speak the word of thee,
in the the hand of thee to stretch out thee for healing, and signs and prodigies to do through the name of the holy child of thee Jesus.
And having prayed of them was shaken the place, in which they were assembled; and they were filled all of a spirit holy, and spoke the word of the God with freedom.
Of the and multitude of those having believed was the heart and the soul one; and not even one any of the possessions of him said his own to be, but was to them all things common.
And with great power the testimony the apostles of the resurrection of the Lord Jesus; favor and great was on all them.
Not even for the poor any one was among them; such as for owners of lands or houses were, were selling bringing the prices of those being sold,
and were placing at the feet of the apostles; it was divided and to each one, according as might one need have.
Joses and, he being surnamed Barnabas by the apostles, (which is being translated, a son of exhortation,) a Levite, a Cyprian by the birth,
having to him a field, having sold brought the price, and placed at the feet of the apostles.
A man but certain Ananias by name, with Sapphira the wife of himself, sold a possession;
and kept back from the price, being privy also the wife of him; and having brought a part certain, at the feet of the apostles placed.
Said and Peter: Ananias, why has filled the adversary the heart of thee, to deceive thee the spirit the holy, and to keep back from the price of the land?
Not remaining, to thee it remained, and having been sold, in the thine authority it was? why that hast thou placed in the heart of thee the thing this? not thou hast lied to men, but to the God.
Having heard and the Ananias the words these, falling down breathed out. And came a fear great on all those having heard these.
Having arisen and the younger ones wrapped up him, and having carried out they buried.
It happened and about hours three apart, and the wife of him not having known that having been done came in.
Answered and to her the Peter: Tell me, if for so much the land you sold? She and said: Yes for so much.
The and Peter said to her: Why that it has been agreed upon by you to tempt the spirit of Lord? Lo the feet of those having buried the husband of thee, at the door, and they will carry out thee.
She fell and immediately at the feet of him, and breathed out; having come in and the younger ones found her dead, and having carried out they buried with the husband of her.
And came a fear great on whole the assembly, and on all those having heard these things.
Through and the hands of the apostles were done signs and prodigies among the people many; and they were with one mind all in the portico of Solomon;
of the and others no one presumed to join himself to them. But magnified them the people;
(more and were added believing to the Lord multitudes of men both and women;)
so that in the open squares to bring out the sick ones, and to place on beds and couches, that coming of Peter if even the shadow might overshadow some of them.
Came together and also the multitude from the surrounding cities into Jerusalem, bringing sick ones and those being troubled by spirits impure; whom were healed all.
Having arisen and the high priest and all those with him, the being sect of the Sadducees, were filled of anger.
And laid the hands of them on the apostles, and placed them in prison public.
A messenger but of a Lord by the night opened the doors of the prison, having brought out and them said:
Go, and standing speak you in the temple to the people all the words of the life this.

Having heard and they entered at the dawn into the temple, and taught. Having come and the highpriest and those with him, they called together the high council even all the senate of the sons of Israel, and sent into the prison, to have brought them.
The but officers having gone not found them in the prison; having returned and reported,
saying: That the indeed prison we found having been closed with all safety, and the guards standing before the doors; having opened but, within no one we found.
When and they heard the words these the, both priest and the commander of the temple and the highpriests, they doubted concerning them, what might be this.
Having come but one told them: That lo, the men whom you put in the prison, are in the temple standing and teaching the people.
Then having gone the commander with the officers, they brought them, not with violence; they feared for the people, that not they might be stoned.
Having brought and them they stood in the sanhedrim. And asked them the highpriest,
saying: Not with a charge we charged you, not to teach in the name this? and lo, you have filled the Jerusalem of the teaching of you, and you wish to bring on us the blood of the man this.
Answering and the Peter and the apostles, said: To obey it is necessary God rather than men.
The God of the fathers of us raised up Jesus, whom you laid violent hands upon, having hanged on a cross;
him the God a prince and a savior has lifted up to the right hand of himself, to give reformation to the Israel, and forgiveness of sins.
And we are of him witnesses of the matters these, and the spirit also the holy, which gave the God to those submitting to him.
They and having heard were enraged, and took counsel to kill them.
Having arisen and one in the high council a Pharisee, by name Gamaliel a teacher of law, honored by all the people, ordered without a little while the apostles to be put.
He said and to them: Men Israelites, take heed to yourselves, to the men these, what you are about to do.

Before for these the days stood up Theudas, saying to be some one himself, to whom adhered a number of men about four hundred; who was put to death, and all as many as listened to him, were dispersed, and came to nothing.
After this stood up Judas the Galilean, in the days of the registering, and drew away people much behind himself; and he was destroyed, and all as many as listened to him, were dispersed.
And now I say to you, withdraw from the men these, and let alone them, because if may be from men the counsel this or the work this, it will be overthrown;
if but from God it is, not you are able to overthrow them, not and fighters against God you should be found.
They were persuaded and by him; and having called the apostles, having beaten they commanded not to speak in the name of the Jesus, and released them.
They indeed therefore went rejoicing from presence of the highcouncil, because in behalf of the name they were accounted worthy to be dishonored.
Every and day in the temple and at home not they ceased teaching and announcing glad tidings of Jesus the Anointed.
In and the days those increasing the disciples, came a murmuring of the Hellenists to the Hebrews, because were overlooked in the service the daily the widows of them.
Having called and the twelve the multitude of the disciples, said: Not proper it is us having left the word of the God, to serve tables.
Look you out therefore, brethren, men from of you being attested seven, full of spirit and wisdom, whom we will appoint to the need this;
we but to the prayer and to the service of the word will constantly attend.

And pleased the word in presence of all of the multitude; and they chose Stephen, a man full of faith and spirit holy, and Philip, and Prochorus, and Nicanor, and Timon, and Parmenas, and Nicolaus a proselyte of Antioch;
whom they placed in presence of the apostles; and having prayed they put to them the hands.
And the word of the God grew, and was multiplied the number of the disciples in Jerusalem greatly; great and a crowd of the priests were obedient to the faith.
Stephen and full of favor and of power performed prodigies and signs great among the people.
Stood up and some of those from the synagogue of that being called of Libertines, and of Cyrenians, and of Alexandrians, and of those from Cilicia and Asia, disputing with the Stephen;
and not were able to resist the wisdom and the spirit with which he spoke.
Then they thrust under men, saying: That we have heard him speaking words blasphemous against Moses and the God.
They stirred up and the people and the elders and the scribes, and having come upon they seized him, and led into the high council,
stood up and witnesses false, saying: The man this not ceases words speaking against the place of the holy and the law.
We have heard for him saying: That Jesus the Nazarene this will destroy the place this, and will change the customs, which delivered to us Moses.
And having gazed on him all those being seated in the highcouncil, saw the face of him like a face of a messenger.
Said and the highpriest: If then these things thus are?
He and said: Men brethren and fathers, hear you. The God of the glory appeared to the father of us Abraham being in the Mesopotamia, before to dwell him in Charran.
And said to him: Go out from the land of thee, and from the kindred of thee, and come into a land, which to thee I may show.
Then going out from land of Chaldeans, he dwelt in Charran; and thence, after the to have died the father of him, he caused to remove him into the land this, in which you now dwell;
and not he gave to him inheritance in her, not even a footbreadth; and he promised to him to give for a possession her, and to the seed of him after him, not being to him a child.
Spoke and thus the God: That shall be the seed of him a stranger in a land foreign, and they will enslave it and they will oppress years fourhundred;
and the nation, to which they may be enslaved, will judge I, said the God; and after these things they shall come out, and shall render service to me in the place this.
And he gave to him a covenant of circumcision; and thus he begot the Isaac, and circumcised him the day the eighth; and the Isaac the Jacob, and the Jacob the twelve patriarchs.
And the patriarchs envying the Joseph sold into Egypt; and was the God with him,
and delivered him out of all of the afflictions of him, and gave to him favor and wisdom in presence of Pharaoh king of Egypt, and placed him ruling over Egypt and whole the house of himself.
Came and a famine on whole the land of Egypt and Canaan, and affliction great; and not found provisions of fathers of us.
Having heard and Jacob being grain in Egypt, he sent the fathers of us first.
And in the second was made known Joseph to the brothers of himself, and shown became to the Pharaoh the family of the Joseph.
Having sent and Joseph called for the father of himself Jacob, and all the kindred, in souls seventyfive.
Went down and Jacob into Egypt, and died he and the fathers of us.
And they were carried into Sychem, and were placed in the tomb, which bought Abraham for a price of silver from the sons of Emmor of the Sychem.
When but drew near the time of the promise, which swore the God to the Abraham, grew the people and were multiplied in Egypt;
till for whom stood up a king another, who not knew the Joseph.
This having dealt deceitfully the family of us, illtreated the fathers of us, of the to cause to be exposed the babes of them; in order that not they might be preserved.
In which season was born Moses, and was beautiful to the God; who was nursed months three in the house of the father.
Having exposed and him, took up him the daughter of Pharaoh, and nursed him herself for a son.
And was taught Moses in all wisdom of Egyptians; was and powerful in words and in works of himself.
When but was completed to him forty years of time, it came up in the heart of him to visit the brethren of himself, the sons of Israel.
And seeing one being wronged, he defended, and did justice to him being oppressed, having smitten the Egyptian.
He thought and to understand the brethren of himself, that the God by hands of him gives to them salvation; they but not understood.
In the but next day he appeared to those contending, and urged them to peace, saying: Men, brethren are you; why wrong you each other?
He but wronging the neighbor, thrust away him, saying: Who thee has appointed a ruler and a judge over us?
Not to kill me thou wishest, in which manner thou didst kill yesterday the Egyptian?
Fled and Moses at the word this, and became a sojourner in land of Midian, where he begot sons two.
And being completed years forty, appeared to him in the desert of the mountain Sinai a messenger of Lord in a flame of fire of a bush.
The but Moses having seen admired the sight; coming near and of him to observe, came a voice of Lord to him:
I the God of the fathers of thee, the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob. Terrified and being Moses not dared to look.
Said and to him the Lord: Loose the sandals of the feet of thee; the for place in which thou standest, ground holy is.
Having seen I saw the evil treatment of the people of me of that in Egypt, and the groaning of them I have heard, and am come down to deliver them; and now come, I will send thee into Egypt.
This the Moses whom they denied, saying: Who thee appointed a ruler and a judge? this the God a ruler and a redeemer sent by hand of a messenger of that having appeared to him in the bush.
This led out them, having done prodigies and signs in the Egypt, and in red sea, and in the desert, years forty.
This is the Moses, he saying to the sons of Israel: A prophet for you will raise up Lord the God from of the brethren of you, like me; him you shall hear.
This is he being, in the congregation in the desert, with the messenger that speaking to him in the mountain Sinai and of the fathers of us, who received oracles living to give to us;
to whom not were willing obedient to become the fathers of us, but thrust away, and turned back in the hearts of them into Egypt,
saying to the Aaron: Make for us gods, who shall go before us; the for Moses this who led out us from land Egypt, not we know what has happened to him.
And they made a calf in the days those, and offered a sacrifice to the idol, and rejoiced in the works of the hands of them.
Turned and the God, and gave up them to serve the host of the heaven; as it is written in book of the prophets: Not victims and sacrifices did you offer to me forty in the desert, house of Israel?
And you took up the tabernacle of the Moloch and star of the god of you Remphan, the images, which you made to worship them; and I will cause to remove you beyond Babylon.
The tabernacle of the testimony was with the fathers of us in the desert, as directed he speaking to the Moses, to make her according to the form which he had seen;
which also brought having received by succession the fathers of us with Jesus in to the possession of the nations, which drove out the God from face of the fathers of us, till the days of David;
